Swords Dance (Grass).description:
Shiftry has decent Attack and fairly decent Speed with incredible wallbreaking potential thanks to Swords Dance, Black Glasses, and Dark-type STAB moves and is strictly seen on Sunny Day variant Grass teams. Shiftry is great for Psychic- and Ghost-type matchups and beats common threats such as Dragapult and Indeedee. Substitute is useful for avoiding moves like Will-O-Wisp, Toxic, and Strength Sap from Pokemon such as Galarian Corsola, Mew, and Toxapex; with Substitute up, Shiftry can get a free Swords Dance and wall break. The combination of Sucker Punch and Substitute makes it difficult for revenge kills from Pokemon like Trace Gardevoir or Gengar to happen. Chlorophyll doubles its Speed, making Shiftry a fiercer wallbreaker to eliminate. Knock Off is useful for inflicting massive damage and removing the item of anything that tries to switch in against it, while Sucker Punch is useful for KOing faster sweepers such as Dragapult and Gengar. Maximum Speed investment allows Shiftry to outspeed Choice Scarf Charizard and Salazzle in sun, and maximum Attack investment with an Adamant nature permits Shiftry to reach its full wallbreaking potential.

Whimsicott and Virizion are viable options to set up Sunny Day, allowing Shiftry to outspeed Pokemon such as Mew and Jirachi because of Chlorophyll. Whimsicott is a better Sunny Day setter that helps with Dragon-, Dark-, and Fighting-types thanks to Moonblast; Choice Scarf Virizion is useful for outspeeding threats like Alolan Ninetales, Choice Scarf Galarian Darmanitan, and Choice Scarf Charizard and has access to Smart Strike, Stone Edge, and Close Combat, which is useful for the Ice-type matchup. Appletun is one of the only Grass-types that can properly tank Fire-type attacks from Pokemon such as Hydreigon and Dragapult. Venusaur is another Pokemon that takes advantage of sun and can use Life Orb and Growth or Choice Specs and helps in the Fairy- and Steel-type matchup because of Weather Ball and Sludge Bomb. Ferrothorn is one of the best defensive utilities that has access to entry hazards such as Stealth Rock and Spikes; it is useful for tanking attacks from offensive Pokemon like Weavile and Cloyster and is very crucial for the Ice-type matchup. Rotom-C cripples Pokemon with Choice Scarf and Trick, which is incredibly useful for against Pokemon such as Corviknight, Mew, and Toxapex. Finally, Celebi gets Stealth Rock, which allows Ferrothorn to run Spikes, and has a number of coverage moves such as Psychic and Earth Power which helps fend off Poison- and Fighting-type Pokemon better.

Sun Sweeper (Grass).description:
Venusaur is a great sun sweeper because of its ability Chlorophyll, good Special Attack, and good movepool consisting of moves like Growth and Weather Ball. Weather Ball turns into a Fire-type move in the sun that can take care of Corviknight and Aegislash. Giga Drain is used to enable Venusaur to take care of Water- and Ground-types such as Keldeo, Toxapex, and Gastrodon while giving it a way to recover from Life Orb recoil. Sludge Bomb is used to OHKO Fairy-types such as Togekiss and can take care of Hydreigon and Kyurem-B after a single use of Growth. Growth should be used under sun to turn Venusaur into a dangerous sweeper. Earth Power is a niche option that can be used to hit Poison-type Pokemon such as Salazzle and Drapion. Venusaur should try to set up Growth on a predicted switch or on a passive Pokemon like Ferrothorn and Toxapex. It should also come in on via a U-turn or Memento from Whimsicott or on passive Pokemon such as Toxapex. A Modest nature allows it to net an OHKO on Aegislash and Corviknight.

Whimsiscott is a mandatory teammate because of its access to Prankster Sunny Day and its ability to get Venusaur in safely with U-turn or Memento. Shiftry is a great partner to pair with Venusaur because of its Dark typing and Chlorophyll, allowing it to take care of Psychic-types that Venusaur can struggle with such as Jirachi and Indeedee. Shiftry can also take care of Dragapult with Sucker Punch. Celebi also goes great with Venusaur because it can help pressure Fighting-types such as Bulletproof Kommo-o and use Weather Ball to help Venusaur sweep in the Steel-type matchup. Celebi can also greatly help in the Poison-type matchup with Earth Power and Psychic. Ferrothorn is great to pair with Venusaur due to its access to entry hazards like Stealth Rock and Spikes and ability to come in on Ice-type attacks from Cloyster and Alolan Ninetales and physical attacks such as Dracovish's Psychic Fang. Virizion is a great revenge killer that also deals with threats like Snorlax, Hydreigon, Kyurem, and Centiskorch against Normal-, Dark-, Ice-, and Bug-type matchups respectively. It can also take care of Alolan Ninetales with Smart Strike and act as an emergency Sunny Day settler if Whimsicott gets KOed.

Choice Scarf (Fire).description:
Charizard isn't a great option, as it is outclassed by special attackers like Volcarona, Blacephalon, and Heatran. However, thanks to its great Speed, high Special Attack, and Solar Power with sun support, Charizard makes a below-average Choice Scarf user. It's able to outspeed threats such as Choice Scarf Excadrill and Dragapult and threaten them with its powerful attacks. Furthermore, Charizard's great Speed combined with its access to Dragon Pulse notably separates it from other Fire-types, as it helps tremendously with the Dragon matchup. However, Charizard faces competition with Blacephalon as a Choice Scarf user. Its Flying typing is beneficial because it grants immunity to Ground-type attacks, but most Ground-types tend to run Rock coverage anyway and it leaves Charizard even more vulnerable to Stealth Rock. Flamethrower is used in situations where Charizard can't afford missing such as against Choice Scarf Excadrill, which can sweep Fire pretty easily without Charizard to revenge kill it. Fire Blast is the more powerful option, best suited when Charizard wants to deal as much damage as possible against bulky Pokemon like Galarian Slowking, Toxapex, and Tapu Fini. Dragon Pulse is what separates Charizard from other Fire-types, as it muscles past Dragon-types such as Dragapult, Dragonite, and Dragalge. Focus Blast hits bulky Pokemon that resist its Fire STAB moves such as Hydreigon, Heatran, and Rhyperior. Solar Beam is an option to hit Water- and Ground-types like Gastrodon and Slowbro, but the types these Pokemon are on have weather in rain and sand, respectively, which can make Solar Beam unreliable. Due to how powerful its Fire attacks are under sun, it should either break holes in the opposing team early so its teammates can clean up or be preserved for a late-game sweep. Charizard is also great at revenge killing threats such as Dracozolt and Hydreigon.

Torkoal is an amazing teammate because it sets up sun for Charizard with Drought, can remove Stealth Rock with Rapid Spin, and can set its own Stealth Rock to chip Pokemon like Dragapult to support Charizard's wallbreaking. Cinderace revenge kills faster Choice Scarf users like Dragapult and Latias with Sucker Punch and also checks special walls like Tyranitar, Snorlax, and Dragalge. Gunk Shot Cinderace, Sludge Bomb Volcanion, and Flash Cannon Heatran are great to check Fairy-types Charizard is threatened by like Azumarill and Tapu Fini. Volcanion absorbs Water-type attacks from Pokemon like Toxapex, Slowbro, and Araquanid and checks Ground- and Rock-types like Hippowdon, Rhyperior, and Stakataka with Steam Eruption. Incineroar, Volcarona, and Heatran check Psychic-types like Tapu Lele, Latios, and Galarian Slowking. Incineroar provides momentum with Parting Shot or U-turn and is also a great check for Ghost-types like Spectrier and Dragapult thanks to its Dark typing. Furthermore, Knock Off hinders recovery on Pokemon running Leftovers and Black Sludge like Tapu Fini and Dragalge, respectively, for Charizard. Rotom-H and Victini are nice checks to Water-types like Toxapex and Mantine with their respective Electric coverage.

Raichu-Alola.overview:
Electric

Alolan Raichu is one of the best revenge killers and late-game cleaners for Electric teams thanks to its good Speed tier coupled with Surge Surfer, letting it handle threats like Sand Rush Excadrill, Swift Swim Kingdra, and Dragapult in Electric Terrain. It has fantastic coverage options in Psychic to nail Poison-types such as Amoonguss, Dragalge, and Nidoking, Grass Knot to defeat Water-types that are immune to Rising Voltage like Gastrodon, Swampert, and Seismitoad, and Focus Blast for troublesome Dark- and Steel-types like Hydreigon, Tyranitar, and Ferrothorn. However, Alolan Raichu's underwhelming Special Attack makes it unable to OHKO walls like Tyranitar in sand, Heatran, and Ferrothorn, even with a Life Orb. Outside of Electric Terrain, Alolan Raichu is outsped by many threats like Spectrier, Choice Scarf Blacephalon, and Choice Scarf Tapu Lele. Alolan Raichu's very poor bulk makes it unable to come into attacks freely while making it susceptible to priority users like Urshifu-R, Crawdaunt, Dragonite, and Rillaboom.
Raichu-Alola.comments:
Other Options

Electric

Psyshock can be used over Psychic to pressure switch-ins like Blissey and Galarian Slowking and OHKO Nihilego.

Checks and Counters

Electric

Specially Defensive Walls: Specially defensive walls such as Galarian Slowking, Blissey, and Celebi tank multiple attacks from Alolan Raichu and threaten it back with their moves. Galarian Slowking 2HKOes Alolan Raichu with Sludge Bomb, Blissey can wear it down with Seismic Toss, and Celebi can wear it down with Giga Drain. However, Galarian Slowking and Blissey have to be careful of the rare Psyshock.

Residual Damage: Residual damage from Life Orb, entry hazards, and Toxic poison wear down Alolan Raichu.

Electric-resistant Pokemon: Since Alolan Raichu relies on Rising Voltage to sweep teams, Electric-resistant Pokemon such as Latias, Latios, and Tapu Bulu are huge threats to it.

Revenge Killers: Revenge killers such as Choice Scarf Galarian Darmanitan, Choice Scarf Excadrill, and Barraskewda outspeed and OHKO Alolan Raichu if Electric Terrain is not active. Because Alolan Raichu is extremely frail, priority users such as Urshifu-R, Crawdaunt, Dragonite, and Rillaboom can also take it out with no problem. Rillaboom is especially threatening to Alolan Raichu, since it disrupts Electric Terrain.

Terrain Sweeper (Electric).description:
Electric Terrain-boosted Rising Voltage hits foes such as Aegislash, Drapion, and Galarian Corsola for great damage. Psychic nails Poison-types such as Amoonguss, Dragalge, and Nidoking and hits Electric-resistant foes like Dragapult, Landorus-T, and Thundurus-T for good damage. Focus Blast heavily damages Dark-, Steel-, and Ice-types such as Zarude, Tyranitar, Excadrill, Ferrothorn, and Kyurem. Knock Off is useful for removing Galarian Slowking's Assault Vest, making it much easier to deal with for Electric teams. Grass Knot can be used over Knock Off to super effectively hit Water-types that are immune to Rising Voltage such as Swampert, Gastrodon, and Seismitoad and threaten Ground-types like Hippowdon. Nasty Plot can be used over Knock Off or Grass Knot to make Alolan Raichu a fearsome setup sweeper, taking advantage of Pokemon it forces out such as Pelipper and Amoonguss. However, replacing Grass Knot makes Alolan Raichu less effective in the Water and Ground matchups. Maximum Speed investment with a Timid nature lets Alolan Raichu outspeed foes like Hydreigon, Volcarona, and Garchomp outside of Electric Terrain.

Because of Alolan Raichu's mediocre bulk, it appreciates Volt Switch support from teammates like Tapu Koko, Zapdos, and Rotom-W to bring it in safely. Tapu Koko is needed to set Electric Terrain for Alolan Raichu, letting it outspeed extremely fast threats thanks to Surge Surfer. Additionally, Tapu Koko can take on Dragon-types that Alolan Raichu struggles with, like Latias and Latios, thanks to its Dragon immunity and Dazzling Gleam and weaken shared checks such as Galarian Slowking, which Alolan Raichu can capitalize on in the late-game. Zeraora is a fantastic physical wallbreaker, pressuring troublesome specially defensive walls like Blissey and Galarian Slowking. In return, Alolan Raichu can deal with threatening physical walls such as Hippowdon, Gastrodon, and Amoonguss. Choice Specs Zapdos is useful to heavily pressure types like Grass, Ground, and Dragon thanks to its powerful Hurricane, letting it beat foes like Rillaboom, Tapu Bulu, and Garchomp for Alolan Raichu. Rotom-W can remove entry hazards with Defog and deal with foes like Cinderace, Blacephalon, and Barraskewda thanks to its typing. Magnezone's Steel typing lets it handle threats like Dragon Dance Dragapult, Nihilego, and Latias with ease while trapping and taking on problematic Pokemon like Ferrothorn and Excadrill with its Air Balloon set.

Nidoking.overview:
Ground

Nidoking is Ground's best special wallbreaker due to its various coverage moves boosted by Sheer Force and Life Orb, which let it break past physically defensive walls such as Skarmory, Amoonguss, and Ferrothorn that are otherwise difficult for the type to break through. Nidoking also helps against types like Fairy, Flying, Steel, and Grass, as they lack sturdy defensive switch-ins to it. Its part-Poison typing provides useful defensive utility by letting it switch in on Fairy-type attacks and remove Toxic Spikes. It is additionally the only way for Ground teams to set Toxic Spikes themselves. However, while Nidoking can pressure many physically defensive walls, its Speed tier leaves it outsped and KOed by a plethora of offensive Pokemon, such as Tapu Lele, Excadrill, and Hydreigon, to name a few. Nidoking's mediocre bulk also makes it difficult to come in on Pokemon that it can deal with but can wear it down, such as Celesteela, Ferrothorn, and Tapu Bulu. This frailty also makes it vulnerable even to revenge killers lacking super effective moves such as Spectrier.

Poison

Nidoking is one of the best wallbreakers that Poison has to offer thanks to its powerful combination of Life Orb and Sheer Force. Its role as a wallbreaker is very important in the Steel matchup, as Earth Power + Flamethrower demolishes Steel teams after Heatran's Air Balloon has been popped. Nidoking also offers Poison an Electric immunity to prevent Volt Switch spam from Electric-types like Regieleki and Tapu Koko. Its access to BoltBeam coverage allows Nidoking to apply more pressure on Flying teams, which is nice, since Stealth Rock cannot pressure Flying much because of how often it uses Heavy-Duty Boots. Nidoking is, however, slower than many faster threats like Excadrill, Cinderace, and Keldeo and weak to Water-, Ice-, and Ground-type moves like Scald, Ice Beam, and Earthquake. These flaws mean, Nidoking can only come in on certain passive walls or slower Pokemon like Galarian Weezing, Skarmory, and Toxapex.
Nidoking.comments:
Other Options

Ground

Sludge Wave can be used over Earth Power to 2HKO defensive Pokemon that can tank the rest of Nidoking's moves easily such as Rotom-W and Moltres. However, forgoing Earth Power means Nidoking can't break through Heatran, limiting its effectiveness in the Steel matchup. Fire Blast over Flamethrower notably 2HKOes specially defensive Celesteela, but it is less reliable. Substitute is an option to make Nidoking harder to revenge kill, but it is very hard to fit.

Poison

Sludge Wave can be used to notably hit Clefable, because, otherwise, Nidoking may be at risk of losing its item from Knock Off.

Checks and Counters

Ground

Specially Defensive Walls: Specially defensive walls such as Blissey and defensive Rotom-W can tank multiple hits from Nidoking and retaliate.

Revenge Killers: Powerful revenge killers such as Alolan Raichu, Barraskewda, and Spectrier can force out Nidoking easily by threatening an OHKO with their STAB moves. Priority users such as Rillaboom and Mamoswine can outspeed and KO Nidoking with little to no chip damage.

Super Effective Moves: Super effective moves from foes faster than Nidoking such as Tapu Lele, Urshifu-R, and Latios can heavily pressure it. Nidoking must also be wary of super effective attacks from slower foes such as Hippowdon, Slowbro, and Swampert, as it fails to OHKO them.

Poison

Knock Off: Nidoking does not appreciate its item being removed and it being weakened by Knock Off users like Clefable and Tornadus-T.

Priority Moves: Priority moves like Aqua Jet and Ice Shard from Pokemon like Crawdaunt, Azumarill, and Mamoswine can KO Nidoking if their users are running a damage-boosting item like Choice Band or Life Orb, or after some prior chip damage.

Super Effective Attacks: Fast Ground-type Pokemon like Landorus-T, Excadrill, and Garchomp threaten Nidoking out with Earthquake. They also fear switching into Nidoking, though, since they are at risk of being hit by Ice Beam. Water-types like Keldeo, Urshifu-R, and Barraskewda can KO Nidoking with their Water-type STAB moves but do not always appreciate switching in risking a Thunderbolt. Ice-types like Kyurem, Weavile, and Mamoswine can KO Nidoking with Ice-type moves bar Ice Shard, which requires prior chip damage. However, yet again, they fear switching in, this time due to Earth Power or Flamethrower.

Specially Defensive Pokemon: Specially bulky Pokemon like Piloswine, Blissey, and Snorlax can sponge all of Nidoking's attacks. Piloswine can KO Nidoking with Earthquake and set Stealth Rock for chip damage, while Blissey and Snorlax can recover from and switch into its moves whenever due to their high bulk. Blissey can set up Stealth Rock and generate momentum with Teleport, while Snorlax can set up Curse and recover off damage with Rest. Slowking can also generate momentum with Teleport or deal chip damage with Scald, while Mandibuzz can remove Nidoking's Life Orb with Knock Off and recover with Roost.

Revenge Killers: Naturally faster threats like both Urshifu formes, Tapu Lele, and Excadrill, and Choice Scarf users like Galarian Darmanitan and Heracross have no problem KOing Nidoking.

Wallbreaker (Ground).description:
Earth Power is the preferred STAB move, as it covers walls such as Heatran, physically defensive Gastrodon, and Tyranitar. Flamethrower provides great coverage against Steel- and Grass-types such as Skarmory, Amoonguss, Ferrothorn, and Tapu Bulu, hitting them for massive damage. Ice Beam nails Flying- and Dragon-types such as Zapdos, Dragonite, and Garchomp, as well as potential switch-ins like Landorus-T, Latias, and Hydreigon. It also deals with Cradily better than Earth Power. Thunderbolt hits additional Flying-types that are neutral to Ice Beam such as Mantine, Pelipper, and Celesteela super effectively. Toxic Spikes can be used over Earth Power to support the team and quickly wear down grounded foes such as Porygon2. However, Nidoking's poor bulk gives it limited opportunities to set Toxic Spikes, and Earth Power is needed to break through Heatran. Sheer Force works well in tandem with Life Orb, preventing Nidoking from being worn down by Life Orb recoil and stacking damage boosts. A Timid nature allows Nidoking to outspeed the likes of Tapu Bulu and Heatran.

Teammates such as Mamoswine, Landorus-T, and Excadrill appreciate Nidoking's ability to deal with threats like Skarmory and Celesteela. Hippowdon is a good partner, as its Sand Stream and Stealth Rock support wears down foes quickly for Nidoking. Additionally, its good bulk lets it come in on physical attackers such as Choice Scarf Excadrill, Garchomp, and Galarian Zapdos. Excadrill breaks through troublesome specially defensive walls such as Blissey and Slowking for Nidoking, beats Psychic- and Ice-types that it struggles against such as Tapu Lele, Alolan Ninetales, and Kyurem, and provides Rapid Spin support. Under Hippowdon's sand, Excadrill can also outspeed a handful of other offensive threats for Nidoking such as Choice Scarf Blacephalon, Dragapult, and Spectrier. Gastrodon and Seismitoad both provide a Water immunity for Nidoking; Gastrodon's Recover makes it more reliable against threats like Barraskewda, Keldeo, and Tapu Fini, and Seismitoad can check the highly dangerous Azumarill. Mamoswine is a powerful wallbreaker that can revenge kill some faster threats that give Nidoking trouble such as Latias, Dragapult, and Thundurus-T with Ice Shard. Choice Scarf Landorus-T is able to revenge kill additional fast foes such as Spectrier, Tapu Lele, and Volcarona while providing entry hazard removal with Defog. Its Ground immunity is also useful to handle threats such as Excadrill and Garchomp. Bulk Up + Gravity Landorus-T is another option to make Nidoking's Earth Power more spammable while helping in matchups like Poison. Choice Scarf Krookodile can act as a dangerous revenge killer against Ghost- and Psychic-types like Spectrier, Victini, and Latios. Krookodile also provides an immunity against Psychic-type attacks directed at Nidoking.

Wallbreaker (Poison).description:
Nidoking's powerful Earth Power damages Steel-, Electric-, Rock-, and Poison-types like Heatran, Tapu Koko, Rhyperior, and Toxapex. It appreciates Flamethrower for consistency to help with Steel-, Bug-, and Grass-types like Skarmory, Ferrothorn, Buzzwole, and Tapu Bulu, whereas Fire Blast is nice for picking up more KOs against bulkier Steel-types like Celesteela and Corviknight. Both Earth Power and Flamethrower are needed to deal with Steel's defensive cores members: Aegislash, Heatran, and Celesteela, but, Thunderbolt or Ice Beam is needed to pop Heatran's Air Balloon. Thunderbolt is useful for hitting Water- and Flying-types like Mantine and Slowbro, whereas Ice Beam helps with Ground-, Grass-, and Flying-types like Hippowdon, Appletun, and defensive Zapdos. Stealth Rock allows Nidoking to compress the role of entry hazard setter, but the presence of Heavy-Duty Boots reduces the need for hazards. Maximized Speed EVs allow Nidoking to Speed tie an opposing Nidoking and outpace Diggersby and Togekiss.

Nidoking offers the entire team its Electric immunity, but Toxapex appreciates it more than other teammates due to its weakness to Electric. Toxapex's bulk and Scald allow it to switch into physical attackers that threaten Nidoking like Barraskewda and Cinderace while also shutting down setup sweepers like Weavile and Cloyster with Haze. Galarian Weezing provides a Dragon immunity, which is important to switch into a Draco Meteor or Dragon Darts that could KO Nidoking, while also having utilities like Defog to get rid of entry hazards, Will-O-Wisp and Toxic Spikes to spread status, and Pain Split for longevity. Nidoking is weak to Psychic, so adding a Psychic-immune teammate like Skuntank or Drapion helps with Pokemon like Latias, Alakazam, and Tapu Lele. The former has Defog and Sucker Punch to revenge kill Psychic- and Ghost-types like Blacephalon and Alolan Raichu, while the latter has useful utilities like Knock Off, which removes Heavy-Duty Boots and makes Stealth Rock more effective and Whirlwind to phaze setup sweepers like Jirachi and Spectrier. Amoonguss is the best check to Ground-type Pokemon, notably Mold Breaker Excadrill, which threatens Nidoking and most of its teammates with Earthquake. Amoonguss also helps break Steel teams, as it has Spore to give Nidoking opportunities to come in while also forming a Regenerator core with Toxapex; together, they help Nidoking deal with Ground-, Rock-, and Water-type Pokemon like Excadrill, Rhyperior, Terrakion, and Urshifu-R. Nihilego runs Choice Scarf to revenge kill Pokemon like Dragonite, Landorus-T, and Victini and appreciates Nidoking's ability to threaten Steel-types it cannot properly deal with, like Ferrothorn and Aegislash. It has nice coverage moves like Thunderbolt, Dazzling Gleam, Power Gem, and Grass Knot, which improve quite a few matchups like Flying, Dragon, Fire, and Ground. Gengar is an option over Nihilego and supports Drapion or Skuntank in dealing with Psychic- and Ghost-type Pokemon like Galarian Corsola and Slowbro with Shadow Ball, and it also deals with bulky Pokemon like Toxapex and Aegislash. Galarian Slowking's ability to sponge Psychic-type attacks that KO Nidoking from Pokemon like Alolan Raichu and Latias is appreciated, and it forms a triple Regenerator core with Toxapex and Amoonguss, making Poison teams harder to break.

Clefable.overview: Clefable is a great utility Pokemon, having access to decent bulk paired with Magic Guard as well as a good movepool that provides it with reliable recovery and the ability to set Stealth Rock. Magic Guard is especially useful, as it allows Clefable to serve as a status sponge for the rest of the team against Pokemon such as SubToxic Aegislash and Toxapex. It also means Clefable can come in freely against Spikes when going against types like Grass and Steel. Both these traits are very valuable due to Fairy teams commonly lacking entry hazard removal, making traditional teams susceptible to hazards like the aforementioned Spikes and Toxic Spikes. However, Clefable's bulk is not good enough to prevent it from being blown away by stronger wallbreakers such as Choice Specs Kyurem, Choice Specs Zapdos, and Choice Band Zeraora.
Clefable.comments:
Other Options

Leftovers can be used over Rocky Helmet, but that sacrifices Clefable's ability to threaten Celesteela outside of removing its recovery. Thunder Wave can be used over Knock Off to cripple various Pokemon, namely faster Pokemon and defensive walls such as Tapu Lele and Corviknight. Healing Wish can also be used over Knock Off in order to support an offensive teammate later on in the game. However, Knock Off's utility is generally a lot more valuable. Babiri Berry may be considered to take Scizor's Bullet Punch at +2 and Choice Band Excadrill's Iron Head, retaliating with Flamethrower. However, Babiri Berry's utility is situational, and Scizor's Bullet Punch can be neutralized by its teammate, Tapu Lele.

Checks and Counters

Wallbreakers Wallbreakers such as Choice Band Rillaboom, Choice Specs Zapdos, and Choice Specs Tapu Lele easily beat Clefable due to its middling bulk.

Stallbreakers: Stallbreakers such as Tapu Fini and Tornadus-T can break through Clefable by preventing it from using its utility moves or recovering with Soft-boiled.

Stealth Rock.description:
Clefable is a great Stealth Rock setter due to its good bulk, recovery, and Magic Guard, allowing it to set it on offensive threats like Choice Scarf Landorus-T or passive walls such as Toxapex and Ferrothorn. Moonblast is important for threatening Substitute Kyurem, Dragonite, Galarian Moltres, and Hydreigon in particular, keeping them from using Clefable as setup fodder. Knock Off cancels out passive recovery from various Pokemon like Celesteela, Dragalge, Toxapex, Aegislash, and Tyranitar by removing Leftovers, softening them up for later on in the game, as well as Heavy-Duty Boots users like Mandibuzz and Mantine so that they take damage from Clefable's Stealth Rock. It's also useful for removing Choice items like Excadrill's and Thundurus-T's Choice Scarf, allowing Pokemon like Choice Scarf Tapu Bulu to revenge kill them. Rocky Helmet in conjunction with Soft-Boiled chips down Celesteela, as it is forced to use Heavy Slam on Clefable in order to beat it. 16 Speed EVs let Clefable outspeed neutral-natured Celesteela so that Clefable can wear it down by using Soft-Boiled first and relying on Rocky Helmet recoil.

All offensive Pokemon on Fairy generally appreciate Clefable's ability to serve as a status sponge. Tapu Bulu and Tapu Koko are offensive teammates that Clefable can support by removing items like Thundurus-T's and Landorus-T's Choice Scarf, allowing them to revenge kill them. Stealth Rock is also great in the Electric matchup in particular, as Choice Scarf Tapu Bulu can OHKO Choice Specs Zapdos with Stone Edge after Stealth Rock damage, and it helps Tapu Koko pressure Flying more easily by chipping down faster checks like the aforementioned Choice Scarf users that try to switch in. In return, Tapu Bulu can provide Clefable with passive recovery with Grassy Terrain, and Tapu Koko can threaten Defoggers like Mantine and Corviknight that may try to remove Clefable's Stealth Rock with Thunderbolt, as Clefable usually cannot threaten them itself. Klefki forms a good hazard stacking core with Clefable and can support its subpar bulk with its dual screens. Mimikyu can check Pokemon such as Hatterene, Aegislash, and Thundurus-T that set up on Clefable due to its passiveness with Disguise. Tapu Lele can beat Poison-type Pokemon such as Toxapex and Dragalge for Clefable. Azumarill appreciates Stealth Rock, as it allows it to OHKO Celesteela with more ease after Belly Drum.

Calm Mind (Fairy).description:
Calm Mind Clefable functions as a bulky setup sweeper for Fairy teams due to its good coverage in Flamethrower and Thunderbolt, which lets it deal with Celesteela and Toxapex. Its ability in Magic Guard stops entry hazards and status from wearing it down. Calm Mind, in conjunction with Soft-Boiled, allows Clefable to accrue several boosts against Pokemon that cannot significantly damage it such as Ferrothorn, SubToxic Aegislash, and SubRoost Kyurem. Thunderbolt deals with Water- and Flying-types such as Mantine, Celesteela, and Volcanion, and it also wears down Haze and Roar users such as Toxapex and Heatran. Flamethrower deals with Steel- and Grass-types such as Ferrothorn and Rillaboom. Moonblast can be used to help deal with Dark- and Dragon-types such as Hydreigon and Garchomp, and it also wears down Swampert, which can wall Clefable's coverage moves. Moonblast also allows Clefable to threaten Dragon teams, which do not mind Clefable's coverage moves. Life Orb turns Clefable into a fearsome threat, allowing it to consistently 2HKO Toxapex, Celesteela, and Drapion at +1. Magic Guard also nullifies its recoil. Alternatively, Leftovers makes Clefable harder for types such as Grass, Dark, and Water to handle due to its increased longevity. 16 Speed EVs let Clefable outspeed defensive variants of Celesteela, while the remaining EVs maximize its physical bulk to better deal with threats such as Choice Scarf Excadrill, Rillaboom, and Zeraora.

Klefki's dual screens make it an ideal partner for Clefable, as these allow Clefable to set up more easily, as well as staying in to damage threats such as Choice Band Excadrill and Rillaboom. Klefki also provides a Poison immunity to come in against threats such as Nihilego, debilitates Clefable answers such as Gengar and Mantine with Thunder Wave and Toxic, and sets Spikes to wear down the opposing team. Tapu Bulu and Clefable both wear down their shared checks in Toxapex, Celesteela, and Melmetal. Tapu Bulu also sets Grassy Terrain to improve Clefable's longevity, deals with Swampert, Clear Smog Gastrodon, and Regieleki for it, and pressures Heatran for Clefable not running Thunderbolt. This allows Clefable to sweep Steel teams late-game. Tapu Lele checks Poison-types like Nidoking and Dragalge, allows Clefable to deal with Scizor by setting Psychic Terrain, and deals with Dragon-types such as Hydreigon and Kyurem, especially if Clefable doesn't have Moonblast. Clefable repays this by wearing down Steel-types such as Aegislash and Corviknight, which wall Tapu Lele. Tapu Koko pivots Clefable into passive Pokemon such as Ferrothorn, is a fast teammate that deals with Urshifu-R, Weavile, and Cinderace, and can deal with Water-types such as Mantine, Slowking, and Toxapex for Clefable not running Thunderbolt. Azumarill appreciates its checks in Mantine, Volcanion, and Ferrothorn being worn down, as this allows it to clean types such as Flying, Fire, and Steel late-game. In return, Azumarill deals with Alolan Marowak, Galarian Slowking, and Nidoking, which Clefable struggles against. Alternatively, Calm Mind Tapu Fini forms a special wallbreaking core with Clefable and relieves it from having to use Moonblast, as Tapu Fini deals with Dragon-, Ground-, and Fire-types such as Dragonite, Landorus-T, and Heatran. Mimikyu is a Swords Dance sweeper that deals with Ghost- and Psychic-types such as Spectrier, Gengar, and Hatterene. Alolan Ninetales appreciates Clefable's ability to take out Celesteela and Toxapex, as this allows Alolan Ninetales to clean Flying and Water teams late-game, and can also provide support with Grudge.

Nasty Plot.description:
Fire teams appreciate Ninetales's Drought ability to summon sun, boosting Fire-type moves for the team and weakening opposing Water-type attacks. A coveted move in Nasty Plot lets it shred apart opposing teams and take up the role of a wallbreaker too. Its access to a strong Grass-type move in Solar Beam, which charges in one turn when sun is up, lets it take care of Rock-, Water-, and Ground-types such as Rhyperior, Jellicent, and Gastrodon. With Nasty Plot and Extrasensory, Ninetales is also able to deal with Toxapex, which can otherwise stomach hits from it. Hypnosis is an option over Extrasensory to put to sleep troublesome Pokemon like Tyranitar and Toxapex on a predicted switch-in. Against defensive teams like Poison, Ninetales should focus on setting up with Nasty Plot to break through the opposition, while against offensive teams like hyper offense Ghost, Ninetales should focus on direct attacking due to the lack of a defensive backbone to tank hits. Maximum Special Attack investment lets Ninetales hit as hard as possible, and maximum Speed investment with a Timid nature allows it to outspeed slower Pokemon that could KO Ninetales, such as Indeedee and Obstagoon. Heat Rock maximizes the number of sun turns, increasing the damage of Fire-type moves for Ninetales and its teammates.

All of Ninetales's teammates enjoy its ability to set sun. Charizard appreciates Ninetales's wallbreaking ability that allows it to clean late-game, as well as providing sun to activate Solar Power. In return, Charizard can take care of threats like Dragapult and Tyranitar with Dragon Pulse and Focus Blast, respectively. Choice Band Arcanine forms a good wallbreaking core with Ninetales, weakening each other's checks and counters. Arcanine also appreciates Hypnosis support from Ninetales to further limit its checks like Hippowdon. Cinderace can swap Stealth Rock from its side of the field with Court Change and threaten common hazard setters like Tyranitar with High Jump Kick. Torkoal can provide Ninetales with essential Stealth Rock support to score easier KOs and keep opposing hazards away with Rapid Spin, as they would otherwise undermine Ninetales's potential as a wallbreaker. In addition, Torkoal can set sun against slower weather setters like Pelipper and Hippowdon. Rotom-H can provide Ninetales with Volt Switch and Defog support; additionally, they can run Nasty Plot sets together to overwhelm shared checks.

Ninetales-Alola.comments:
Other Options

Ice

Grudge is an option that lures and depletes the PP of threatening moves, namely Melmetal's Double Iron Bash, but its usefulness is very situational. Hypnosis is a similarly inconsistent option, but it can cripple an opposing wall or sweeper if it hits.

Aurora Veil (Ice).description:
Alolan Ninetales is a crucial Pokemon on Ice thanks to its great typing and utility in Snow Warning and Aurora Veil. Moonblast threatens Fighting-, Dark-, and Dragon-types such as Galarian Zapdos, Crawdaunt, and Kyurem. Freeze-Dry hits Water-types like Swampert and Gastrodon. Encore allows Alolan Ninetales to punish passive walls, setup sweepers, and entry hazard setters like Corviknight, Tapu Fini, and Clefable. Light Clay is preferred to get maximum value from Aurora Veil, but Icy Rock can be run if using Arctozolt. A bulkier spread with maximum HP investment over Special Attack is an option to provide more opportunities to set up Aurora Veil.

All of Alolan Ninetales's teammates appreciate Aurora Veil and it checking dangerous Fighting-types such as Urshifu-R. Kyurem can check Fire-types that wall and scare out Alolan Ninetales like Heatran and Volcanion and threaten them with Earth Power. Dragon Dance Kyurem, in particular, appreciates Alolan Ninetales's Aurora Veil to ease setting up Substitute and Dragon Dance. Piloswine is a more passive Pokemon that can perform a similar role in checking Fire-types such as Volcarona and Heatran with help from Aurora Veil while also being able to set Stealth Rock. Cloyster can get rid of entry hazards for Alolan Ninetales while also chipping Steel-types such as Melmetal with Rocky Helmet and bringing it in safely with Teleport. Galarian Darmanitan and Weavile are offensive wallbreakers that can abuse the special bulky Pokemon that wall Alolan Ninetales, like Slowking and Aegislash. Arctozolt can use Alolan Ninetales's Hail to decimate offensive teams and common checks to Alolan Ninetales like Celesteela and Corviknight. Mamoswine is an option for a more offensive Stealth Rock setter that can help preserve offensive momentum.

Aurora Veil Setter (Fairy).description:
Alolan Ninetales's fast Aurora Veil allows Fairy teams to better take advantage of their setup sweepers. Freeze-Dry nails Water- and Ground-type Pokemon such as Hippowdon, Gastrodon, Seismitoad, and Pelipper, while Moonblast allows Alolan Ninetales to hit Dark-, Dragon-, and Fighting-type such as Sableye, Hydreigon, Kyurem-B, and Kommo-o hard. Encore enables Alolan Ninetales to lock setup sweepers such as Corviknight, Snorlax, and Centiskorch and defensive Pokemon like Toxapex and Hippowdon into inopportune moves. Light Clay and Snow Warning pair with Aurora Veil to maximize its duration and enable setup, enabling teammates such as Mimikyu to more easily take advantage of it. The given EVs and a Timid nature allow Alolan Ninetales to be as strong and fast as possible and take on Pokemon such as Cloyster and Toxapex. Alolan Ninetales should time when its sets Aurora Veil against other teams with access to weather, as it can easily be blocked if hail is overridden.

All of Alolan Ninetales teammates appreciate its ability to set up Aurora Veil, especially the setup sweepers. Calm Mind Hatterene, Swords Dance Mimikyu, Bulk Up Grimmsnarl, and Nasty Plot Togekiss are the team's setup sweepers that can take advantage of Aurora Veil, allowing them to tank hits with more ease and making setting up easier. Hatterene also can bounce back entry hazards for Alolan Ninetales thanks to Magic Bounce, which also allows it to keep up Aurora Veil against Defog users such as Galarian Weezing and Pelipper. Other teammates such as Gardevoir and Primarina appreciate the Aurora Veil, as it allows them to spam their attacks with little drawback. Gardevoir especially helps Alolan Ninetales, as it can take advantage of opposing weather teams thanks to Trace and its Choice Scarf to revenge kill their sweepers with ease, such as Excadrill and Barraskewda. Clefable is another support Pokemon available to Aurora Veil teams, being able to support them with Thunder Wave and Healing Wish or set up Stealth Rock, allowing its teammates to break through the foe's team with more ease. Stealth Rock also allows Alolan Ninetales to at least 2HKO all Pokemon in the Water matchup, such as taking out Toxapex with Freeze-Dry and OHKOing Cloyster with Moonblast. Pokemon such as Grimmsnarl can take on Pokemon that can beat Ninetales such as Jirachi and Gengar with Sucker Punch, and Togekiss can tank attacks from Choice Scarf users that take can OHKO Alolan Ninetales such as Duraludon and paralyze them with Thunder Wave. Lastly, Ribombee's Sticky Web allows Alolan Ninetales to outspeed Choice Scarf users such as Terrakion, Dracovish, and Duraludon.

Focus Sash Trapper.description:
Dugtrio serves as a trapper for Ground-type teams with its excellent ability in Arena Trap. Thanks to it, Dugtrio can pick off weakened foes or eliminate problematic threats such as Dracovish and Weavile without allowing them to counteract. Earthquake is Dugtrio's primary and strongest attack. Stone Edge is mainly used to hit Flying-types such as Gyarados and Charizard. Reversal hits extremely hard when Focus Sash is consumed, allowing Dugtrio to do significant damage to Normal- and Ice-type Pokemon such as Obstagoon and Mamoswine. Sucker Punch allows Dugtrio to hit common Choice Scarf users such as Galarian Darmanitan and Dracovish, and common priority users such as Mamoswine. Screech can be used as an alternative to further complement its physical presence, allowing Dugtrio to trap foes more consistently by reducing their Defense. Focus Sash complements its ability Arena Trap, as it guarantees at least one Pokemon trapped from full HP. Dugtrio should seek trapping opportunities to pick off weakened foes or slower Pokemon that it can reliably beat.

Dugtrio needs to keep its Focus Sash intact in order to trap fast threats such as Weavile effectively, so Excadrill makes an excellent teammate for Dugtrio, as it can use Rapid Spin to remove entry hazards for Dugtrio. It can also handle Fairy-types such as Grimmsnarl and Ribombee that either use Dugtrio as setup fodder or simply easily KO it without fear of Reversal. Hippowdon makes another decent teammate for Dugtrio with its access to Sand Stream and Stealth Rock; the cumulated passive chip damage allows Dugtrio to trap more consistently throughout the match. With its great bulk, Hippowdon can also pivot for Dugtrio after it traps and removes a threat and a revenge killer is sent out by the opponent. Mamoswine is a good offensive teammate with nearly unresisted coverage that allows it to punch many holes in opposing teams; this allows Mamoswine and Dugtrio to complement each other excellently. Dugtrio can trap and eliminate Pokemon that were weakened by Mamoswine, while it also can be used to trap fast Choice Scarf Pokemon such as Dracovish to grant Mamoswine freedom. Seismitoad is a good defensive partner with access to Toxic, which can generate chip damage for Dugtrio for consistent trapping. With its ability in Water Absorb, it can also check Dracovish. Rhyperior makes a good teammate for Dugtrio, as it can handle the Flying-types that Dugtrio cannot trap and struggles against, most notably Corviknight.

Focus Sash.description:
Thanks to its ability Magic Guard combined with its stellar Speed stat and a Focus Sash, Alakazam performs the role of a revenge killer for Psychic-type teams. It also has a high Special Attack stat, which lets it hit hard against Pokemon such as Hydreigon, Tyranitar, and Ferrothorn with its coverage moves. Counter in combination with Focus Sash and Magic Guard helps Alakazam beat threatening physical attackers like Sharpedo, Cinderace, and Excadrill. Expanding Force is its STAB move of choice and is boosted to crazy levels in Psychic Terrain, letting Alakazam OHKO Pokemon like Azumarill after minor chip damage. It can also 2HKO Pokemon like Scizor and Araquanid if they switch in against it. Dazzling Gleam can be used to beat Dark- and Dragon-type Pokemon like Crawdaunt and Hydreigon. Shadow Ball lets Alakazam do good damage to Pokemon weak to it like Aegislash and Alolan Raichu. Focus Blast, on the other hand, lets Alakazam threaten Ferrothorn and Tyranitar, which can stomach its other moves easily. Alakazam should not take any unnecessary damage that may result from directly switching it into opposing Pokemon, as they may leave it unable to retain its Focus Sash. Also, it should be preserved in matchups against Bug- and Dark-type teams where it is needed to take on threats like Scolipede and Sharpedo. Maximum Special Attack investment optimizes Alakazam's overall damage output. Maximum Speed investment with a Timid nature lets it outspeed comparably fast Pokemon such as Cinderace and Salazzle.

Alakazam's teammates appreciate its role as a revenge killer being able to take on problematic Pokemon. Teammates like Choice Specs Indeedee-M and Nasty Plot Mew can wallbreak opposing foes, making Alakazam's job easier as a revenge killer late-game. Indeedee-M is a notable teammate, as it provides it with Ghost-type immunity and Psychic Terrain support, making the team immune to threatening priority moves like Sucker Punch and Shadow Sneak from Pokemon like Bisharp, Aegislash, and Mimikyu, allowing Alakazam to deal with such threats much better. Nasty Plot Mew, meanwhile, can take care of the Steel-type matchup by taking on Pokemon like Corviknight and Ferrothorn that may be an obstacle for Alakazam late-game. Support teammates like Orbeetle and Celebi provide Sticky Web and Stealth Rock support, enabling Alakazam to outspeed faster Pokemon like Choice Scarf Gengar and score easier KO with Expanding Force against Azumarill under Psychic Terrain. Pokemon like Slowbro can spread paralysis and bring Alakazam onto the field safely with Teleport, acting as a defensive pivot for the team. Choice Scarf users like Gardevoir and Jirachi are good teammates, as the former can deal with weather sweepers like Kingdra, Barraskewda, and Excadrill, while the latter does a good job against Fairy- and Ice-type teams, beating Pokemon like Cloyster, which can otherwise beat Alakazam with its multi-hit moves especially after Shell Smash boost. Hatterene and Alakazam form a great core against offensive types like Dark, Dragon, and Electric where Hatterene can break teams with its defensive Calm Mind set, letting Alakazam clean up late-game.

Slowbro.comments:
Other Options

Psychic

Future Sight may be used in the second moveslot, as Teleport allows it to pivot in wallbreakers such as Victini and Latios to pressure switch-ins such as Toxapex, Swampert, and Gastrodon with Future Sight, allowing the wallbreakers to more easily overwhelm the opposing team. Thunder Wave may also be used there to slow down foes, supporting teammates such as Choice Specs Tapu Lele and Choice Band Victini. However, Slowbro then fails to check threatening setup sweepers without one of the listed options. Flamethrower allows Slowbro to punish Grass-types such as Ferrothorn that directly switch into it, as well as dealing decent damage to Bisharp and Weavile. However, Flamethrower is unable to OHKO Bisharp and Weavile, which can be an issue for Psychic teams.

Defensive Pivot (Psychic).description:
Slowbro is an excellent defensive pivot for Psychic teams, as it is able to take on threats such as Urshifu-R, Excadrill, and Mamoswine. Scald dissuades physical attackers such as Excadrill and Scizor from staying in and setting up on Slowbro due to the threat of burn. Foul Play should be paired with Kasib Berry, as it lets Slowbro survive a hit from and remove threats such as Dragon Dance Dragapult, Choice Scarf Blacephalon, and Swords Dance Aegislash. Foul Play also punishes setup sweepers such as Dragonite and Garchomp. Body Press + Colbur Berry allows Slowbro to check Swords Dance Bisharp and Weavile, and it also has the added benefit of punishing Substitute users such as Hydreigon and Kyurem, which otherwise take advantage of it. Ice Beam is another option, as it heavily damages threatening setup sweepers such as Landorus-T, Garchomp, and Dragonite. Teleport safely switches in a teammate that can take advantage of the foe. Heavy-Duty Boots protects Slowbro from entry hazards, allowing it to sponge hits more easily. Alternatively, Rocky Helmet punishes physical attackers such as Landorus-T, Galarian Zapdos, and Urshifu-R that tend to pivot out of it with U-turn. 0 Speed IVs allow it to underspeed opposing Teleport users, letting its teammates come in after the foe has already used Teleport.

Galarian Slowking is an excellent teammate for Slowbro, as they form a strong defensive Regenerator core, with the former taking on special attackers such as Tapu Koko, Aegislash, and Kingdra, while the latter easily switches into physical attackers. Psychic teams also appreciate Slowbro taking on physical threats and bringing in wallbreakers such as Latios, Victini, and Tapu Lele safely. Victini deals with Grass-types like Rillaboom and Ferrothorn, loves Slowbro taking on Landorus-T and Excadrill, and appreciates being pivoted into Steel- and Flying-types such as Ferrothorn and Celesteela. Tapu Lele deals with Dark-types such as non-Choice Scarf Weavile and Bisharp, which is especially helpful if Slowbro isn't holding a Colbur Berry, and also deals with Dragon-types like Hydreigon and non-Choice Scarf and Dragapult. It also appreciates pivoting support. Jirachi and Bronzong can take on other special attackers such as Tapu Lele and Hatterene, and they also set Stealth Rock, which synergizes with Slowbro's ability to force switches. If Slowbro isn't running Heavy-Duty Boots, it has a tendency to get overwhelmed by entry hazards, so entry hazard control teammates like Latias and Hatterene are greatly appreciated.

Shell Smash Sweeper (Ice).description:
With a sky-high Defense stat, Cloyster is able to function as a Shell Smash sweeper on Ice teams. Icicle Spear can threaten Pokemon such as Mandibuzz, Togekiss, and Dragapult on Dark, Flying, and Dragon teams. Utilizing Rock Blast, Cloyster is able to sweep Fire teams fairly easily, providing Ice teams with a win condition versus them. It is also able to sweep opposing Ice teams, thus aiding in the mirror matchups. Liquidation prevents Cloyster from being walled by Steel-types such as Bisharp, Bronzong, and Aegislash, as well as aiding in sweeping Rock teams. Skill Link allows both Icicle Spear and Rock Blast to always hit five times for maximum damage output. Focus Sash allows Cloyster to set up with Shell Smash guaranteed and is crucial against special attackers such as Indeedee and Gardevoir in order to set up in a pinch. Maximum Attack and Speed investment alongside a Jolly nature allow Cloyster to be as strong and as fast as possible, as at +2 only base 110 Speed Choice Scarf Pokemon or higher can revenge kill it, of which only Dragapult is particularly viable.

Cloyster is used as a late-game sweeper when all its checks and counters are either eliminated or have been worn down, and it is best to set up in front of a physical attacker or when Aurora Veil is up. It can also be used to set up early to break holes for its teammates. Wallbreakers such as Weavile and Galarian Darmanitan are amazing teammates for Cloyster, as they are able to punch holes through teams, allowing Cloyster to sweep more easily. Galarian Darmanitan can notably wear down Steel teams easily to the point of where Cloyster can sweep. Choice Scarf Weavile is able to check Choice Scarf Jirachi, which is a huge threat to Ice teams. Alolan Ninetales is a fantastic partner for Cloyster, as it is able to use Aurora Veil to allow it to set up more easily, as well as threatening Toxapex, which Cloyster struggles to break, with Freeze-Dry; in addition, it can threaten Swift Swim Water teams with Snow Warning. Mamoswine, Piloswine, and Froslass provide entry hazard support with Stealth Rock and Spikes to wear down foes, allowing Cloyster to sweep more easily. In addition, Froslass has access to Taunt to deny entry hazards from the opposing team, making sure that Cloyster's Focus Sash is intact. Galarian Mr. Mime and Avalugg are good teammates that provide Rapid Spin support to ensure that Cloyster's Focus Sash remains intact. In particular, Galarian Mr. Mime fits better on the offensive teams that leverage Cloyster thanks to its high Speed and can also cripple Pokemon with Trick, potentially giving Cloyster a free setup opportunity.

Shell Smash Sweeper (Water).description:
Cloyster performs the role of a threatening Shell Smash sweeper and late-game cleaner for Water teams. It helps Water teams to greatly improve matchups against types such as Dragon, Flying, and Grass. Cloyster has average offensive stats, but its ability Skill Link combined with moves like Icicle Spear and Rock Blast give it high Base Power moves to use with Shell Smash and allow it to pose a threat to unprepared teams. Rock Blast allows it to beat Ice- and Bug-type Pokemon such as Lapras and Vikavolt, and priority Ice Shard helps Cloyster to revenge kill faster Choice Scarf users like Noivern and beat opposing priority users like Dragapult and Whimsicott after Shell Smash. Maximum Attack investment optimizes Cloyster's damage output maximum Speed with a Jolly nature makes it as fast as possible, allowing it to outspeed most Pokemon at +2 with the exception of foes like Choice Scarf Gengar. Its huge Defense stat and Focus Sash ensure that it can set up at least one Shell Smash during the battle.

Hard-hitting Pokemon such as Barraskewda and Crawdaunt appreciate Cloyster taking care of Dragon-and Grass-type teams, and in return, both of them can weaken shared checks like Ferrothorn for Cloyster. Cloyster's weakness to Electric-type moves can be mitigated by using teammates like Seismitoad, which not only can provide Cloyster with essential Stealth Rock support but also help Cloyster beat Pokemon such as Aegislash and Toxapex with STAB Earth Power. Toxapex provides Cloyster with a defensive pivot and a Grass neutrality, can put walls on timer with Toxic or spread burns with Scald, and can absorb Toxic Spikes to help Cloyster retain its Focus Sash.

Gengar.comments:
Other Options

Ghost

Gengar can run Energy Ball to heavily damage Ground-types such as Gastrodon and Hippowdon, or Thunderbolt to damage Flying- and Water-types such as Toxapex and Corviknight, but Focus Blast and Dazzling Gleam are preferred; these cover Ghost's natural weakness to Dark, hitting super effectively against targets like Tyranitar and Hydreigon. Will-O-Wisp + Hex can be used alongside Black Sludge or Life Orb to let Gengar lure in physical attackers; however, this set faces competition from Spectrier. Trick is another option to debilitate specially defensive walls like Blissey and Mantine that come in on Gengar, but the reduced coverage from running it is significant.

Revenge Killer (Ghost).description:
Gengar is a powerful revenge killer on Ghost teams due to its high Special Attack and potent movepool. Sludge Bomb picks off weakened Fairy- and Grass-types such as Choice Scarf Tapu Lele and Zarude. Focus Blast takes down Steel- and Dark-types, such as Ferrothorn, Heatran, and Tyranitar. Dazzling Gleam is also a more accurate way to nail Dark-types, and it hits certain ones like Hydreigon and Galarian Moltres better. A Choice Scarf allows it to outspeed threats such as Choice Scarf Zarude, Choice Scarf Hydreigon, and Dragon Dance Tyranitar, making it one of the best revenge killers for Ghost-type teams.

Gengar has a unique role in absorbing Toxic Spikes, as Ghost teams don't have reliable entry hazard removal to prevent teammates like Galarian Corsola and Mimikyu from being worn down. Galarian Corsola takes on and burns physical attackers such as Excadrill and Zeraora, and it softens up the opposing team for Gengar by setting Stealth Rock. Bulky foes such as Toxapex and Gastrodon can be pressured by Calm Mind Spectrier, which can also spread burns with Will-O-Wisp, wearing down special walls like Drapion and Celesteela. Swords Dance Aegislash deals with Hatterene and Clefable, and it appreciates Gengar removing fast threats such as Zarude and Hydreigon for it. Mimikyu can beat Sucker Punch users like Bisharp and removes Dark-types such as Galarian Moltres, which pose a threat to Gengar and its teammates. Setting Spikes, Froslass helps wear down Pokemon like Toxapex and Heatran to allow Gengar to sweep late-game. Dragapult can handle troublesome Dragon-types like Kyurem and Garchomp, as well as pressuring Volcarona, which can use Gengar as setup fodder.

Choice Specs (Ghost).description:
Choice Specs Gengar is a potent pick as a wallbreaker on Ghost teams thanks to its high Special Attack and Speed stat along with excellent coverage options and a good typing. Sludge Wave threatens Grass- and Fairy-types such as Rillaboom, Togekiss, Primarina, and Clefable. It also massively damages any unresisted foe such as Hydreigon or Indeedee, both of which can otherwise take or ignore Shadow Ball. Focus Blast provides very important coverage against Tyranitar, Diggersby, and Incineroar. Thunderbolt pressures Water-types such as Keldeo and Toxapex, as well as Flying-types such as Corviknight, Mandibuzz, and Mantine. Trick can cripple bulky walls such as Chansey, which is otherwise hard to wear down. Gengar's Special Attack and Speed EVs alongside a Timid nature and Choice Specs allow it to hit as hard and be as fast as possible. It's also very frail, so it should be brought in against resisted attacks or predicted switches.

Dragapult serves as an efficient late-game cleaner with Dragon Dance, being able to clean teams easily and outspeed almost the entire metagame after a boost. Choice Scarf Dragapult can also be used to revenge kill fast threats such as Zeraora, Sand Rush Excadrill, and Swift Swim Kingdra. Mimikyu is a great late-game cleaner, as its ability Disguise allows it to blanket check many Pokemon and pick off weakened foes in tandem with Swords Dance and Shadow Sneak. Its unique Ghost / Fairy typing also helps it play a crucial role in revenge killing Dark-types for the team. Galarian Corsola provides a defensive backbone for the team thanks to its good bulk, which allows it to annoy physical attackers with the combination of Will-O-Wisp and Strength Sap. In addition, its access to Stealth Rock makes Gengar a more consistent wallbreaker. Aegislash is incredibly versatile, as it can be a specially defensive wall with SubToxic, wearing down special attackers such as Jirachi and Celebi, or a Swords Dance wallbreaker. Additionally, it can check other Fairy-types that Choice Specs Gengar has trouble revenge killing, such as Choice Scarf Gardevoir. Jellicent provides a useful Water immunity for Ghost teams, keeping Dracovish, Keldeo, and Barraskewda in check. Alolan Marowak and SubCM Chandelure are powerful wallbreakers that easily handle Ice, Grass, and Steel teams. Alolan Marowak provides a useful Electric immunity for Ghost teams thanks to its ability Lightning Rod. Chandelure can also punish Sucker Punch users such as Bisharp and Skuntank, which are huge threats to Ghost teams. Froslass acts as a fast Spikes setter on hyper offensive teams that can prevent entry hazards from the opposing team thanks to Taunt.

Choice Scarf (Poison).description:
Gengar has great Speed and Special Attack, which allows it to function as a potent revenge killer that can also sweep a weakened team late-game. Its STAB Shadow Ball allows it to beat Ghost-type teams. Gengar has great coverage in the form of Focus Blast to hit Pokemon that resist its STAB like Tyranitar, and Dazzling Gleam for Dragon-types like Kommo-o and Hydreigon that tend to be difficult for Poison-types to take down.

Gengar is a frail Pokemon, so Toxapex is an incredible teammate, as it absorbs hits for it. It is particularly useful against threats with priority like Mimikyu and Bisharp. Drapion is able to switch into the super effective Psychic-, Dark-, and Ghost-type attacks that are used against Gengar. Roserade helps it handle Ground-type Pokemon while also setting Spikes, which makes Gengar's late-game cleaning easier. Toxtricity can bring Gengar in with Volt Switch and beat Pokemon like Corviknight and Toxapex that would otherwise come in and wall Gengar. Toxicroak breaks the special walls, like Snorlax, that would otherwise hinder Gengar's sweep. Galarian Weezing provides a Ground immunity and can remove entry hazards with Defog, allowing Gengar to come in more freely during the game. Moreover, it serves as another Dark-resistant teammate to support Gengar. Vileplume helps Gengar by checking Excadrill, which greatly threatens Poison-type teams. Salazzle also aids Gengar by threatening Steel-type teams and withering down other types with a Substitute + Toxic set.

Weezing-Galar.overview:
Fairy

Galarian Weezing's strong defensive typing, solid natural bulk, and ability Neutralizing Gas make it a solid pick on Fairy teams. Neutralizing Gas allows Galarian Weezing to weaken threats such as Azumarill and Scizor and take them on with Will-O-Wisp, set Toxic Spikes against Magic Bounce users, and stop weather setters such as Hippowdon from setting weather. Its low HP stat makes Pain Split a form of semi-reliable recovery. Its part-Poison typing provides a neutrality to Poison-type attacks, allowing it to switch into attacks such as Drapion's Poison Jab and excel in the Fairy matchup. Nonetheless, its special bulk is not great, allowing many special attackers to take advantage of it such as Spectrier, Kyurem, and Volcarona. Additionally, its low Speed means that many Taunt users such as Tornadus-T, Cobalion, Corviknight, and Mew outspeed it and prevent it from using its utility moves, nearly shutting it down.
Weezing-Galar.comments:
Other Options

Fairy

Defog can be used in order to clear entry hazards, which Fairy teams tend to be weak to; however, then Galarian Weezing has to give up Pain Split, reducing its longevity.

Checks and Counters

Fairy

Super Effective Attacks: Strong super effective attacks such as Latios's Psychic, Nidoking's Earth Power, and Magnezone's Flash Cannon can easily OHKO Galarian Weezing.

Stallbreakers: Taunt and Choice item + Trick users can quickly shut down Galarian Weezing.

Special Wallbreakers: Special wallbreakers such as Tapu Koko, Kyurem, and Spectrier can easily break past Galarian Weezing with their neutral STAB attacks due to its poor Special Defense.

Physically Defensive (Fairy).description:
Galarian Weezing has found its place on Fairy teams as a physically defensive pivot that sets Toxic Spikes for the team and absorbs them while being able to neutralize physical attackers such as Diggersby and Azumarill with Will-O-Wisp. Neutralizing Gas allows it to hinder Pokemon that rely on their abilities to function well, nullifying Crawdaunt's Adaptability, Jirachi's Serene Grace to reduce its flinch chance, and even Hatterene's Magic Bounce to set up Toxic Spikes. Additionally, its ability nullifies Levitate, making Pokemon such as Rotom-W and Hydreigon vulnerable to its Toxic Spikes. Finally, Neutralizing Gas also allows Galarian Weezing to prevent Regenerator users such as Amoonguss and Toxapex from healing by switching out, allowing Fairy teams to make significant progress against Poison teams. Sludge Bomb allows it to target Pokemon such as Azumarill as well as poison walls such as Mantine and Mandibuzz. Will-O-Wisp cripples physical attackers such as Diggersby and Zeraora. Toxic Spikes cripples foes such as Dragapult and Urshifu-R, allowing its teammates like Azumarill, Mimikyu, and Togekiss to sweep easily. Pain Split allows Galarian Weezing to regain health throughout the match and wear down the foe. Black Sludge is especially useful due to Pain Split not always being reliable. Maximum HP and Defense EVs alongside a Bold nature make Galarian Weezing as physically bulky as possible, allowing it to take on Pokemon such as Zeraora and Diggersby.

All of Galarian Weezing's offensive teammates appreciate its ability to set up Toxic Spikes, which allows them to break through Pokemon such as Swampert and Porygon2. Galarian Weezing can also help teammates set up more easily by crippling physical attackers with Will-O-Wisp. Its secondary Poison typing also allows it to absorb Toxic Spikes for its teammates. Tapu Lele can take on Poison-type Pokemon such as Toxapex and Amoonguss with Psychic for Galarian Weezing. Additionally, it can threaten a majority of Defog users with Thunderbolt and Moonblast, like Mantine and Mandibuzz. Tapu Bulu can take on and pressure Ground- and Water-type Pokemon like Garchomp, Swampert, and Urshifu-R. Tapu Koko can deal with Flying-type Pokemon such as Celesteela. Additionally, Tapu Koko can provide Taunt utility to prevent Defog users such as Zapdos from removing Galarian Weezing's Toxic Spikes. Mimikyu can take on Psychic-type Pokemon that threaten Galarian Weezing like Tapu Lele and Alakazam with its Ghost-type STAB moves. Azumarill sets up with Belly Drum to break past bulky Pokemon such as Ferrothorn, Toxapex, and Chansey. Azumarill can also threaten Ground-type Pokemon such as Excadrill for Galarian Weezing. Choice Scarf Alolan Ninetales can take on Ground- and Flying-type Pokemon such as Landorus-T with Blizzard. Klefki can form a hazard-stacking core with Galarian Weezing by setting Spikes and can set dual screens to allow Galarian Weezing to tank attacks more easily.

Physically Defensive (Poison).description:
Galarian Weezing plays an important role on Poison teams because of its access to Defog along with its good ability and typing. Having a Defog user is especially important for Poison as a balance type because it prevents teams from being overwhelmed by Spikes. Galarian Weezing also helps against opposing Terrain, allowing teammates like Skuntank to use priority without Psychic Terrain and helping other revenge killers like Choice Scarf Gengar and Choice Scarf Drapion to beat Alolan Raichu by overriding its Electric Terrain. Seeing as Poison teams are typically weak to Ground-type Pokemon such as Sand Rush Excadrill, Choice Band Mamoswine, and Diggersby, Levitate is extremely crucial. Furthermore, Galarian Weezing's Fairy typing allows it to switch into Dark- and Dragon-type attacks from Pokemon such as Hydreigon and Dragapult and beat them in return with Strange Steam. Will-O-Wisp cripples physical attackers such as Mimikyu and Tyranitar. A physically defensive spread is used to more easily check massive threats in Dragon Dance Dragapult and Swords Dance Garchomp. Clear Smog or Flamethrower can be used over Defog if the team has Skuntank to fill the Defog role. The former prevents setup sweepers from setting up on Galarian Weezing for free, and the latter hits Steel-type Pokemon such as Ferrothorn for super effective damage. Seeing as it relies on Pain Split for recovery, Galarian Weezing should be carefully preserved throughout a match in order to switch into Ground-type attacks as well as Defog away hazards. This means it should avoid switching into strong attacks such as Pelipper's Hurricane and Heliolisk's Thunderbolt.

The entire Poison team appreciates Galarian Weezing's Ground immunity. Salazzle is one of the best partners for Galarian Weezing, as it can beat Steel-types such as Ferrothorn, Bisharp, and Corviknight. Toxapex, Vileplume, and Drapion form a good defensive core with Galarian Weezing. Toxapex can switch into a myriad of attacks such as Bisharp's Iron Head and Aegislash's Flash Cannon, as well as neuter setup sweepers with Haze and scout Choice-locked Pokemon such as Mamoswine and Galarian Darmanitan. Vileplume can switch into Mold Breaker Excadrill's Earthquake and remove pressure by checking Ground-type Pokemon with its defensive typing, Giga Drain, and Strength Sap. Skuntank provides a crucial Psychic immunity, meaning it can switch into and pick off Pokemon such as Gardevoir, Alolan Raichu, and Indeedee with Sucker Punch. Skuntank can also run Defog, freeing up Galarian Weezing to run Clear Smog or Flamethrower. Other offensive Pokemon such as Toxitricity and Gengar are able to beat faster threats such as Pelipper, Corviknight, and Obstagoon that Galarian Weezing struggles against.

Eviolite Wall.description:
Chansey is a defensive staple on Normal-type teams thanks to its massive HP and Special Defense stats along with Eviolite and its various amounts of utility. One of these forms of utility is its access to Stealth Rock, which can allow it to assist its teammates by chipping down opposing threats, making it easier to revenge kill them. Seismic Toss allows Chansey to not be completely passive, which lets it wear down opposing special attackers very quickly and break most Substitutes. These two moves paired with the amazing recovery of Soft-Boiled allow Chansey to wear down types that rely on their special attackers, namely Electric, Poison, and Psychic. Teleport can be used on its last slot to help Chansey act as a great pivot and get its offensive teammates in safely, or it can use Toxic to put opposing offensive Pokemon on a timer and make it harder for your opponent to keep them in. Its ability in Natural Cure also allows it to absorb status ailments for its offensive teammates and works well with Teleport when scouting for status moves. Chansey invests its EVs in bulk and Defense so that it can take physical hits better, especially from weaker revenge killers like Choice Scarf Excadrill.

Every other Pokemon on Normal appreciates Chansey's ability to wall special attackers like Hydreigon, Indeedee-M, and Hatterene. Offensive Pokemon like Indeedee-M, Diggersby, Bewear, Obstagoon, and Heliolisk especially appreciate its Teleport support, as they can immediately threaten the opposing team with their dangerous power once switched in. Indeedee-M can force out dangerous Fighting-types like Conkeldurr and Keldeo with a Choice Scarf while also breaking down opposing walls like Toxapex and Amoonguss thanks to Expanding Force's power. Diggersby, Obstagoon, and Bewear coming in for free can also be a huge boon against opposing bulky teams, as they give most defensive cores in the game a very hard time. Heliolisk also appreciates Teleport pivoting greatly, as it can threaten to KO Keldeo, which is a massive threat to Chansey thanks to its Secret Sword and also has a great matchup against opposing Water-type teams. Outside of Teleport, Porygon2 is Chansey's preferred partner thanks to its ability to wear down physical attackers and complete the Eviolite defensive core. This physical wall appreciates Chansey's ability to wear down special attackers that threaten Porygon2, and in return it walls the physical attackers like Mimikyu that threaten Chansey. Ditto is also a great Pokemon on Normal that can beat out certain setup sweepers or wallbreakers that try to take advantage of Chansey's passive nature, such as Dragon Dance Tyranitar and Shell Smash Cloyster.

Dragon Dance Sweeper (Flying).description:
Thanks to its Water typing and the combination of Power Whip and Earthquake, Gyarados sets itself apart from other Flying-types as the best option to tackle Fire and Water teams. After a Dragon Dance, Gyarados OHKOes almost every Water-type with Power Whip and can beat Toxapex one-on-one. Because Water teams are typically good at setting Stealth Rock against Flying, it is important to give Gyarados Heavy-Duty Boots in order to make sure it is as healthy as possible when attempting to sweep. While often used to handle Water, Gyarados is effective in other matchups too; for example, Ground teams have no defensive answer to the perfect Water + Grass coverage that Gyarados uses. While Gyarados is very powerful against Fire teams, keep in mind that sun halves Waterfall's damage output, it will find much more success if Torkoal is either removed or weakened before attempting to sweep. Intimidate is preferred in order to give Gyarados more opportunities to set up, as the matchups it is most effective in only require a single Attack boost, but Moxie is another option to make sweeping slightly easier if Gyarados can find a KO.

Gyarados is fairly self-sufficient in its particular matchups and doesn't rely on its teammates for too much. However, Xatu's dual screens make it much easier to set up. Gyarados fits best on teams that use one or two Pokemon to cover each matchup, so Pokemon like Corviknight that are extremely effective against types, such as Steel, that it struggles with are especially useful. While Gyarados does not require Defog support, Mandibuzz can still act as a support Pokemon with its slow U-turn to bring it in safely on setup fodder. Because Gyarados is almost entirely walled by Grass-types, it is essential to have a very solid answer that can counter them, such as Charizard or Togekiss.

Dragon Dance (Water).description:
Dragon Dance in conjunction with Moxie makes Gyarados a powerful setup sweeper. As for coverage, it can run Power Whip to hit Water-types like Gastrodon, Seismitoad, and Rotom-W more reliably. Earthquake can also be used to hit Pokemon like Duraludon and Dracozolt that resist its STAB moves or safely take out a Haze user like Toxapex. Heavy-Duty Boots prevents Gyarados from being hindered from Stealth Rock, as Water-type teams do not run entry hazard removal.

Gyarados is unable to set up against Pokemon with Electric- or Rock-type coverage, which makes Seismitoad an excellent partner. In exchange, Gyarados is able to remove its Grass-type threats. It also has excellent synergy with Swift Swim Pokemon like Barraskewda and Drednaw, as they can break down the opposing Pokemon for the other to clean up late-game. The two also have the advantage of eliminating Ice-types with Freeze-Dry, which otherwise prevent Gyarados from setting up, like Lapras. Toxapex is a great partner, as it can take hits for Gyarados and cripple the foe with status such as burn or poison. Burning a physical attacker gives Gyarados more opportunities to set up with Dragon Dance.

Ditto.comments:
Other Options

Normal

Ditto has no other viable options.

Revenge Killer.description:
Ditto has an important role on Normal teams thanks to its ability to revenge kill boosted threats. Choice Scarf allows Ditto to outspeed almost any Pokemon it copies, with the exception of other Choice Scarf users. Ditto also acts as a setup deterrent, as sweepers such as Galarian Moltres, Excadrill, and Belly Drum Azumarill cannot set up without risking a countersweep. The EV spread provided maximizes Ditto's HP and allows Ditto to use Struggle four times before fainting. 252 Defensive EVs minimize damage from an opposing Ditto's Struggle. 0 Speed ensures Ditto's Imposter ability activates last against other Ditto to win the resulting PP stall.

Ditto appreciates the presence of pivots like Heliolisk, Braviary, Porygon2, and Chansey that provide Ditto opportunities to switch in safely. Ditto struggles against bulkier foes, so eliminating them quickly is the best route to success. Snorlax assists with this task handily, as it can switch into bulkier foes like Toxapex and Slowbro easily for Ditto. In return, Ditto revenge kills setup sweepers such as Bisharp that force Snorlax out. Ditto also appreciates Obstagoon's wallbreaking capabilities, which can allow Ditto to sweep late-game. Diggersby and Indeedee are also good teammates for Ditto thanks to their ability to defeat more passive Pokemon such as Galarian Weezing. Indeedee, in particular, is a treasured teammate, as its Psychic Terrain prevents foes like Bisharp and Mimikyu from revenge killing Ditto with priority moves like Sucker Punch and Shadow Sneak.

Curse Sweeper (Normal).description:
Snorlax finds a strong niche on Normal-teams as a bulky setup sweeper using Curse that can threaten types like Ice, Electric, Psychic, and Ghost after accumulating multiple boosts and serve as a strong late-game wincon. Snorlax's high Special bulk gives it setup opportunities against many common special attackers such as Dragapult and Gardevoir, and Curse's Defense boost makes it difficult to break past for many teams. Thick Fat makes Snorlax a valuable asset for Normal teams, allowing it to check Fire- and Ice-types such as Chandelure and Galarian Darmanitan, which Normal teams otherwise struggle to switch into. Rest in conjunction with Sleep Talk allow Snorlax to keep itself healthy throughout the match and heal itself of crippling status such as burn and Toxic without being entirely passive. However, Snorlax is susceptible to getting shut down by common Taunt users like Sableye, Mew, and Corviknight, as well as by Haze and Whirlwind users such as Toxapex and Hippowdon. Darkest Lariat is Snorlax's attack of choice, as it ignores opposing stat boosts from Pokemon such as Reuniclus and has no Pokemon that are completely immune to it. However, Snorlax's reliance on Curse and Darkest Lariat to pose an offensive threat means exceptionally powerful attackers that resist Dark such as Nasty Plot Hydriegon, Crawdaunt, and most Fighting-types can break through it with relatively few issues. Snorlax's HP and Defense EVs allow it to always avoid being 2HKOed by Choice Scarf Galarian Darmanitan's Earthquake after Stealth Rock damage. Snorlax should utilize its special bulk and Rest to switch into powerful special attackers such as Hatterene and Alolan Raichu and common status users such as Salazzle and Gastrodon.

Obstagoon serves as a great offensive partner for Snorlax, as it can switch into common Taunt users such as Mew and Sableye without fear of Will-O-Wisp and break past them, allowing Snorlax to sweep Psychic- and Ghost-type teams more easily. Ditto is a good Choice Scarf user that can dissuade opponents from using Snorlax as setup fodder thanks to Imposter allowing it to threaten to countersweep. Indeedee-M is a powerful special attacker that can pressure Fighting-types like Conkeldurr and Kommo-o as well as break past physically defensive walls such as Toxapex and Galarian Weezing using its powerful Psychic Terrain-boosted attacks. Diggersby acts as a powerful wallbreaker that can utilize its good coverage options to break past Pokemon such as Ferrothorn and Corviknight, which can use Snorlax as setup fodder, as well as set Spikes to wear down teams for Snorlax to sweep more easily. Choice Scarf Braviary provides a Ground immunity to help check Pokemon such as Obstagoon and Keldeo and can Defog away entry hazards that can wear down Snorlax over the course of a match. Heliolisk acts as a check to Corviknight, as well as an offensive check to Water- and Flying-types, helping Snorlax deal with Pokemon such as Keldeo, Togekiss, and Toxapex more easily. Bewear acts as a check to physically offensive Dark-types such as Tyranitar, Bisharp, and Crawdaunt that can easily beat Snorlax while appreciating Snorlax's ability to switch into Fire-types such as Rotom-H and Chandelure thanks to Thick Fat.

Zapdos.overview:
Electric

Zapdos is an incredible special wallbreaker for Electric teams mainly due to Hurricane and a great Speed tier. Choice Specs Hurricane hardly has any reliable switch-ins in the metagame when paired with Volt Switch and Heat Wave, OHKOing Hydreigon and 2HKOing other Pokemon like Toxapex and Excadrill. Many types such as Ground, Dragon, and Water cannot switch into Hurricane. Hurricane is also useful for taking out Grass-type Pokemon such as Amoonguss, Celebi, and Rillaboom, which Electric teams typically struggle with. Zapdos's Speed tier is important, as it allows Zapdos to outspeed common slower offensive threats such as Hydreigon, Tapu Lele, and Kyurem and threaten the rest of the team. However, Hurricane can be unreliable due to its shaky accuracy. This, combined with Zapdos's overreliance on the move and weakness to Stealth Rock, makes it a rather inconsistent wallbreaker. Choice Specs Zapdos also forces Rotom-W to drop Pain Split and serve as the Defogger or the team.
Zapdos.comments:
Other Options

Electric

A Defog set can be used on Zapdos with Heavy-Duty Boots, though this gives up Zapdos's amazing wallbreaking capabilities with Choice Specs. Roost can be used over Thunderbolt in case Zapdos gets its item removed through Knock Off.

Checks and Counters

Electric

Special Walls: Pokemon such as Cradily under Grassy Terrain, Galarian Slowking, Blissey, and Heatran can take any of Zapdos's attacks and beat it.

Residual Damage: Stealth Rock limits the amount of times Zapdos can switch in and leaves it more vulnerable to getting revenge killed by Pokemon such as Choice Scarf Tapu Lele. Toxic poison hurts Zapdos's longevity as well and hinders its ability to break against types like Steel, Water, and Flying.
