Revenge Killers: Faster Pokemon such as Choice Scarf Dracovish, Tapu Koko, and Weavile outspeed and beat Zapdos. Priority users such as Bisharp and Mamoswine can also pick it off if it is chipped.

Knock Off and Trick Users: Knock Off users such as Drapion, Mew, and Clefable limit Zapdos's wallbreaking potential by removing its Choice Specs. Trick users such as Tapu Fini and Jirachi hinder Zapdos in a similar fashion.

Choice Specs (Electric).description:
Hurricane is the most important move on this set and allows Zapdos to beat a majority of the metagame. Certain Pokemon such as Nidoking, Choice Band Dracovish, and Mamoswine are OHKOed, while bulkier Pokemon and Flying-resistant foes such as Toxapex, Swampert, and Excadrill risk being 2HKOed. Volt Switch is used to grab momentum, mainly against types that don't commonly carry an Electric immunity such as Psychic, Fairy, Ghost, and Dark. Heat Wave hits Steel-type Pokemon such as Ferrothorn, Excadrill, and Aegislash, and along with Volt Switch, makes Zapdos able to break through Steel teams. Thunderbolt deals consistent damage against Pokemon like Galarian Corsola and Calm Mind Tapu Fini. Static can punish contact moves such as Excadrill's Rapid Spin and Landorus-T's U-turn.

Rotom-W provides entry hazard removal and removes Stealth Rock, which otherwise limits the amount of times Zapdos can switch in. It can also utilize its defensive typing to check Pokemon such as Barraskewda under rain and Heatran for Zapdos. In return, Rotom-W appreciates Zapdos's ability to take out Grass-type Pokemon such as Tapu Bulu and Rillaboom with Hurricane. Magnezone's ability to trap Excadrill is amazing for Zapdos, as it can spam Volt Switch and beat Steel teams with it removed. Magnezone's defensive typing is also notable to take on Ice- and Rock-type attacks from the likes of Weavile and Tyranitar as well as Dragon Dance Dragapult. Alolan Raichu's Knock Off removes Galarian Slowking's Assault Vest in the matchup against Poison teams, allowing Zapdos to 2HKO the entire team with Hurricane. Zeraora is a physical wallbreaker that beats Pokemon such as Galarian Slowking, Tyranitar, and Blissey for Zapdos; in return, Zapdos deals with physical walls like Amoonguss and Hippowdon for Zeraora. Tapu Koko forms a good wallbreaking core with Zapdos that is very good against types like Ground, Water, and Dragon.

Zapdos-Galar.overview:
Flying

Galarian Zapdos stands out as a good wallbreaker for Flying teams thanks to its good Attack stat, excellent coverage, and part-Fighting typing, which allows it to help against matchups such as Dark, Steel, and Normal. Close Combat, Brave Bird, and Blaze Kick or Stomping Tantrum hit almost the entire metagame for neutral damage, and it is able to pivot against checks like Slowbro, Hippowdon, and Zapdos with U-turn. Defiant is useful to pressure Defoggers such as Mandibuzz, Galarian Weezing, and Corviknight, preventing them from removing entry hazards off the field. It also takes advantage of Intimidate from Landorus-T, becoming almost unwallable after an Attack boost. However, Galarian Zapdos is outsped and revenge killed by many threats such as Weavile, Blacephalon, Choice Scarf Tapu Lele, and Spectrier due to its only average Speed stat. While Galarian Zapdos is good at wallbreaking, it can easily be worn down in a match through Brave Bird recoil and Stealth Rock damage. Each of its moves can be easy to switch into, meaning that Steel-type core of Aegislash + Heatran + Celesteela can deal with it if they predict correctly. Lastly, using Galarian Zapdos comes at the cost of not being able to run Zapdos.

Fighting

Galarian Zapdos's high Attack stat combined with its excellent STAB combination and a great ability in Defiant allows it to act as a fearsome wallbreaker on Fighting-type teams. Its typing allows it to help in the Bug-, Fighting-, and Grass-type matchups, notably checking Pokemon such as Buzzwole and Rillaboom. Its STAB combination allows to hit a large portion of the metagame for neutral or super effective damage, while U-turn pivots out of tough matchups and maintains momentum. However, its reliance on Brave Bird to beat troublesome Pokemon such as Toxapex and Galarian Weezing wears it down quickly, thus affecting its wallbreaking potential. Despite its fine Speed tier allowing it to outspeed Pokemon like Mimikyu and Nidoking while Speed tying with Pokemon such as Choice Band Victini, it can be easily revenge killed by faster threats such as Alolan Ninetales, Tornadus-T, and Zeraora or Choice Scarf users such as Galarian Darmanitan and Tapu Lele.
Zapdos-Galar.comments:
Other Options

Flying

Choice Scarf lets Galarian Zapdos outspeed fast foes like Choice Scarf Tapu Lele, Zeraora, and Dragapult; however, it loses a significant amount of damage output without Choice Band, limiting its role as a wallbreaker. A Substitute + Bulk Up set may also be used to let Galarian Zapdos set up on foes like Ferrothorn, Mandibuzz, and Amoonguss and become more dangerous in matchups such as Dark and Steel.

Fighting

A Choice Scarf set can be used to outspeed foes such as Choice Scarf Galarian Darmanitan, Keldeo, and Alakazam, but Fighting teams already have access to better Choice Scarf users in Terrakion and Buzzwole, the former having a higher Speed tier and the latter being able to boost its Attack stat with Beast Boost. A Bulk Up set alongside Substitute or Agility with Thunderous Kick and Brave Bird can be utilized, but Choice Band's immediate power is preferred.

Checks and Counters

Flying

Physically Defensive Walls: Physically defensive walls such as Slowbro, Galarian Corsola, and Skarmory can deal with Galarian Zapdos and take advantage of it being Choice-locked into one of its STAB moves. Slowbro can burn it with Scald and force it out with Future Sight, Galarian Corsola cripples it with Will-O-Wisp and Strength Sap, and Skarmory can phaze it with Whirlwind. However, Slowbro can be 2HKOed by Brave Bird, Galarian Corsola can be 2HKOed by Brave Bird after minor chip damage, and Skarmory fears switching into Close Combat.

Revenge Killers: Revenge killers such as Choice Scarf Victini, Alolan Raichu, and Spectrier outspeed and threaten Galarian Zapdos with their STAB attacks.

Residual Damage: Stealth Rock wears down Galarian Zapdos every time it switches in, making it unable to wallbreak more consistently. Galarian Zapdos is also significantly worn down by Brave Bird recoil, making it unable to spam the move freely.

Status: Burn limits Galarian Zapdos's wallbreaking, Toxic puts it on a timer, and paralysis leaves it outsped by slower foes like Hydreigon, Nidoking, and Kyurem.

Fighting

Revenge Killers: Galarian Zapdos is prone to being revenge killed by faster Pokemon such as Tornadus-T, Alakazam, and Choice Scarf Darmanitan; however, they can't directly switch into Galarian Zapdos.

Status: Galarian Zapdos is pretty vulnerable to status effects, with burn greatly lowering its damage, paralysis making it easy to revenge kill, and poison further hurting its longevity.

Aegislash: Aegislash can be tough to break past for Galarian Zapdos, as it can easily come in on its STAB moves. Aegislash can scout for its moves with King's Shield and can also badly poison it with Toxic. However, it has to be careful of Galarian Zapdos locked into Blaze Kick, as Defiant can give it an Attack boost if Aegislash uses King's Shield. Galarian Corsola on Ghost-type teams and Heatran on Steel-type teams can help Aegislash against Blaze Kick.

Choice Band (Flying).description:
Close Combat hits Dark-, Normal-, and Steel-types that give Flying teams trouble, such as Tyranitar, Porygon2, and Celesteela. Brave Bird hits Fighting-resistant foes such as Toxapex, Amoonguss, and Galarian Zapdos for good damage. Both of these moves can be very hard to switch into, as even physically defensive walls like Hippowdon, Clefable, and Skarmory get 2HKOed. Blaze Kick is mainly used to hit Aegislash, which otherwise completely walls Galarian Zapdos. Stomping Tantrum can be used as a more powerful alternative to hit both Aegislash and Heatran super effectively, but it risks being Choice-locked against Skarmory and Celesteela. U-turn lets Galarian Zapdos pivot against checks such as Slowbro and Galarian Corsola and bring in a teammate to deal with them. Maximum Speed investment with a Jolly nature allows Galarian Zapdos to outspeed threats like Hydreigon, Kyurem, Mimikyu, and Tapu Lele.

Landorus-T is an invaluable teammate, as it switches into Electric-type attacks from foes like Zeraora and Tapu Koko, provides Stealth Rock, Knock Off, and U-turn support, and can revenge kill foes like Dragapult and Spectrier with Choice Scarf. Stealth Rock is especially useful to wear down foes and give Galarian Zapdos opportunities to gain Defiant boosts because of Defog. In return, Galarian Zapdos can pressure walls that give Landorus-T trouble such as Celesteela, Galarian Weezing, and Swampert, as well as Defoggers like Corviknight and Mandibuzz thanks to Defiant. Celesteela or Corviknight can be used to provide a switch-in against Psychic-, Ice-, and Fairy-type attacks from foes like Latias, Kyurem, and Alolan Ninetales. Skarmory can also be used as an excellent physically defensive wall, shutting down threatening physical attackers such as Weavile, Mamoswine, and Urshifu-R more easily. In addition, it provides Spikes support, making Galarian Zapdos more difficult to switch into. Mantine provides a useful Water immunity, handling threats that can overpower Galarian Zapdos like Barraskewda and Kingdra. Thundurus-T is also a useful way to deal with Water teams, as it can defeat the entirety of it with Thunderbolt + Grass Knot while being hard to stop after a Nasty Plot and Agility boost. Galarian Moltres is a great tool against Psychic, Ghost, and Poison teams, notably dealing with answers to Galarian Zapdos such as Slowbro, Galarian Corsola, and Galarian Weezing. Tornadus-T is a great offensive pivot that can bring in Galarian Zapdos safely with U-turn while helping against types like Psychic and Ghost thanks to Knock Off.

Choice Band (Fighting).description:
Brave Bird acts as Galarian Zapdos's main STAB move, dealing massive damage to any Pokemon not resisting it, OHKOing Pokemon such as Amoonguss, Buzzwole, and Choice Specs Tapu Lele and 2HKOing Pokemon like Clefable and Toxapex after Stealth Rock damage. STAB Close Combat complements Brave Bird nicely, helping it hit Rock- and Steel-type Pokemon like Celesteela, Jirachi, and Tyranitar. Thunderous Kick can be used over Close Combat to avoid Defense drops and deal with physical walls like Klefki and Mandibuzz a bit better. U-turn helps Galarian Zapdos pivot out of tough matchups or pick off weakened Pokemon while maintaining momentum alongside Pokemon like Volt Switch Cobalion and Flip Turn Keldeo. Blaze Kick acts as coverage to hit Pokemon like Aegislash and Zapdos better. Defiant is a great ability that allows it to punish Intimidate and Defog users such as Landorus-T and Galarian Weezing, respectively. Maximum Speed investment along with a Jolly nature helps Galarian Zapdos outspeed threats such as Choice Specs Tapu Lele, non-Choice Scarf Urshifu-R, and Mimikyu, while maximum Attack investment along with Choice Band makes it a fearsome wallbreaker.

Galarian Zapdos does a great job at weakening teams for cleaners such as Buzzwole and Terrakion. It should avoid directly switching into walls, as they could inflict status conditions that greatly harm its wallbreaking potential, or into most attacks, which can hurt its longevity when combined with Brave Bird recoil. Fighting teams appreciate its ability to switch into Fighting- and Ground-type attacks like Close Combat and Earthquake from Choice Scarf Buzzwole and Excadrill, respectively. Cobalion acts as a great partner for Galarian Zapdos with its ability to switch into Fairy- and Ice-type attacks, provide Stealth Rock support, and provide Thunder Wave support so it can outspeed threats like Dragapult, Latios, and Tornadus-T. It can also bring Galarian Zapdos in with Volt Switch, and, in return, it appreciates Galarian Zapdos switching into Fighting- and Ground-type attacks. Keldeo can help Galarian Zapdos in dealing with physical walls like Hippowdon and Skarmory a bit better, and it appreciates Galarian Zapdos's ability to deal with special walls such as Blissey and Slowking. Choice Scarf Terrakion can clean through teams weakened by Galarian Zapdos and also helps in dealing with Flying-types such as Zapdos and Tornadus-T, which would otherwise trouble Galarian Zapdos, or weakening shared checks with a Swords Dance set. Choice Scarf Buzzwole can clean through teams weakened by Galarian Zapdos thanks to Beast Boost while also having Earthquake and Leech Life to beat Electric- and Psychic-types like Zeraora and Choice Specs Latios. Hawlucha can be used alongside Galarian Zapdos for dual Flying-type STAB move spam.

Moltres-Galar.overview:
Dark

Galarian Moltres is an excellent addition to Dark teams due to its Flying typing providing them with immunity to Ground-type attacks such as Excadrill's Earthquake and ability to take on Fighting-types and other threats such as Keldeo, Tapu Bulu, and Azumarill with Hurricane. Galarian Moltres is an excellent stallbreaker that can take advantage of passive defensive Pokemon such as Toxapex and Amoonguss with Substitute. Agility allows Galarian Moltres to become a threat to offensive teams, while Nasty Plot allows it to devastate defensive cores such as Amoonguss and Toxapex, letting it to threaten a multitude of teams. However, Galarian Moltres relies on getting Nasty Plot boosts before it can get across meaningful damage. Galarian Moltres's Speed tier also leaves a lot to be desired, as it is threatened by a multitude of faster attackers like Garchomp and Tapu Lele.
Moltres-Galar.comments:
Other Options

Dark

Heavy-Duty Boots allows Galarian Moltres to switch into Stealth Rock freely. Substitute can be used over Agility, allowing Galarian Moltres to set up on Pokemon such as Toxapex and Amoonguss more easily. Air Slash can be used over Hurricane for its better accuracy; however, the power difference is noticeable, such as not being able to OHKO Garchomp after a Nasty Plot boost.

Checks and Counters

Dark

Revenge Killers: Faster Pokemon such as Garchomp, Choice Specs Zapdos, and Weavile can easily take out Galarian Moltres. However, after an Agility boost, it can easily take on some of these threats.

Status: Paralysis severely limits Galarian Moltres's ability to take on slower Pokemon such as Nidoking and Azumarill and makes it more susceptible to being revenge killed, while being poisoned, especially by Toxic, puts Galarian Moltres on a timer.

Phazers: Haze users such as Toxapex and Mantine prevent Galarian Moltres from being able to break through teams with ease. Whirlwind and Roar users such as Hippowdon and Swampert can phaze Galarian Moltres and remove its boosts.

Faster Taunt Users: Faster Taunt users such as Tapu Koko, Cobalion, and Zarude prevent Galarian Moltres from accumulating Nasty Plot boosts, allowing their teammates to more easily take it on.

Specially Defensive Walls: Blissey and Tyranitar easily wall Galarian Moltres, even after several Nasty Plot boosts, and threaten it back with Seismic Toss from Blissey or Rock Blast and Toxic from Tyranitar.

Double Dance (Dark).description:
Nasty Plot allows Galarian Moltres to become a powerful wallbreaker that is able to take on defensive types like Poison in their entirety and threaten physical walls such as Hippowdon, Galarian Corsola, Slowbro, and Mandibuzz. Hurricane allows Galarian Moltres to target Dark-resistant foes such as Kommo-o, Tapu Bulu, and Zarude. Fiery Wrath is Galarian Moltres's most spammable attack, especially with its chance to flinch foes, and targets Pokemon such as Aegislash, Celesteela, and Heatran. Agility allows Galarian Moltres to outspeed threats such as Sand Rush Excadrill, Kingdra in rain, Regieleki, and Choice Scarf Terrakion and makes it a great sweeper against other offensive teams. Berserk allows Galarian Moltres to take advantage of its good natural bulk by boosting its Special Attack on top of Nasty Plot boosts. Maximum Speed investment alongside a Timid nature allow Galarian Moltres to outspeed threats such as Sand Rush Excadrill outside of sand, Nidoking, Togekiss, and Swords Dance Landorus-T.

All of Galarian Moltres's teammates appreciate its ability to take on walls such as Amoonguss and Toxapex with Substitute and Nasty Plot and threaten Fighting-types such as Keldeo. Grimmsnarl provides dual screens, giving Galarian Moltres ample opportunities to set up. Tyranitar can switch into powerful special attacks such as Choice Specs Kyurem's Ice Beam and Choice Specs Zapdos's Thunderbolt for Galarian Moltres and set Stealth Rock. Bisharp helps take on Fairy-types such as Clefable for Galarian Moltres and acts as a revenge killer, picking off weakened threats such as Choice Specs Zapdos with Sucker Punch. Weavile can break through Flying- and Dragon-types such as Tornadus-T and Dragonite and pick off weakened faster threats such as Choice Scarf Landorus-T with Ice Shard. Zarude takes care of Water- and Ground-types such as Swampert, Tapu Fini, Hippowdon, and Gastrodon and forms a stallbreaking core with Galarian Moltres to beat defensive Pokemon such as Toxapex. Krookodile provides an Electric immunity and can stop Hippowdon and Swampert from setting entry hazards with Taunt.

Dragonite.overview:
Dragon

Dragonite is a powerful wallbreaker and setup sweeper thanks to its high Attack stat and access to Dragon Dance. Its Multiscale ability paired with Heavy-Duty Boots allows it to check many Pokemon, since it can withstand nearly any attack from full HP. It has solid coverage options in Earthquake and Fire Punch to hit Pokemon such as Heatran and Celesteela, respectively, and access to a strong priority move in Extreme Speed to pick off weakened foes. However, Extreme Speed can't fully compensate for Dragonite's mediocre Speed even after setting up. At +1, it is left outsped by fast Pokemon such as Zeraora and Dragapult if running an Adamant nature, and many Choice Scarf users even with Jolly. Once it has revealed its moveset, it becomes easier to check, as, if it's lacking Earthquake, it gets walled by Heatran and neutered by Haze Toxapex, whereas without Fire Punch it can't touch Pokemon such as Celesteela and Ferrothorn. Dragonite may also struggle to find safe opportunities to switch in because it risks getting its Multiscale broken.

Flying

Multiscale allows Dragonite to tank most unboosted hits from full health, and Heavy-Duty Boots keeps it from getting chipped by Stealth Rock; this endurance makes Dragonite a fearsome setup sweeper. Extreme Speed allows it to revenge kill faster offensive threats to Flying-type teams, such as Alolan Raichu and Kingdra. Flying-type teams also appreciate its part-Dragon typing, which gives it many notable resistances, including Water and Fire against Pokemon such as Urshifu-R, Volcarona, and Victini. It also gives a neutrality to Electric. However, Dragonite has very limited opportunities to safely switch into the field due to the risk of breaking Multiscale. It is susceptible to status conditions such as burn and poison, which easily break Multiscale. Dragonite also struggles with breaking through walls such as Slowbro, Galarian Weezing, and Galarian Corsola, as they can threaten to burn it.
Dragonite.comments:
Other Options

Dragon

Dragonite can use a Choice Band set for immediate power and a fourth coverage move; however, without Heavy-Duty Boots, Dragonite can't preserve its Multiscale if Stealth Rock is up and, as a result, loses a lot of utility.

Flying

Choice Band is an alternative set that gives immediate power; however, this leaves Dragonite and Multiscale susceptible to Stealth Rock. Roost over Extreme Speed or a coverage move is another plausible set, but the trade results in less damage output and potency overall. An Adamant nature can be opted for on sets that utilize Fire Punch over Earthquake, as outspeeding Tapu Koko after a Dragon Dance boost is no longer necessary.

Checks and Counters

Dragon

Ice-types: Due to Dragonite's 4x weakness to Ice, Pokemon that carry Ice-type coverage pose huge threats to it, and STAB Ice-type attacks can sometimes even OHKO it through Multiscale.

Fairy-types: Dragonite doesn't run any coverage for Fairy-types, so naturally it has a hard time dealing with Pokemon such as Galarian Weezing and Clefable.

Status: Dragonite hates getting inflicted with any status because it severely hinders its sweeping capabilities.

Physically Defensive Walls: Dragonite may struggle getting past many physical walls such as Hippowdon, Galarian Corsola, and Mandibuzz because they're bulky enough to take a boosted attack and threaten it in various ways.

Flying

Status: Dragonite is susceptible to being burned or poisoned, since the former halves its Attack and both break its Multiscale, making it harder to set up. Paralysis also harms it greatly, leaving it unable to outspeed many threats after a boost and more easily revenge killed.

Sand and Hail: Both sand and hail immediately and automatically break Multiscale.

Physically Defensive Walls: Dragonite has a hard time breaking through physically defensive Pokemon such as Galarian Weezing and Galarian Corsola, even after Dragon Dance boosts.

Knock Off: As Dragonite heavily relies on Heavy-Duty Boots to ameliorate its weakness to Stealth Rock, Knock Off heavily cripples it.

Dragon Dance (Dragon).description:
Dragon Dance gives Dragonite the necessary power to break through opposing teams. It should be used late-game once the opposing team has been weakened. Outrage is its strongest STAB attack, dealing massive damage to anything that doesn't resist it. It should be used carefully, as it locks Dragonite in for a few turns. Extreme Speed allows Dragonite to pick off weakened Pokemon without taking damage and deal with fast threats such as Weavile and Tapu Koko. Earthquake hits Steel-types that resist its other moves such as Heatran, Aegislash, and Melmetal. Alternatively, Fire Punch can be used to hit Celesteela and Ferrothorn. Heavy-Duty Boots relieves Dragonite of worrying about Stealth Rock so it can keep its Multiscale. An Adamant nature can be used for maximum power, whereas Jolly can be used to outspeed Pokemon such as Zeraora and Dragapult at +1 Speed.

As a setup sweeper, Dragonite appreciates teammates that help weaken the opposing team as much as possible before going for the win. Garchomp's Stealth Rock aids in this goal, as it makes it easier for Dragonite to get KOs. Hydreigon is able to threaten Steel-type teams with its coverage, giving Dragonite an easier time due to its exploitable moveset. Dragalge switches in well on most Fairy-type attacks that threaten Dragonite thanks to its Poison typing and good Special Defense. It can also set up Toxic Spikes to whittle down the opposing team for Dragonite. Kyurem is a strong breaker and does well in matchups where Dragonite struggles such as Poison, Ground, and Water. Latias provides Healing Wish support, which is extremely valuable for a setup sweeper such as Dragonite. Dragapult can spread status in the form of Will-O-Wisp and Thunder Wave and punch holes in teams with its attacks to open up for Dragonite to clean.

Offensive Dragon Dance (Flying).description:
Dragon Dance makes Dragonite both a setup sweeper and a late-game cleaner. Outrage is the best Dragon-type STAB move available to Dragonite, and it can comfortably 2HKO walls such as Slowbro and Hippowdon after a Dragon Dance boost. Extreme Speed gives Dragonite the only priority available on Flying teams, and it can be used to clean up chipped or frail threats such as Alolan Raichu. Earthquake is primarily used to hit Electric-types, such as Tapu Koko and Zeraora, and Pokemon that resist or are immune to Dragon such as Heatran, Jirachi, and Azumarill, as well as hitting targets like Tyranitar and Toxapex super effectively. Fire Punch can be used in lieu of Earthquake to deal with Ferrothorn and Celesteela, since they otherwise completely wall Dragonite. Heavy-Duty Boots makes Dragonite immune to Stealth Rock, allowing it to preserve Multiscale reliably. Thanks to its Jolly nature, it outspeeds several threats such as Tapu Koko, Spectrier, Zeraora, and Dragapult after just one Dragon Dance boost.

Celesteela, Corviknight, and Skarmory can sponge super effective Ice-, Dragon-, Rock-, and Fairy-type attacks for Dragonite with ease. Celesteela notably takes on threatening Fairy-types such as Tapu Lele, Clefable, and Mimikyu. Corviknight and Skarmory take on Ice-types such as Kyurem and Weavile, respectively. Corviknight is also able to safely bring in Dragonite with U-turn, while Skarmory can provide Spikes support. Landorus-T helps greatly in the Electric matchup, is able to set Stealth Rock, and can provide Knock Off support. Tornadus-T can use Knock Off too, and it can also use Taunt and then pivot into Dragonite. Thundurus-T is a complementary setup sweeper to Dragonite, since it can deal with foes such as Tapu Fini, but it can also act as a reliable revenge killer and great offensive pivot when equipped with a Choice Scarf. Zapdos can Pressure stall and reliably pivot to eventually put bulkier foes such as Slowking in a weakened position. Choice Specs Zapdos and Dragonite deal with each other's threats well. Galarian Moltres aids greatly in matchups like Psychic, Ghost, and Steel, while Galarian Zapdos helps immensely in matchups such as Steel, Dark, and Ice.

Stallbreaker.description:
Mew's good bulk combined with its wide array of utility moves and pure Psychic typing makes it a good stallbreaker that can be troublesome for a variety of types such as Steel, Ground, and Psychic to deal with. Its access to moves such as Taunt, Knock Off, and Will-O-Wisp combined with reliable recovery in Roost allows it to break down a variety of defensive Pokemon in the Monotype metagame such as Toxapex, Corviknight, and Ferrothorn, as well as cripple offensive Pokemon such as Excadrill and Duraludon. Taunt is especially important, as it prevents said defensive Pokemon from healing, setting up, spreading status, and setting entry hazards. The given EV spread allows Mew to outspeed Mimikyu and Kyurem-B in order to cripple both before they can move and prevent the latter from using Dragon Dance with Taunt while also outpacing other offensive Pokemon such as Bisharp and Mamoswine.

Mew dislikes dealing with wallbreakers such as Dragapult and Keldeo. Choice Scarf users such as Indeedee and Gardevoir support Mew by revenge killing said wallbreakers, while Mew can break down defensive Pokemon like Corviknight that they struggle with. Indeedee's Normal typing also allows it to switch into Ghost-type moves such as Gengar and Dragapult's Shadow Ball. Hatterene can utilize its Magic Bounce to reflect entry hazards that wear down and cripple Mew as it switches in. Gardevoir and Hatterene are also good checks to Dark-type Pokemon such as Hydreigon and Weavile that Mew struggles with, while Healing Wish users such as the aforementioned Gardevoir, Indeedee-F, Celebi, and Jirachi can heal Mew if it ever gets worn down or inflicted with status. Using its good defensive typing, Celebi can take Water-type attacks such as Seismitoad and Keldeo's Hydro Pump under rain, and in return it appreciates Mew's ability to Taunt Defoggers such as Corviknight, Mandibuzz, and Pelipper in order to keep its Stealth Rock on the field.

Cosmic Power (Psychic).description:
Thanks to its decent bulk, typing, and Speed, Cosmic Power Mew is an excellent late-game wincon on Psychic teams, finding setup opportunities against matchups such as Steel, Water, and Electric. Stored Power's Base Power is boosted as Mew sets up Cosmic Power and when Weakness Policy is triggered, allowing it to overwhelm bulky Psychic-resistant Pokemon like Corviknight. Taunt denies defensive counterplay in the form of Toxic, Whirlwind, and Haze from users such as Aegislash, Hippowdon, and Toxapex, respectively; it also prevents bulky setup sweepers such as Bulk Up Corviknight and Calm Mind Tapu Fini and Clefable from boosting alongside Mew. On the other hand, Body Press lets Mew KO Dark-types such as Bisharp, Hydreigon, and Weavile without as much help from its teammates. Weakness Policy takes advantage of the opposing team's need to strike Mew with super effective moves to take it down before it has accumulated Cosmic Power boosts, allowing it to OHKO Zeraora if it uses Knock Off on Mew after a Cosmic Power, and takes advantage of Mew's weakness to U-turn, which is commonly used by pivots such as Landorus-T and Corviknight. Alternatively, Lum Berry may be used to deal with faster Toxic users such as Tapu Koko and Tornadus-T. Maximum Speed with a Timid nature lets Mew outspeeds threats such as Urshifu-R and Hydreigon.

Choice Scarf Tapu Lele is an excellent teammate, as it handles Dark- and Dragon-types that overwhelm Mew even after a Cosmic Power boost, such as Choice Band Weavile, Zarude, and Dragapult. Slowbro checks strong physical attackers such as Barraskewda and Excadrill for Mew and can utilize a Colbur or Kasib berry to deal with Dark- or Ghost-types, respectively. Trick users such as Victini, Latias, and Jirachi can lure and debilitate defensive walls, such as Toxapex, Mandibuzz, and Mantine, which check Mew if it's not running Taunt. Victini also KOes Steel-types like Celesteela and Aegislash which give Mew a hard time if not running Taunt. Choice Scarf Jirachi and Latias can also utilize Healing Wish, allowing Mew to try to set up a second time once the opposing team has been weakened. Galarian Slowking is a specially defensive wall that checks Aegislash and removes Toxic Spikes for Mew on switch-in. Hatterene bounces back entry hazards and checks Dark-types such as Galarian Moltres and Zarude. Hatterene also benefits from Body Press Mew, as Hatterene is walled by Steel-types, and in return deals with Toxapex that variants of Mew without Taunt are vulnerable to.

Nasty Plot.description:
Mew's access to Nasty Plot and good coverage options make it a good setup sweeper capable of threatening many types like Steel, Grass, and Poison. Fire Blast is extremely important, as it allows Mew to hit Steel-type Pokemon such as Ferrothorn, Corviknight, Aegislash, and Bisharp for super effective damage, therefore making it amazing in the Steel matchup when set up. Focus Blast is used to check Steel- and Dark-types like Heatran and Tyranitar. Thunderbolt hits Water- and Flying-types like Crawdaunt, Mantine, and Celesteela. A Colbur Berry allows Mew to take Bisharp's Sucker Punch while helping with other Dark-type attacks. Generally, Mew should find passive Pokemon like Toxapex, Ferrothorn, and Corviknight to set up on and force out with its attacks.

Stealth Rock is particularly notable for securing the OHKO on Corviknight at +2 with Fire Blast, as well as breaking Focus Sash on Pokemon such as Cloyster that could otherwise stop Mew. Tapu Lele is a strong wallbreaker that can set Psychic Terrain for Mew, protecting it from priority and boosting its Psychic, while Hatterene can keep entry hazards off the field with Magic Bounce. Trick users such as Victini, Latias, and Jirachi can lure and debilitate defensive walls, such as Toxapex, Mandibuzz, and Mantine.

Crobat.comments:
Other Options

Poison

U-turn can be opted for instead of Toxic in order to gain more momentum throughout the game and can help get in threats such as Nidoking against Steel- and Flying-type teams. Taunt can also be used over Toxic in order to prevent setup sweepers such as Dragon Dance Dragonite, Gravity Landorus-T, Nasty Plot Hydreigon, and Calm Mind Clefable while also denying Defog from Pokemon such as Tornadus-T.

Utility (Poison).description:
Crobat's immunity to Ground-type moves and ability to quickly spread Toxic, even through Substitute, is invaluable for Poison teams; it also switches into attacks such as Choice Scarf Landorus-T's Earthquake and Tapu Bulu's High Horsepower that give Poison teams trouble. Brave Bird is Crobat's primary STAB move and allows it to hit foes such as Choice Band Galarian Zapdos, Tapu Bulu, and Tornadus-T, which Poison struggles to deal with long-term. Toxic is great on Crobat, as it allows Poison to make progress against Pokemon it struggles to break through such as Landorus-T, Mantine, and Kyurem. Additionally, paired with Infiltrator, it allows Crobat to use Toxic against prominent Substitute users such as Bulk Up Landorus-T, SubRoost Kyurem, and Nasty Plot Hydreigon. Defog allows Crobat to keep entry hazards off the field, allowing its slower defensive teammates such as Amoonguss and Galarian Slowking to remain healthy throughout the course of the battle. 184 Speed EVs allow Crobat to outspeed Tornadus-T, which lets Crobat catch it with a Toxic or Brave Bird, while the rest of the EVs are put into HP and Special Defense so Crobat can get off a Toxic on SubRoost Kyurem.

Amoonguss appreciates Crobat's Defog, as it can continuously regenerate health with Regenerator and doesn't have to worry about being overwhelmed when helping Crobat by switching into physical attackers Poison struggles with such as Garchomp and Zeraora. Nidoking serves as an excellent teammate, as it also appreciates Crobat's entry hazard removal and deals with Steel- and Electric-types that Crobat can't do anything to such as Celesteela, Ferrothorn, and Tapu Koko. Drapion and Skuntank are both very helpful to Crobat and Poison in general, as they provide a mandatory Psychic immunity, being able to switch into the likes of Hatterene and Choice Scarf Tapu Lele. Galarian Slowking is a secondary switch-in to Psychic-type moves from Latios and Jirachi; it also deals with special attackers such as Alolan Ninetales and Heatran and can combat Kyurem by itself after Crobat has poisoned it. Toxapex finds itself supporting Poison teams by dealing with setup users such as Swords Dance Weavile, Dragon Dance Dragapult, and Swords Dance Aegislash with Haze. Finally, Nihilego helps defeat Galarian Moltres, as it is able to take both of its attacks and threaten it with Power Gem.

Lanturn.comments:
Other Options

Water

Scald can be run over Protect to further spread status and as a way of hitting Pokemon that it otherwise would not be able to hit, such as Excadrill, on the switch. Doing this, however, would limit Leftovers recovery, which is the only form of reliable recovery that Lanturn has.

Specially Defensive Pivot (Water).description:
Lanturn is a niche choice for Water teams as a specially defensive pivot and check for Flying- and Electric-types such as Thundurus-T. What sets Lanturn apart from the other Electric-immune Pokemon like Swampert is the fact that it is able to check Pokemon that would otherwise threaten the aforementioned foes, such as Grass Knot Thundurus-T and Choice Specs Zapdos. Volt Absorb helps out tremendously in the Electric matchup and against teams that utilize Volt Switch. Volt Absorb can also be used as a form of recovery with correct prediction. Volt Switch allows Lanturn to pivot out and gain momentum. Toxic wears down foes such as Swampert and Thundurus-T, which Lanturn is otherwise helpless against. Heal Bell helps prevent Lanturn and its teammates from being worn down by Toxic users such as Toxapex. Protect allows Lanturn to gain some health back using Leftovers, accumulate Toxic damage, and scout Choice-locked foes such as Landorus-T.

An Electric-immune Pokemon is useful to practically every Pokemon on a Water team that is not immune to Electric. While Lanturn's main niche historically has been on defensive Water teams, it can be used on other kinds of teams, such as balanced or offensive ones. Pelipper makes for an ideal partner for Lanturn, as it has an immunity to Ground-type moves and can switch into strong physical attacks that otherwise threaten Lanturn. In return, Lanturn can help preserve Pelipper with its immunity to Electric-type moves. Toxapex makes for an ideal partner for Lanturn, as it can deal with Grass-type Pokemon that threaten Water teams, such as Choice Scarf Tapu Bulu, and can remove Toxic Spikes. Lanturn's Volt Absorb synergizes well with Mantine, as it allows for an easy switch-in to Mantine's quadruple Electric weakness, while Mantine is immune to Ground-type moves that are super effective against Lanturn. Mantine can also remove entry hazards with Defog, allowing Lanturn to switch into Electric-types with more ease. Other Electric-immune teammates, such as Swampert and Quagsire, are ideal, as they can take on Pokemon that threaten Lanturn's weak Defense stat, such as Zeraora. Sap Sipper Azumarill makes for an ideal partner on stall Water teams, as it provides Lanturn with a Grass immunity and pressures Nasty Plot Hydreigon. Slowking can switch into special attacking Pokemon that threaten Lanturn, such as Nidoking, Substitute + Roost Kyurem, and Tapu Lele. Crawdaunt can benefit from Lanturn's ability to wear foes down, as Lanturn allows it to have an easier time to pull off a late-game sweep against types like Poison, Dark, and Steel. Suicune can also function well when paired with Lanturn thanks to Suicune's ability to sweep late-game. Tapu Fini can prevent Lanturn from being poisoned with Misty Surge, and Calm Mind sets can check Dragon-types such as Hydreigon and Kommo-o for Lanturn. Urshifu-R is a tremendous wallbreaker that can take care of bulky Pokemon that threaten Lanturn, such as Excadrill, Heatran, Ferrothorn, and Kyurem. Lanturn can also bring Urshifu-R in safely via Volt Switch. Lanturn pairs well with offensive Pokemon such as Barraskewda, as they make up for Lanturn's passivity, and Lanturn's Volt Switch can be used to bring in these Pokemon safely.

Xatu (Flying).description:
With its ability in Magic Bounce deterring Stealth Rock and dual screens support for teammates, Xatu acts as a great utility support Pokemon for hyper offensive Flying-type teams. It provides threatening setup sweepers like Gyarados and Hawlucha not only with dual screen support, but also with Thunder Wave to slow down faster Pokemon and open up more room for offensive teammates to shine. U-turn allows it to switch into the desired teammate after setting up dual screens without losing much momentum for the team. Xatu should be preserved, as Magic Bounce is crucial for Flying-type teams and its Speed tier lets it repeatedly set up dual screens throughout the game. Maximum Speed investment allows Xatu to be as fast as possible to set up dual screens, while the rest of the spread improves its overall bulk to paralyze threats like Barraskewda and Togekiss for the team when behind dual screen support.

Offensive behemoths like Gyarados, Hawlucha, Braviary, and Charizard all make exceptional teammates for Xatu, as they all appreciate dual screen and Thunder Wave support to aid them in setting up. Xatu should be kept away from Knock Off users like Clefable and Whimsicott, as without its Light Clay, the number of turns its teammates can take advantage of dual screens support is reduced. Additionally, Xatu should be kept away from faster Dark-, Ice-, and Ghost-types that can outright OHKO it and instead should pivot out with U-turn on their predicted switch in.

Azumarill.overview:
Fairy

Thanks to its ability in Huge Power and Aqua Jet, Azumarill can act as a powerful physical attacker for Fairy teams. It can run either a sweeping Belly Drum set or a Choice Band set to wallbreak. Azumarill can remove items and hit Pokemon like Aegislash and Slowbro with Knock Off. It can also damage Steel-types like Melmetal and Ferrothorn with Superpower. Due to its low stats and reliance on Aqua Jet, Azumarill gets revenge killed easily by any Pokemon that doesn't mind Aqua Jet, like Zarude or Tapu Lele. Its Speed leaves it slower than some defensive Pokemon like Rotom-W and Mew, letting them burn or cripple Azumarill.
Azumarill.comments:
Other Options

Fairy

Azumarill can run a Jolly nature to outrun Pokemon like Adamant Azumarill and Rotom-W. Play Rough is an option with Choice Band too, since it hits Dragon- and Fighting-types like Kingdra and Keldeo, but it is usually outclassed by a move like Knock Off, which hits more important targets.

Checks and Counters

Fairy

Haze: Pokemon like Mantine can remove Azumarill's Attack boost from Belly Drum with Haze. Unlike other setup sweepers, Azumarill usually only has one chance to set up, since it costs half of Azumarill's health.

Status: All status conditions greatly hamper Azumarill's ability to make progress. A burn renders its attacks much weaker, paralysis lets Pokemon like Melmetal outrun it, and being poisoned forces Azumarill to take even more residual damage on top of entry hazards and often Belly Drum.

Revenge Killlers: Pokemon that can outspeed Azumarill and also survive or nullify Aqua Jet, like Kyurem, Tapu Lele, and Tapu Bulu—which aren't OHKOed even at +6—are able to revenge kill Azumarill easily.

Psychic Terrain: Psychic Terrain from Azumarill's common teammate, Tapu Lele, prevents it from using Aqua Jet, a key part of its arsenal. This leaves it unable to KO Pokemon like Nihilego, Victini, and Nidoking.

Belly Drum (Fairy).description:
Belly Drum Azumarill is an effective sweeper with its STAB Aqua Jet, which lets it pick up KOs on threats like Thundurus-T, Nihilego, and Zeraora. Knock Off can OHKO targets that comfortably tank Aqua Jet, like Amoonguss, Aegislash, and Gastrodon, after a Belly Drum. It also has the added utility of removing items, like Toxapex's Black Sludge or Mantine's Heavy-Duty Boots. Substitute is used to avoid status conditions and set up on defensive Pokemon like Torkoal and defensive Aegislash when Azumarill is behind Light Screen. Brick Break can also be used, as it hits Pokemon like Melmetal for more damage. Play Rough is an option for targets that survive both Knock Off and Aqua Jet, like Hydreigon. 4 HP EVs allow Azumarill to trigger its Sitrus Berry after a Belly Drum every time. The Speed EVs allow it to outpace most defensive Pokemon like Aegislash and Celesteela. It is a good idea to set up Belly Drum with dual screens active or in front of a passive Pokemon, since Azumarill usually only gets once chance to use it. You also don't want to use Belly Drum if Tapu Lele's Psychic Terrain will still be active, since it prevents Aqua Jet from being used.

Klefki is an invaluable teammate because of its dual screens—allowing Azumarill to set up more easily, Spikes, and Steel typing providing a Poison immunity and resistance to Ice. Spikes support is incredibly important for Azumarill, allowing it to always OHKO Pokemon like Toxapex and Ferrothorn after a Belly Drum. Clefable's utility options in Stealth Rock and Knock Off cripples foes and makes it easier for Azumarill to sweep as well. Tapu Bulu is great because it can beat Electric-types like Rotom-W and Alolan Raichu. It can revenge kill threats like Zapdos and Thundurus-T with a Choice Scarf or break through defensive Pokemon like Ferrothorn and Toxapex with Substitute + Swords Dance. Tapu Koko is a great offensive pivot that provides STAB Thunderbolt and Dazzling Gleam to hit troublesome Water- and Dragon-types like Mantine, Toxapex, Latios, and Kyurem for Azumarill. Tapu Lele can beat Poison- and Dragon-types like Nidoking, Hydreigon, and Latias with its STAB Psyshock and Moonblast. Nasty Plot Togekiss can remove troublesome Poison- and Grass-types like Toxapex, Galarian Weezing, Ferrothorn, and Rillaboom. Other dual screens sweepers like Bulk Up Grimmsnarl and Swords Dance Mimikyu can work together with Azumarill and break down the opposing team. Both are excellent in the Ghost or Psychic matchup with their STAB, super effective attacks and priority attacks.

Choice Band (Fairy).description:
Choice Band Azumarill's immediate power lets it act as an effective physical wallbreaker. Liquidation hits Pokemon like Hippowdon, Heatran, and Mandibuzz. Aqua Jet allows Azumarill to occasionally revenge kill Pokemon like Excadrill, Nihilego, and Victini. Knock Off can remove items like Leftovers or Heavy-Duty Boots from opposing Pokemon, and it also beats the likes of Slowking and Aegislash. Superpower lets Azumarill deal hefty damage to Steel-types like Ferrothorn and Melmetal.

Klefki is an incredible teammate, providing dual screens and a switch-in to Ice-, Grass-, and Poison-type attacks, as well as Spikes, which Azumarill heavily appreciates to pick up KOs more easily. Clefable's Stealth Rock and Knock Off are equally helpful for Azumarill. It also has Magic Guard, letting it act as a status absorber for Azumarill. Its Rocky Helmet allows it to chip down Pokemon like Celesteela, making it easier for Azumarill to break past them. Tapu Koko's U-turn can help Azumarill find opportunities to break through the opposing team. Choice Band Azumarill and Tapu Koko form a good offensive core, as Azumarill can beat Ground-types that come in on Tapu Koko, like Hippowdon and Excadrill, and Tapu Koko beats troublesome Dragon-, Water-, and Flying-types, like Hydreigon, Mantine, and Corviknight. Tapu Lele and Azumarill can break many defensive cores together with their powerful attacks. Tapu Lele can handle Poison- and Dragon-types like Dragalge, Toxapex, and Latios, while Azumarill can beat targets like Ferrothorn, Aegislash, and Slowking. However, Tapu Lele's Psychic Surge can sometimes prevent Azumarill from using Aqua Jet. Tapu Bulu enjoys Azumarill revenge killing Pokemon like Volcarona and Choice Scarf Blacephalon. In return, Tapu Bulu can beat Electric-type Pokemon like Rotom-W and Tapu Koko. It also beats Water-types like Mantine and Seismitoad. Togekiss beats Grass's and Poison's defensive cores with Substitute + Nasty Plot, that Azumarill has trouble breaking through. Bulk Up Grimmsnarl and Swords Dance Mimikyu are other great dual screens attackers that help beat Ghost and Psychic.

Slowking.overview:
Water

Slowking has cemented itself as a staple on Water teams due to its impressive special bulk allowing it to switch into threats such as Nidoking and access to Teleport. With Future Sight and Teleport, Slowking can force progress against types like Water and Poison with Urshifu-R. Slowking also has extremely reliable recovery in Slack Off and Regenerator, allowing it to stay healthy throughout the match with ease. Slowking's Psychic typing allows it to stomach Psychic-type attacks such as Choice Specs Tapu Lele's Psychic with ease. While Slowking's special bulk is phenomenal, its physical bulk is lacking and allows physical wallbreakers and setup sweepers such as Dragon Dance Dragapult and Bisharp to easily OHKO it. Slowking is also heavily reliant on Heavy-Duty Boots to act as a reliable pivot and can be worn down by entry hazards and Toxic Spikes if they are removed.
Slowking.comments:
Other Options

Water

Ice Beam can be run over Scald to target Pokemon such as Dragonite and Substitute Hydreigon. Calm Mind Slowking can be used on stall Water teams to answer Kyurem; however, it is not worth using on any balance or offensive team.

Checks and Counters

Water

Physical Wallbreakers and Setup Sweepers: Zeraora, Bisharp, Tapu Bulu, Dragon Dance Dragapult, and Swords Dance Garchomp can easily break through Slowking due to its poor physical defense. However, none of these Pokemon can safely switch into Slowking because they fear being burned by Scald.

Stallbreakers: Stallbreakers such as Mew, Tapu Fini, and Tornadus-T can prevent Slowking from pivoting with Teleport or using Slack Off. They can also remove Slowking's Heavy-Duty Boots with Knock Off, forcing it to take chip damage from entry hazards whenever it tries to pivot into battle.

Toxic: Being poisoned by Toxic makes it more difficult for Slowking to switch into special attackers such as Tapu Lele and Nidoking and safely bring in a teammate with Teleport.

Specially Defensive Pivot (Water).description:
Scald can be used to fish for burns against Pokemon such as against Corviknight and deter physical attackers such as Bisharp from switching in. Slack Off, Regenerator, and Heavy-Duty Boots help Slowking with its longevity, as the former two provide recovery and the latter protects it from entry hazards like Toxic Spikes. Teleport + Future Sight is a potent combination that allows Slowking to safely bring in an offensive teammate and support them offensively by pressuring foes with an extra attack. Maximum HP and Special Defense investment maximizes Slowking's special bulk, allowing it to reliably switch into attacks like Choice Specs Latios's Draco Meteor and Nidoking's Earth Power or Thunderbolt. A Sassy nature alongside 0 Speed IVs allows Slowking to retain momentum against opposing Slowking with a slower Teleport.

Urshifu-R can take on Steel- and Dark-types for Slowking such as Ferrothorn, Corviknight, Bisharp, Tyranitar, and Mandibuzz. Urshifu-R and Slowking form a potent offensive core that can make progress against types such as Water and Poison by using Future Sight, bringing in Urshifu-R safely with Teleport, and forcing a Pokemon to switch into both its attacks and Future Sight. While not as good as Urshifu-R, Keldeo can outspeed threats such as Zarude. Swampert is an Electric immunity, can take on Electric-types such as Zeraora with Earthquake, and provides Stealth Rock, which in tandem with Future Sight can wear down foes quickly. Toxapex can form a Regenerator core with Slowking, absorbing physical attacks such as Rillaboom's Grassy Glide and retaliating with Poison Jab. Choice Scarf Tapu Fini can take on Dark- and Dragon-types such as Zarude, Hydreigon, and Kyurem for Slowking. Additionally, it can cripple other walls by locking them into one attack with Trick or removing items such as Toxapex's Black Sludge with Knock Off. Crawdaunt can put in work against Psychic and Ghost teams, taking on opposing walls such as Slowbro and Galarian Corsola. Rotom-W can clear entry hazards with Defog, act as a revenge killer with Choice Scarf, and dent Choice Specs Zapdos. It can also use Trick to lock foes into an unfavorable move.

Slowking-Galar.overview:
Poison

Assault Vest Galarian Slowking is a great specially defensive wall for Poison teams that sponges special attacks from Pokemon like Latios, Kyurem, and Thundurus-T. It can also use its Psychic neutrality to switch into Psychic-type attacks from threats to Poison like Tapu Lele and Latias. It forms a Regenerator core with Toxapex and Amoonguss, making them extremely hard to break through. Its many coverage moves keep it from being setup fodder and improve a number of matchups for Poison like Flying, Dragon, and Fighting. Its lackluster physical bulk leaves it forced out by wallbreakers like Bisharp, Cinderace, Excadrill, and Zeraora.
Slowking-Galar.comments:
Other Options

Poison

Psyshock is an option over Future Sight to prevent Calm Mind and Quiver Dance sweepers like Spectrier and Keldeo from setting up.

Psychic

44 EVs may be invested in Defense instead of Special Defense to always take Choice Specs Tapu Lele's Psyshock after Stealth Rock and better handle Choice Band Urshifu-R and Galarian Zapdos, which is important for teams lacking Jirachi or Bronzong. Scald may be used over Earthquake to dissuade physical attackers such as Landorus-T and is situationally useful when frozen against Kyurem. Using Psychic over Ice Beam lets Galarian Slowking immediately threaten Nidoking and Urshifu-R. Psyshock does the same, albeit worse, while letting Galarian Slowking beat Volcarona without Roost and pressure SubRoost Kyurem attempting to PP stall. However, using these moves instead of Ice Beam leaves it unable to threaten Flying- and Dragon-types.

Assault Vest (Poison).description:
Future Sight in conjunction with its other attacks helps Galarian Slowking break through bulkier Pokemon like Toxapex and Cradily and targets wallbreakers like Dragapult and Zeraora. Sludge Bomb immediately damages special attackers and has a nifty chance to poison defensive Pokemon like Mantine and Zapdos, making them a lot easier to beat. Sludge Bomb is also needed to break Substitute from Kyurem, which can threaten Poison with Earth Power and Ice Beam. Earthquake helps with Poison- and Steel-types like Dragalge, Nidoking, and most importantly Heatran, which could trap and remove this set otherwise. Flamethrower with Earthquake gives Poison teams a better chance in the Steel matchup, specifically allowing Galarian Slowking to hit Ferrothorn and other Steel-types like Scizor, Skarmory, and Magnezone. Ice Beam hits Flying- and Dragon-types like Galarian Zapdos, Landorus-T, Garchomp, and Hydreigon, but it often needs to catch them as they switch in. A Sassy nature avoids weakening Earthquake.

All of Galarian Slowking's teammates appreciate its ability to switch in on special attacks from Pokemon like Heatran, often Psychic-types like Alakazam and Choice Scarf Latias. Nidoking can set Stealth Rock, provide an Electric immunity for Regieleki, and get rid of defensive Pokemon and physical attackers like Mantine, Aegislash, and Dragonite. Toxapex and Amoonguss form a Regenerator core alongside Galarian Slowking, making them harder to KO. Toxapex beats setup sweepers like Cinderace and Dragapult with Haze and physical attackers like Bisharp and Weavile. Amoonguss helps the team switch into Earthquake from Mold Breaker Excadrill and avert Swords Dance sweeps with Foul Play. Furthermore, it spreads status with Spore and Stun Spore and helps Galarian Slowking with physical attackers like Zeraora. Galarian Weezing gets rid of entry hazards with Defog, has Levitate for Ground-types like Garchomp and Landorus-T, and has Strange Stream to threaten Dark- and Dragon-types like Dragapult, Hydreigon, Weavile, and Zarude. While Galarian Slowking can withstand most Psychic-type moves, using Drapion prevents the team from being swept by a Calm Mind sweeper like Latias or Jirachi and gives the team Knock Off to remove items and help with Ghost-types like Spectrier and Aegislash.

Assault Vest (Psychic).description:
Galarian Slowking serves Psychic teams as a strong special wall that deals with threats such as Heatran, Tapu Fini, and Nihilego while absorbing Toxic Spikes. Sludge Bomb spreads poison and deals with Fairy-types such as Tapu Lele and Tapu Fini. Flamethrower threatens Steel-types such as Ferrothorn and Aegislash, while Earthquake covers Heatran and Nihilego. Future Sight lets Galarian Slowking support wallbreakers such as Victini and Latios by making them much harder for types such as Water and Poison to switch into, while Ice Beam punishes switch-ins such as Landorus-T and Garchomp alongside generally nailing Flying- and Dragon-types like Zapdos and Hydreigon. Assault Vest in tandem with Regenerator allows Galarian Slowking to pivot into most special attackers with ease. 12 Special Attack EVs allow it to always break SubToxic Aegislash's Substitute with Flamethrower.

For teammates, Slowbro is a physically defensive pivot that can take on strong physical attackers such as Landorus-T, Excadrill, and Urshifu-R; it also completes a defensive Regenerator backbone covering physical and special attackers for some Psychic teams. Victini helps Galarian Slowking break down Steel teams, as they both wear down their shared check in Heatran, and Victini can pivot Slowking in with U-turn. Choice Scarf Tapu Lele deals with Dark-types such as Bisharp and Hydreigon. In turn, it appreciates Galarian Slowking wearing down Steel-types like Aegislash and Celesteela so it can clean Steel and Flying late-game. Hatterene is an additional Dark-type check that also provides entry hazard control for Galarian Slowking's Regenerator. Jirachi deals with special attackers like Tapu Lele and Hatterene and sets Stealth Rock. Cosmic Power Mew is an excellent teammate that functions as a late-game sweeper; it benefits from Galarian Slowking removing Toxic Spikes and checking faster Toxic users such as Tapu Koko. Latios deals with fast threats such as Galarian Zapdos and Hydreigon.

Steelix.comments:
Other Options

Ground

Curse is an excellent option instead of Iron Defense, as it allows Steelix to boost Heavy Slam and Body Press simultaneously, but Iron Defense is preferred, as it combats Swords Dance users like Rillaboom. A set with Curse, Rest, Sleep Talk, and Heavy Slam may be used to shrug off burns and improve Steelix's longevity, although Steelix would be losing out on coverage.

Physically Defensive (Ground).description:
Steelix's exceptional defensive typing and unmatched Defense stat make it a great asset on Ground teams without sand. Being part-Steel-type lets Steelix deter Toxic for the team and irritates teams like Grass, Fairy, and Dragon teams with Iron Defense. Heavy Slam is vital to check foes like Tapu Bulu and Clefable, which can trouble Steelix with their own setup, and also catches Whimsicott switching in to lock Steelix into a setup move with Encore. Body Press capitalizes on Iron Defense boosts to deal with Pokemon like Zarude, Ferrothorn, and Galarian Darmanitan. Steelix uses Substitute to block Leech Seed users like Ferrothorn, which interfere with its Leftovers recovery, and Iron Defense makes it much more difficult to break. Additionally, Substitute punishes foes like Weavile, Zarude, and Rillaboom switching out of Steelix, as it grants free Iron Defense setup or chip damage with Heavy Slam or Body Press.

Steelix provides neutralities against Grass-types such as Tapu Bulu, Zarude, and Rillaboom and Ice-type Pokemon like Weavile, Arctozolt, and Galarian Darmanitan. Furthermore, Steelix can switch into common Toxic users like Klefki and Blissey for its teammates. Landorus-T is a reliable Ground-immune and Fighting-resistant teammate that can switch into Excadrill and Garchomp. Mamoswine is greatly appreciated for checking opposing Ground-types like Hippowdon, Nidoking, and Garchomp, as well as threatening Dragon- and Flying-types like Kommo-o, Hydreigon, and Galarian Zapdos. Garchomp is an incredibly powerful wallbreaker that checks troublesome Pokemon like Volcarona and Victini. Gastrodon is extremely important to Ground teams for its Water immunity against Pokemon such as Kingdra, Barraskewda, and Volcanion. Nidoking is a potent special wallbreaker that breaks past Pokemon like Corviknight, Thundurus-T, and Tornadus-T with coverage moves in Thunderbolt and Ice Beam. Furthermore, it greatly pressures Aegislash and Kommo-o, which use Steelix as setup fodder.

Scizor.overview:
Bug

Scizor is an essential sweeper for Bug teams due to its solid bulk, Steel typing, and access to recovery in Roost giving it ample setup opportunities with Swords Dance. With a spammable Technician-boosted STAB move in Bullet Punch and useful coverage in Knock Off and Superpower, Scizor is able to greatly threaten common types such as Fairy, Ice, Flying, and Dragon. Scizor's typing and access to reliable recovery in Roost allow it to check Psychic-, Fairy-, and Poison-types that Bug teams can often struggle against, such as Tapu Lele and Nihilego. However, Scizor's coverage is very one-dimensional, causing it to struggle in other matchups such as Water, Electric, and Fire. Furthermore, it is reliant on Bullet Punch for its damage output against faster targets, meaning that it can be easily revenge killed by Pokemon that resist Steel such as Heatran and Urshifu-R. Scizor's exploitable 4x weakness to Fire also limits its ability to switch into defensive Pokemon carrying Fire coverage such as Celesteela and Galarian Slowking.
Scizor.comments:
Other Options

Bug

Life Orb can be used over Metal Coat for more damage at the cost of longevity. Dual Wingbeat is an option that does more neutral damage than Bullet Punch thanks to Technician and hits Amoonguss, Urshifu-R, and Substitute users like Kyurem, while Psycho Cut can cover Poison-types like Toxapex. However, these are usually less useful than Roost or Superpower. A Choice Band set can be used for more initial power, but it makes Scizor much easier to play around once the set is known.

Checks and Counters

Bug

Walls: Physical walls such as Hippowdon, Skarmory, and Toxapex take negligible damage from Scizor's boosted attacks and can get rid of its boosts through phazing moves or Haze.

Steel-resistant Pokemon: Water-, Fire-, Electric-, and Steel-types, including Urshifu-R, Volcanion, Zapdos, and Celesteela, do not fear Scizor's Bullet Punch and threaten Scizor with their powerful attacks or super effective coverage.

Status: Burn from Pokemon like Galarian Corsola and Sableye is crippling for Scizor because it forces it to have multiple Swords Dance boosts to deal significant damage. While Scizor is not reliant on its Speed, paralysis annoys it because it prevents it from safely healing with Roost or getting guaranteed damage versus offensive threats.

Swords Dance (Bug).description:
Swords Dance boosts Scizor's attack, enabling it to OHKO offensive threats like Dragapult and Tapu Koko with Bullet Punch. Knock Off is a utility move that hits Steel- and Psychic-types such as Aegislash, Celesteela, and Slowbro. Roost keeps Scizor healthy, allowing it to set up with Swords Dance and attack multiple times. Superpower is a useful coverage option that hits Steel-types like Ferrothorn and Excadrill. Metal Coat provides the most damage on Bullet Punch without drawbacks. 216 Speed EVs allow Scizor to outspeed Jolly Azumarill, as well as Adamant Bewear and Aegislash.

All Pokemon on Bug teams appreciate Scizor's wallbreaking capability and defensive utility. Volcarona is the primary partner for Scizor, as it can help deal with Steel-types such as Skarmory while also being able to sweep most types, including Poison and Electric, after Scizor breaks through them. In return, Scizor can handle Rock-types such as Tyranitar and Nihilego. Sticky Web support from Araquanid and Shuckle can help make up for Scizor's middling Speed, and Araquanid also provides a switch-in to Fire-types. Stealth Rock and Spikes support from Shuckle, Armaldo, and Golisopod can ease Scizor's wallbreaking by spreading chip damage, and Golisopod additionally provides utility against defensive teams through Knock Off and Taunt. Galvantula and Vikavolt can break Water-types that Scizor struggles against such as Toxapex and Gastrodon. Guts Heracross can threaten Steel-types such as Heatran and Celesteela for Scizor while also threatening Rotom-W. Buzzwole is another cleaner that appreciates Scizor's wallbreaking that can sweep against types like Steel and Fire, matchups where Scizor is less useful.

Shuckle.comments:
Other Options

Rock

Toxic can be run over Knock Off in order to put defensive Pokemon like Slowbro on a timer. Final Gambit can also be run on Shuckle to allow it to set hazards and gain momentum. However, Shuckle can usually generate momentum without Final Gambit, meaning that it often isn't necessary.

Entry Hazards Lead (Bug).description:
Shuckle is the primary entry hazard setter for Bug teams, with its access to Stealth Rock and Sticky Web. Since Shuckle is a utility Pokemon, Encore is used as an insurance against setup Pokemon such as Gyarados and Hawlucha, which can potentially exploit Shuckle. Toxic is used to cripple bulky Pokemon such as Hippowdon. Knock Off can be used as an alternative to cripple Pokemon such as Corviknight and Ferrothorn by removing their item. Mental Herb is used to bypass Taunt users such as Froslass and Sableye in order to allow Shuckle to at least set up either Stealth Rock or Sticky Web; otherwise, it is forced to Struggle under Taunt.

Strong wallbreakers such as Centiskorch and Durant appreciate Stealth Rock, as they can wallbreak more consistently with the chip damage. Centiskorch greatly benefits from Sticky Web, as its Speed is mediocre as well. Durant can outspeed common Choice Scarf users with Sticky Web up on the opposing side of the field, such as Dracozolt and Excadrill. Sticky Web also frees teammates like Galvantula and Vikavolt from running it, allowing them to use more offensive sets.

Entry Hazard Setter (Rock).description:
Thanks to its access to both Sticky Web and Stealth Rock, Shuckle has become the premier entry hazard setter on Rock. Sticky Web allows Shuckle to slow down almost all Pokemon, being especially useful against those that rely on their Speed to be threatening like Choice Scarf Tapu Lele, Spectrier, and Alolan Raichu. It also helps against threats such as Choice Scarf Weavile and Excadrill that can clean Rock-teams late-game. In addition, it improves the matchup against types with poor entry hazard control such as Steel, Ghost, and Fairy. Encore prevents Shuckle from becoming setup fodder by locking foes like Cinderace or Aegislash into a setup move, giving a teammate that is able to deal with them a free switch. Encore can also annoy Defoggers, letting Shuckle's teammates come in safely and setup. Knock Off allows Shuckle to remove items like Heavy-Duty Boots and Leftovers from foes like Tornadus-T and Landorus-T. Mental Herb prevents foes such as Froslass and Spectrier from taunting Shuckle, ensuring it can set up entry hazards at least once. Custap Berry can be used instead to ensure that Shuckle can set up both Stealth Rock and Sticky Web against strong foes without Taunt. Sturdy allows Shuckle to usually set up entry hazards at least once. Shuckle's EVs make it as physically bulky as possible in order to live Urshifu-R's Surging Strikes.

All of Shuckle's offensive teammates benefit from its Stealth Rock and the speed control it provides. Choice Band Tyranitar loves Shuckle's Sticky Web, as it allows Tyranitar to defeat foes it would otherwise lose against, such as Choice Specs Tapu Lele and Choice Specs Gengar. Barbaracle outspeeds and defeats Sand Rush Choice Band Excadrill and Choice Scarf Galarian Darmanitan and Weavile when supported with Sticky Web after a Shell Smash, allowing it to clean types such as Ground and Ice. It also becomes harder to revenge kill because Sticky Web slows down grounded Choice Scarf users. Nihilego is another setup sweeper that appreciates the entry hazards Shuckle sets, allowing Nihilego to devastate Water, Flying, Ground, and Fairy. Specifically, Nihilego can defeat Barraskewda, Swampert, and Corviknight with Shuckle's entry hazards in play. Choice Scarf Terrakion checks threats such as Cinderace, Zeraora, Choice Scarf Excadrill, and Choice Scarf Heatran before Sticky Web has been set. It also acts as a strong revenge-killer, as it removes sweepers such as Bisharp, Tyranitar, and Excadrill, improving the Dark and Steel matchups. Rhyperior provides an Electric immunity and pressures types such as Steel due to its ability to threaten Corviknight and Ferrothorn.

Heracross.overview:
Bug

Heracross is a nice option for Bug-type teams thanks to its high Attack, average Speed, and Fighting typing, which is mandatory for Bug teams to deal with otherwise troublesome Rock- and Steel-types like Tyranitar and Heatran. Further, Heracross has two incredible abilities in Guts and Moxie. The first turns it into a powerful Flame Orb wallbreaker that freely switches into status moves like Will-O-Wisp from Galarian Corsola, while the latter greatly improves its sweeping potential. Its Speed tier is average, but enough for threats like Heatran, Tapu Bulu, and Diggersby and tying with Nidoking. However, Heracross is slower than problematic Pokemon like Tapu Lele and Victini, and Choice Scarf sets are slower than other Choice Scarf users like Latias and Blacephalon. Heracross has to face the competition of Buzzwole, which has better bulk, higher Attack, Beast Boost, and a wider range of coverage options like Ice Punch and Thunder Punch. However, Heracross is faster than Buzzwole and can match Beast Boost with Moxie or use Guts to absorb burns, which cripple Buzzwole.
Heracross.comments:
Other Options

Bug

Heracross has no viable other options.

Checks and Counters

Bug

Fairy-types: Fairy-types like Clefable, Azumarill, and Tapu Fini resist both of Heracross's STAB moves and Knock Off, and they easily KO it with their STAB moves. However, slower Fairy-types must be careful of Facade, especially after a Swords Dance boost.

Bulky Poison-types: Defensive Poison-types like Toxapex, Amoonguss, and Galarian Weezing can easily check Heracross. However, Facade severely dents them and Toxapex fears a 2HKO from Guts Heracross's Earthquake.

Bulky Flying-types: Bulky Flying-types like Skarmory and Zapdos can easily switch in into Choice Scarf Heracross's STAB moves, and Skarmory can also threaten it with Brave Bird or use it to set up entry hazards. However, both of them have problems with Guts Heracross, and Zapdos needs to be wary of Stone Edge from Choice Scarf Heracross.

Revenge Killers: Faster Choice Scarf users like Tapu Lele and Blacephalon can easily revenge kill Choice Scarf Heracross. Furthermore, Close Combat's defense drops leave Heracross more susceptible to being revenge killed by priority moves.

Status: Burns and paralysis from Pokemon like Galarian Corsola and Klefki limit Choice Scarf Heracross's ability to revenge kill and clean.

Wallbreaker (Bug).description:
Guts Heracross is a good mid-game wallbreaker that enables Bug teammates like Scizor to clean late-game. It can also switch into status moves like Will-O-Wisp for teammates like Scizor and Buzzwole. Swords Dance lets Heracross break through staple walls like Toxapex, Skarmory, and Celesteela. Facade takes advantage of Flame Orb to nail some troublesome Fairy- and Poison-types like Hatterene, Amoonguss, and especially Galarian Weezing. Earthquake is an option over Facade to hit Poison-types that resist Close Combat, OHKOing Toxapex after Swords Dance, and Steel-types that are not worried about Close Combat like Aegislash. Knock Off cripples annoying switch-ins like Galarian Corsola and defensive Pokemon that rely solely on Leftovers or Black Sludge for recovery, like defensive Landorus-T, Seismitoad, and Swampert. It can also deal a lot of damage to defensive Pokemon like Slowbro. Maximum Speed investment alongside a Jolly nature allows Heracross to outspeed some key threats like Heatran. An Adamant nature is an alternative to 2HKO Toxapex and Galarian Weezing with Facade after Stealth Rock damage.

Shuckle and Araquanid are great partners for Heracross, as their Sticky Web allows Heracross to outspeed faster threats like Tapu Lele and Victini. Shuckle can also weaken opposing teams with Stealth Rock and Knock Off, while Araquanid can deal with most Fire-types like Volcarona. Scizor and Scolipede are incredible setup sweepers that can handle otherwise problematic Fairy-types like Clefable, Tapu Bulu, and Alolan Ninetales. In return, Heracross can absorb burns directed to Scizor and Scolipede. Volcarona can deal with physical walls such as Skarmory and Celesteela. In return, Heracross takes care of specially defensive Pokemon like Heatran and Rock- and Normal-types like Tyranitar and Blissey. While Buzzwole has the same typing as Heracross, it is also a good partner and an incredible Choice Scarf user for Bug teams. Heracross can weaken Pokemon mid-game, while Beast Boost Buzzwole can be a deadly late-game cleaner and take on Flying-types like Mantine and Landorus-T with Thunder Punch or Ice Punch. Furthermore, they can easily overpower their shared checks like Landorus-T. Galvantula helps against Flying- and Water-types like Skarmory, Mandibuzz, and Toxapex, which are otherwise complicated to face for Bug-type teams. Lastly, Quiver Dance Ribombee can be used to deal with some problematic Dragon-types for Heracross.

Choice Scarf (Bug).description:
Choice Scarf Heracross is a deadly cleaner for Bug-type teams thanks to its high Attack, usable Speed, and Moxie. Megahorn can be spammed against Psychic- and Dark-type Pokemon like Mew, Alakazam, Zarude, and Hydreigon to get some KOs, boosting Heracross's Attack to unstoppable levels. It can also deal a lot of damage against neutral targets like Swampert and Gastrodon. Close Combat is its most consistent STAB attack. Stone Edge is used to nail Flying-types like Moltres and Mantine, which resist both of its STAB moves, and Fire-types such as Cinderace and Volcarona, which otherwise can be very threatening to Bug-type teams. Knock Off cripples item-reliant switch-ins like Galarian Corsola, Landorus-T, and Swampert. It also hits hit Ghost-types like Aegislash and Galarian Corsola. As a fast cleaner, Heracross must be kept from being burned or paralyzed. Maximum Speed investment alongside a Jolly nature allows Heracross to outpace the entire unboosted metagame bar Regieleki.

Shuckle supports Heracross by setting Stealth Rock and Sticky Web, allowing it to outspeed opposing Choice Scarf users such as Blacephalon and Weavile. Araquanid is an alternative Sticky Web setter, and it can improve the matchup against Fire teams and switch into Will-O-Wisp users like Galarian Corsola and Mew. Galvantula can help Heracross in the Water and Flying matchups thanks to Thunder and Energy Ball nailing Heracross walls like Toxapex, Skarmory, Seismitoad, and Gastrodon. Scizor and Volcarona are excellent setup sweepers that can weaken the opposition for Heracross to clean or clean up themselves in Heracross's wake. In return, Heracross can revenge kill Fire- and Rock-type threats like unboosted Volcarona and Tyranitar. In addiction, Scizor can deal with threats like Nihilego with its Bullet Punch, while Volcarona can handle physical walls that Heracross struggles against like Corviknight and Amoonguss. Ribombee is another good teammate that's mainly used for the Dragon matchup, being able to weaken most Dragon-type teams after Quiver Dance.

Stealth Rock (Ice).description:
Piloswine performs the role of a defensive Stealth Rock setter for Ice-type teams. Its decent natural bulk not only allows it to switch into Pokemon like defensive Tyranitar and Life Orb Mimikyu, but it also lets it set up Stealth Rock efficiently. Thanks to its ability in Thick Fat and Eviolite boosting its defenses, it is able to check threatening Fire-type Pokemon like Charizard and Centiskorch for Ice-type teams. As most Fire-type attack users are specially-oriented, Piloswine becomes more useful as a specially defensive Pokemon for Ice teams. With Stealth Rock, Piloswine is able to aid offensive Pokemon like Galarian Darmanitan, Cloyster, and Weavile to score easier KOs. Rock Slide allows it to beat the aforementioned Fire-type Pokemon. Ice Shard allows it to deal with Substitute Hydreigon and it can also be used to pick off weakened Pokemon. Maximum Special Defense investment along with its ability in Thick Fat lets it take Fire-type moves for the team, while Maximum HP investment is used to improve its overall bulk.

Galarian Darmanitan is a fantastic wallbreaker that appreciates Stealth Rock support to wear down defensive Pokemon such as Corviknight and Toxapex for it. It also loves having Piloswine as an option to pivot into with its fast U-turn against a defensive threat. With Flare Blitz, Galarian Darmanitan can beat Steel-type Pokemon like Ferrothorn and Bronzong for Piloswine. Mamoswine is able to utilize an offensive Choice Band set to wallbreak thanks to Piloswine taking up the role of a Stealth Rock setter. Piloswine, however, is susceptible to Knock Off, hence Avalugg acts as a good defensive sponge for it while also acting as a Rapid Spin user for the team. Piloswine's weakness against Water-type Pokemon can be covered by using Water Absorb Lapras with Freeze-Dry, as it can also drastically improve the team's matchup against Water-type teams. Vanilluxe can provide Aurora Veil support to further bolster Piloswine's defensive capabilities.

Defensive Wall (Ghost).description:
Galarian Corsola is a physically defensive wall whose primary purpose on Ghost teams is to set up Stealth Rock and neuter physical attackers with a combination of Will-O-Wisp and Strength Sap, which also is its form of recovery. Night Shade prevents Galarian Corsola from becoming Taunt bait and enables it to chip down foes. Its EVs and Eviolite allow it to be as physically bulky as possible, allowing it to take on threats such as Gyarados. Cursed Body can make Galarian Corsola more difficult to handle, as it can disable coverage to attack it, making it harder to KO.

Jellicent and Sableye appreciate Galarian Corsola's ability to form a strong defensive core with them and whittle down foes for offensive teammates. Jellicent can switch into Water-type attacks for it such as Lapras's Hydro Pump, while Sableye can cripple setup sweepers with Prankster Taunt as well as shut down a boosted Gyarados with Will-O-Wisp. All the offensive Pokemon on Ghost teams appreciate Galarian Corsola's ability to set up Stealth Rock as it makes it easier to break through opposing Pokemon. In return, Galarian Corsola specifically appreciates Mimikyu's ability to take on Dark-type Pokemon that threaten it such as Hydreigon. Thanks to its ability to set Spikes, Froslass forms a good entry hazard stacking core with Galarian Corsola.

Mantine.overview:
Water

Mantine's superb Special Defense and HP stats and access to utility moves such as Defog, Haze, and Roost make it a great wall on Water balance teams, taking on foes such as Volcarona, Hydreigon, and Hatterene. It can form a potent defensive core with Pokemon such as Swampert, Slowking, and Toxapex. Mantine's Flying typing provides a key neutrality to Grass as well as an immunity to Ground; this makes it effective against foes such as Swampert and Choice Scarf Excadrill locked into Earthquake, which its teammates appreciate. It's held back by its its 4x weakness to Electric, making it susceptible to Pokemon such as Victini and Nidoking that carry Electric-type coverage. Mantine's passivity also leads to a tremendous loss of momentum whenever it enters the field. Special wallbreakers such as Choice Specs Tapu Lele and Choice Specs Zapdos take advantage of this, being able to freely switch in on Mantine and release powerful attacks that can severely damage Mantine or its teammates.

Flying

Mantine is a solid Defogger for Flying teams due to its immunity to Water-type moves and access to Haze and Roost. Furthermore, Mantine's high Special Defence allows it to pivot into threats like Blacephalon, Choice Scarf Tapu Fini, and Tapu Lele. Mantine notably is the only Water absorber on Flying, checking offensive Water-types like Urshifu-R and Barraskewda. However, Mantine is extremely passive and is threatened by offensive Pokemon such as Bisharp, Zapdos, and Kyurem. Mantine also faces competition with other Defoggers like Tornadus-T and Corviknight because of its lack of momentum.
Mantine.comments:
Other Options

Water

Toxic can be used over Haze; however, this makes Mantine setup fodder for foes that are either immune to Toxic or use Substitute, such as Spectrier. Mantine can also use Water Veil as an ability, preventing Spectrier from burning it.

Flying

Toxic may be used over Haze on Mantine to reduce its passivity and allows it to deal with Volcanion and opposing Mantine. However, this prevents Mantine from checking setup sweepers like Volcarona and Cinderace. Defog can be dropped for Toxic, but this forces one of Mantine's teammates to run Defog. The other EVs can also be placed in Special Defense along with a Calm nature to better handle special attackers, but the reduced Defense prevents Mantine from safely checking Cinderace and Azumarill.
