Alternatively, allocating only 96 Defense EVs on Mantine and dumping the excess EVs from Defense to Special Defense lets Mantine not only avoid the 2HKO from Choice Band Urshifu-R's Close Combat but also improve its Special Defense.

Checks and Counters

Water

Physical Wallbreakers: Many physical attackers such as Choice Band Rillaboom and Bisharp can easily threaten Mantine with either an OHKO or severe damage due to Mantine's average Defense stat.

Stallbreakers: Many stallbreakers such as Tapu Fini and Mew prevent Mantine from using Defog and restoring health via Roost.

Toxic: Many common walls such as Mandibuzz and Toxapex can Toxic stall Mantine, as it normally doesn't run Toxic itself. Mandibuzz also has access to Taunt, letting it obstruct Mantine from healing off Toxic damage with Roost. Toxic also generally puts Mantine on a timer and prevents it from easily coming in and using Defog.

Flying

Toxic: Toxic hinders Mantine's ability to clear entry hazards and reliably check setup sweepers and Water-types.

Heatran: Mantine has to be wary of swapping into Heatran, as it can inflict Toxic on Mantine, trap it with Magma Storm, and inflict with with Taunt to weaken Mantine or forcibly remove it from the match.

Taunt: Taunt users such as Mew, Tapu Fini, and Galarian Moltres can prevent Mantine from doing its role and can take advantage of it by using it as setup bait.

Setup Sweepers: Although Mantine can deal with most setup sweepers, it notably cannot handle certain physical setup sweepers such as Swords Dance Bisharp and Dragon Dance Dragapult. Physical setup sweepers do not appreciate Scald's burn chance, but this can be circumvented by Substitute.

Water-types: Although Mantine can take Water-type attacks from Urshifu-R and Barraskewda, it cannot meaningfully threaten Water-type Pokemon. Because of this, the opposing team can take advantage of Mantine by pivoting defensive Pokemon such as Toxapex and Slowking on Mantine to force it out, which allows the opponent to pivot the threatening Pokemon in again.

Defensive Pokemon: Mantine cannot threaten defensive Pokemon, as Scald deals negligible damage to Galarian Slowking, Aegislash, and Dragalge, while these Pokemon can cripple Mantine with poison or Toxic.

Support (Water).description:
Set Description

Scald prevents Mantine from being completely passive and prohibits physical attackers such as Dragonite and Dragapult from switching in recklessly, as they risk being burned. Haze prevents Mantine from becoming setup fodder, letting it reliably switch into and deal with setup sweepers like Keldeo, Hatterene, and Volcarona. Roost allows it to consistently wall foes such as Galarian Moltres and Volcarona and reliably clear entry hazards throughout the game. Mantine has enough Speed investment to outpace Adamant Azumarill, allowing it to use Haze before Azumarill attacks it.

Mantine enjoys the presence of Toxapex to take on physical attackers such as Dragapult and Mimikyu. In return, Mantine can check potent special attackers such as Choice Scarf Tapu Lele. Swampert is able to check Electric-types such as Regieleki and Zeraora while also being able to set Stealth Rock. Gastrodon is also an option in lieu of Swampert, as it is able to check prominent threats to Mantine's team such as Tapu Koko while also having reliable recovery. Slowking is able to switch into powerful Psychic-types like Latios and Choice Specs Tapu Lele, which can otherwise overpower Mantine. Urshifu-R and Keldeo also appreciate Mantine switching in on certain Psychic- and Fairy-type special attackers such as Tapu Lele and Hatterene that threaten them. In return, they can defeat foes such as Bisharp and Terrakion, respectively, for Mantine. Wallbreakers such as Crawdaunt and Tapu Fini appreciate Mantine's Defog, which allows them to enter the field safely to defeat walls that pressure Mantine such as Toxapex, Mandibuzz, and Chansey. Mantine also enjoys having Lanturn on its team, as it provides an Electric immunity and Heal Bell support while also taking on Choice Specs Zapdos more reliably and providing slow Volt Switch support to the team. However, it should be noted that Lanturn is primarily seen on stall teams. Setup sweepers such as Calm Mind Tapu Fini, Cloyster, and Suicune welcome Mantine's ability to remove Toxic Spikes, which jeopardize their ability to set up.

Utility (Flying).description:
Haze checks setup sweepers such as Volcarona, Corviknight, and Azumarill. Scald threatens physical attackers with its burn chance. 96 Speed EVs allow Mantine to outspeed Adamant Azumarill.

Landorus-T greatly appreciates Mantine's ability to switch into Water-types such as Urshifu-R. In return, Landorus-T covers for Mantine's Electric weakness by checking Tapu Koko and Zeraora and other threats such as Victini and Jirachi. Celesteela appreciates Mantine's ability to switch into Fire-types such as Blacephalon and Volcarona, and Celesteela repays this by covering for Mantine's weakness to Rock and checking Tyranitar, Alolan Ninetales, and Kyurem. Mantine, Landorus-T, and Celesteela form the defensive backbone of some Flying teams, which allows other teammates to run more offensive sets to pressure the opposing team better. Thundurus-T and Choice Specs Zapdos appreciates Mantine's Defog and removes hindrances such as Volcanion and Toxapex that can cripple Mantine, and the former takes on Electric-type attacks. Galarian Moltres aids in the Steel, Psychic, Poison, and Ghost matchup and can set up on passive defensive Pokemon such as Ferrothorn, Toxapex, and Slowbro, which Mantine struggles with. Galarian Zapdos can remove threats like Kyurem, Bisharp, and Galarian Darmanitan and walls such as Porygon2 and Blissey.

Skarmory.overview:
Steel

Skarmory's typing allows it to easily find itself a spot in Steel teams for providing the much-needed Ground immunity and Fighting neutrality. Skarmory has access to Spikes, making it the primary setter for its team while freeing up Ferrothorn to run more utility options such as Thunder Wave and Stealth Rock. Its high Defense stat and great typing allow Skarmory to check various physically offensive Pokemon such as Garchomp, Landorus-T, and Urshifu-R with the help of Roost, Rocky Helmet, and Toxic. Moreover, having access to Roost and Toxic sets Skarmory apart from its competitors in Celesteela and Corviknight. Skarmory is an easy target for Electric-types such as Zapdos and Zeraora, which can grab momentum against Skarmory with their respective coverage. Furthermore, Skarmory can be trapped and eliminated by Magnezone, which enables a safer win route for Bulk Up Zeraora, and it is also vulnerable to Fire-type attacks from Pokemon such as Victini, Blacephalon, and Volcarona, which all pose a threat to it. Skarmory's Special Defense is low, making it weak to common special attackers in the tier such as Blacephalon, Dragapult, Hydreigon, and Kyurem. Being unable to touch any Ghost-type Pokemon outside of Toxic causes Skarmory to lose momentum heavily, especially against Substitute users such as non-Choice Specs Aegislash, Dragapult, and Spectrier, which all force it out.

Flying

Often appearing on balance teams, Skarmory's incredible Defense stat allows it to check many physical attackers such as Melmetal and Bisharp for its teammates. Due to its excellent typing, Skarmory can provide a key neutrality to Ice-type attacks, allowing it to check powerful Ice-types such as Mamoswine and Weavile. Skarmory's access to Spikes, Whirlwind, and Roost allows it to carve out a niche for itself on Flying teams. As a result of its low HP and Special Defense, Skarmory is unable to tank resisted hits from special attackers such as Choice Specs Kyurem and Choice Specs Tapu Lele and can be worn down by walls using special attacking moves like Scald from Toxapex. Skarmory faces competition from Corviknight and Celesteela, as they both share the same typing. Corviknight and Celesteela can tank both physical and special attacks, while Skarmory is relegated to tanking physical attacks.
Skarmory.comments:
Other Options

Steel

In offensive structures, using Skarmory as a suicide lead with both Spikes and Stealth Rock paired with a Custap Berry allows it to set up entry hazards for its offensive teammates at the beginning of the game and apply pressure more easily.

Flying

224 HP EVs allow Skarmory to always be at full HP after two turns of Leftovers recovery after Stealth Rock damage, thus enabling it to use Sturdy. However, this spread reduces Skarmory's overall physical bulk and makes it easier to KO.

Checks and Counters

Steel

Ghost-types: Skarmory's only attacking move is Body Press, which is blocked by every Ghost-type Pokemon in the metagame and causes Skarmory to be forced out, especially if it's lacking Whirlwind.

Electric-types: Electric-types can all force out Skarmory with their respective STAB moves. Zapdos and Rotom-W can remove Spikes with Defog, while Magnezone threatens Skarmory with trapping. However, Magnezone must be careful to not take a hit from Body Press on the switch.

Fire-types: Skarmory has no way of handling offensive Fire-types such as Blacephalon, Volcarona, and Heatran, and these Pokemon can easily take advantage of Skarmory. However, the former two need to be careful about Toxic and the latter must be aware of Body Press.

Special Attackers: Special attackers such as Hydreigon, Kyurem, Dragapult, Gengar, and Spectrier can easily break through Skarmory due to its low Special Defense.

Taunt: Fast Taunt users such as Tornadus-T, Tapu Fini, and Heatran can block Skarmory from using Spikes, Whirlwind, and Roost.

Flying

Hatterene: While preventing Skarmory from setting Spikes with Magic Bounce, Hatterene can also use Skarmory as setup fodder.

Special Attackers: Due to Skarmory's low HP and Special Defense, it is 2HKOed from resisted special attacks from foes such as Choice Specs Tapu Lele.

Taunt: Foes such as Mandibuzz and Bulk Up Corviknight are able to inflict Taunt on Skarmory, preventing it from not only setting Spikes but also healing itself via Roost.

Physically Defensive (Steel).description:
Skarmory serves as the primary Spikes setter for its team, allowing offensive teammates such as Bisharp and Excadrill to wallbreak more consistently throughout the game. Body Press synergizes well with Skarmory's bulk and is especially helpful in the mirror matchup against Pokemon such as Bisharp, Ferrothorn, Melmetal, and Heatran on the switch, as well against Dark-types such as Weavile, Tyranitar, and Hydreigon. Roost helps Skarmory to stay healthy throughout the match against foes such as Urshifu-R, Excadrill, and Tyranitar. Whirlwind is used to prevent setup from Pokemon such as Garchomp and Dragapult while also generating passive chip damage if Spikes were set beforehand. Toxic can be used over Whirlwind to cripple Pokemon such as Mandibuzz and Mantine. Rocky Helmet complements Skarmory's physical bulk and typing excellently, as contact move users such as Urshifu-R and Weavile as well as U-turn and Flip Turn users such as Landorus-T, Scizor, Swampert, and Barraskewda will all be worn down by it. Sturdy allows Skarmory to set Spikes or use Toxic on a foe that can knock it out from full health if necessary. Furthermore, Sturdy allows Skarmory to deal damage against troublesome Pokemon that threaten Steel teams, such as Hydreigon. An Impish nature and maximum HP and Defense investment make Skarmory as tanky as possible against the aforementioned physical threats such as Urshifu-R, Excadrill, and Landorus-T.

Having access to Spikes makes Skarmory a valuable teammate, as it allows its offensive teammates such as Excadrill, Aegislash, Melmetal, and Bisharp to have an easier time against common walls such as Toxapex, Porygon2, and Ferrothorn. Ferrothorn is one of the best teammates for Skarmory, as the duo form an effective entry hazard-stacking core with Ferrothorn's Stealth Rock. Furthermore, Skarmory can make up for Ferrothorn's weakness to Fighting, while Ferrothorn takes care of Electric-types such as Tapu Koko and Rotom-W for Skarmory and provides a resistance to Water. Heatran provides the much-needed Fire immunity against Pokemon like Blacephalon and Hydreigon, while Skarmory can take on Ground-type attacks such as Earthquake from Garchomp and Excadrill. Furthermore, Heatran's common moves in Toxic and Magma Storm can deal immense chip damage when combined with Skarmory's Spikes. Excadrill takes care of Electric-types such as Tapu Koko and Zeraora if it is holding a Choice Scarf and can remove Stealth Rock with Rapid Spin to preserve Skarmory's Sturdy. Aegislash makes a good partner for Skarmory, as it relieves the pressure from Skarmory to handle Fighting-type attacks. This is especially important against Choice-locked foes such as Urshifu-R, which will have to avoid being heavily punished by Skarmory's Rocky Helmet. Furthermore, Aegislash helps greatly against Psychic-types such as Hatterene and Tapu Lele, which Skarmory generally struggle against. Bisharp's ability in Defiant also deters Defog from Pokemon such as Mantine and Zapdos, and its typing allows it to shine against Psychic- and Ghost-types such as Galarian Slowking, Slowking, Galarian Corsola, and Spectrier.

Defensive Spikes (Flying).description:
Toxic allows Skarmory to punish opposing Defoggers such as Rotom-W and Heavy-Duty Boots Zapdos as they try to switch into it. Whirlwind can be used over it to phaze opposing setup sweepers such as Bisharp and Dragon Dance Dragapult. In conjunction with Skarmory's bulk it can be used to shuffle opposing teams, slowly damaging them via Spikes. Body Press uses Skarmory's enormous Defense stat to hit threats such as Galarian Darmanitan and Tyranitar. Roost provides Skarmory with reliable recovery, allowing it to preserve Sturdy as well as consistently providing an answer to foes such as Cloyster and Excadrill. Rocky Helmet punishes physical attackers as well as pivots that use Flip Turn and U-turn by taking a chunk of their HP. Leftovers allows Skarmory to gain passive recovery, which it in turn gives it more chances to use its ability Sturdy. Sturdy is Skarmory's best ability, as it can allow Skarmory to survive attacks from foes such as Heliolisk and Volcarona when at full HP, and it can proceed to OHKO the former with Body Press. Maximum HP and Defense investment with a Bold nature allows Skarmory to be as bulky as possible, as well as boosting the power of Body Press.

Mantine is an excellent teammate for Skarmory, as its superb Special Defense allows it to wall special attackers such as Volcarona, Choice Scarf Blacephalon, and Hydreigon. In return, Skarmory is able to handle foes like Dragonite and Dragapult. Skarmory appreciates the presence of Landorus-T to OHKO threats such as Tapu Koko and Zapdos. Landorus-T can also switch in on foes such as Zapdos after it has been Choice-locked into Thunderbolt. Skarmory then reciprocates this by acting as a switch-in to physical attackers such as Mamoswine that would otherwise OHKO Landorus-T with Icicle Crash. Defensive Zapdos can provide a key neutrality to Electric-type attacks as well as act as a special wall, taking attacks from foes such as Tapu Koko under Electric Terrain. Moreover, it can run a Toxic + Substitute set to wear down opposing walls such as Mandibuzz that Skarmory would find hard to deal with. Skarmory can then assist Zapdos by taking on potent physical attackers such as Swords Dance Terrakion that Zapdos would otherwise fall to. Zapdos can also run a Choice Specs set that appreciates Skarmory's ability to wear down foes such as Slowking with Spikes. Teammates such as Choice Band Galarian Zapdos and Galarian Moltres appreciate the presence of Spikes on the field, with the former potentially OHKOing foes such as Slowbro, Slowking, and Mew and the latter becoming a much more potent sweeper, being able to guarantee an OHKO on foes such as Slowking. In return, Galarian Zapdos is able to prevent foes from removing Spikes via Defog carelessly due to Defiant. Galarian Moltres is able to check the fearsome Spectrier that would otherwise OHKO Skarmory after it has been inflicted with a status condition. Thundurus-T and Dragonite are also good teammates for Skarmory, as both are helped by Spikes chipping away at their respective checks, and the former can absorb Electric-type attacks for it. Knock Off users such as Tornadus-T allow teammates to take advantage of Skarmory's entry hazards, as it can force foes that normally run Heavy-Duty Boots such as Victini and Cinderace to switchin less often. Moreover, Tornadus-T can use Taunt on opposing Defog users such as Mantine and Corviknight to prevent them from ridding the field of Skarmory's Spikes.

Kingdra.comments:
Other Options

Water

Life Orb lets Kingdra switch moves, but it comes with the drawbacks of less power and recoil. Flip Turn allows Kingdra to take advantage of common switch-ins like Toxapex, pivoting to teammates that can handle it like Barraskewda. Ice Beam is an option over Hurricane so that Kingdra can hit Flying-types like Galarian Moltres super effectively. However, it is less powerful than Hurricane against other targets. Kingdra can also run a Timid nature to outpace Regieleki, Choice Scarf Weavile, and Adamant Dragon Dance Dragapult at +1. However, if Kingdra is not running a Modest nature, it loses the ability to potentially 2HKO Ferrothorn under rain. Mystic Water and Dragon Fang are also options to allow Kingdra to switch moves and hit hard, and unlike Life Orb they don't reveal its item.

Swift Swim (Water).description:
Kingdra is a decent Swift Swim user for Water teams utilizing rain, as it helps in various matchups such as Electric, Grass, and especially Dragon. Draco Meteor threatens bulky walls such as Dragalge and Amoonguss. Dragon Pulse is used to deal with foes that resist Water such as Kyurem, as well as other foes like Galarian Slowking. Hydro Pump allows Kingdra to 3HKO Galarian Slowking and gives it a chance to 2HKO Ferrothron under rain. Hurricane can be run over Hydro Pump to let Kingdra hit Grass-types such as Tapu Bulu super effectively. Maximum Speed investment allows Kingdra to outspeed threats like Choice Scarf Latios and Choice Scarf Thundurus-T.

As Kingdra relies on Swift Swim to do its job, Pelipper is an amazing teammate for it. If Kingdra opts to run Hurricane, Pelipper can run a defensive set with Heavy-Duty Boots rather than a Choice Specs set. Barraskewda can break down walls like Galarian Slowking, as well as threats such as Regieleki and Alolan Raichu in Electric Terrain when rain is active. Urshifu-R is also an option, as it can pressure shared checks like Mantine and Galarian Moltres. It also ravages Ferrothorn and Kyurem, foes that would otherwise pose a huge threat to the team. Eject Button Toxapex supports Kingdra by crippling foes like Porygon2 and Chansey with Toxic and Knock Off. It also walls revenge killers such as Choice Scarf Dragapult. Slowking allows Kingdra to enter the field safely through Teleport, as well as providing Future Sight support to help wear down foes like Galarian Slowking. Swampert provides Stealth Rock support and can pivot Kingdra in via Flip Turn. It can also phaze Substitute Kyurem by using Roar. Late-game sweepers such as Crawdaunt, Cloyster, and Keldeo can be run alongside Kingdra, as they appreciate the holes Kingdra can punch in many teams. They also are able to deal with foes such as Chansey and Ferrothorn, which give Kingdra trouble. Volcanion is also an excellent teammate, as it can switch into and defeat Fairy-types like Tapu Fini, as well as Grass-types such as Ferrothorn.

Physically Defensive.description:
Porygon2 is a great physically defensive option available to Normal teams with the ability to utilize Teleport and check Dragon Dance Dragapult, Mimikyu, and Jirachi, which would all otherwise prove very threatening for Normal. Recover provides Porygon2 with a reliable form of healing for it to continually switch into attacks from Pokemon such as Choice Scarf Excadrill and Mimikyu. Foul Play acts both as a countermeasure for Pokemon like Scizor and Azumarill that would otherwise use Porygon2 as setup bait and as an attacking move to hit other powerful physical threats like Alolan Marowak and Excadrill. Ice Beam gives Porygon2 good coverage to deal with Dragon threats like Hydreigon and Noivern more easily as well as certain other offensive threats like Diggersby and Hawlucha. Toxic allows Porygon2 to wear down defensive Pokemon like Mandibuzz and Gastrodon that may otherwise attempt to switch in. Teleport is another option to be considered, as it allows Porygon2 to bring in frail offensive Normal-type threats like Diggersby, Heliolisk, and Indeedee-M safely and create momentum. Discharge can be an option to run over Toxic as good coverage for hitting Flying- and Water-type threats like Corviknight and Pelipper with a sizable chance to paralyze notable threats for Normal teams such as Calm Mind Keldeo and Bulk Up Urshifu-R, which would otherwise use Porygon2 as setup fodder. Trace is generally the preferred ability due to the potential of copying abilities like Natural Cure from Chansey, Regenerator from Toxapex and Amoonguss, and Intimidate from Krookodile, all of which increase Porygon2's survivability. Maximum investment in HP and Defense with a Bold nature is used to have Porygon2 perform its best as a physical wall against threats like Excadrill and Scizor.

Most if not all Pokemon on Normal appreciate Porygon2's ability to deal with physical threats. Blissey in particular forms an excellent defensive core with Porygon2 due to being especially weak to offensive physical threats. Porygon2 in return appreciates Blissey's role as a special wall to help deal with strong special threats that itself cannot hold off like Kingdra in rain and Volcarona. If Porygon2 is running Teleport, frail offensive threats like Diggersby and Indeedee-M appreciate its ability to bring them in safely without leaving them open to attacks and status moves. Braviary helps Porygon2 deal with hard-hitting threats that have Fighting-type coverage like Heracross and Rillaboom. Porygon2 is especially susceptible to all forms of entry hazards, particularly Toxic Spikes, due to their ability to quickly wear down Porygon2 and reduce its ability of switching into attacks reliably. As a result, Porygon2 along with the entire Normal team appreciates Braviary's ability of keeping hazards off through the use of Defog. Ditto makes for a good partner due to its ability to punish offensive setup sweepers that may use Porygon2 as setup fodder like Belly Drum Azumarill, Swords Dance Excadrill, and Bulk Up Urshifu-S. Ditto and Porygon2 also work well together due to their ability to PP stall Poison and Water teams by copying Regenerator from Pokemon such as Toxapex and Amoonguss. Heliolisk provides Porygon2 with an easier time against Water due to its great ability in Dry Skin for absorbing powerful Water-type attacks from wallbreakers like Dracovish. Bewear appreciates Porygon2's ability to mitigate its low Speed by paralyzing faster Pokemon like Hydreigon and Kyurem with Discharge. Porygon2 in return gains a partner to help deal with Steel- types like Corviknight and Ferrothorn that it would otherwise have a hard time dealing with.

Blissey.overview:
Normal

Blissey's amazing bulk, role of status absorber thanks to Natural Cure, and utility moves such as Stealth Rock and Soft-Boiled in conjunction with Heavy-Duty Boots all make it one of Monotype's best walls. Teleport makes Blissey one of the best defensive pivots in the metagame and synergizes well with strong wallbreakers like Diggersby. Blissey forms one of the most potent defensive cores in Monotype with Braviary and Porygon2. However, due to Blissey's near nonexistent offensive presence, it is extremely susceptible to offensive setup users like Dragapult and Bisharp. Stallbreakers also easily take advantage of it and Knock Off users like Mew severely threaten it. Blissey also fails to successfully hold its own against other defensive Pokemon like Slowbro and Toxapex.
Blissey.comments:
Other Options

Normal

Blissey can opt to run Toxic, Thunder Wave, or Heal Bell in lieu of Stealth Rock. However, its teammates generally appreciate Stealth Rock more.

Checks and Counters

Normal

Setup Sweepers: Due to Blissey's passivity, setup sweepers, especially ones with reliable recovery such as Dragapult and Scizor, comfortably set up on it.

Stallbreakers: As Blissey heavily relies on its utility moves, stallbreakers such as Mew, Zarude, and Mandibuzz can completely shut it down with Taunt, even preventing it from bringing in a teammate with Teleport.

Wallbreakers: While Blissey's amazing bulk allows it to comfortably deal with a majority of both physical and special threats, powerful wallbreakers like Choice Band Victini, Galarian Darmanitan, and Crawdaunt have little to no trouble breaking through it.

Defensive (Normal).description:
Stealth Rock eases the path for Blissey's offensive teammates while also heavily chipping down threats like Galarian Darmanitan and Choice Band Victini. Seismic Toss prevents Blissey from being totally passive, allowing it to deal notable damage to offensive Pokemon like Tapu Koko and Taunt users such as Mew. Soft-Boiled provides reliable recovery, allowing Blissey to act as a reliable wall against foes like Hydreigon and Nidoking throughout the game. Teleport makes it a great defensive pivot, safely bringing in its offensive teammates like Diggersby and Heliolisk.

All of Blissey's teammates appreciate its ability to absorb status conditions while safely bringing them into the field with Teleport. Porygon2 and Braviary form a potent defensive core with Blissey. Porygon2 can reliably switch into physical attacks from the likes of Landorus-T while also forming a great Teleport core with Blissey, while Braviary provides Defog support for the team and a neutrality to Fighting-type attacks, switching in against foes such as Choice Scarf Heracross. Diggersby is a great wallbreaker, taking care of opposing walls like Ferrothorn and Toxapex that Blissey fails to do much against, while Heliolisk aids greatly in the Water- and Flying-type matchups. Obstagoon provides a Psychic immunity while also threatening Ghost-type Pokemon like Blacephalon and Aegislash, which wall Blissey completely. Ditto deals with setup sweepers such as Volcarona and Aegislash that get the better of Blissey's passivity. Indeedee aids greatly in the Fighting-type matchup and provides a great special wallbreaker for Normal-type teams.

Suicune.overview:
Water

Sporting great defensive stats, amazing defensive typing, and decent natural Speed, Suicune is able to wall and stall many Pokemon in Monotype such as Slowking and Tapu Lele. Thanks to its ability in Pressure, Calm Mind, and its natural bulk, Suicune can stall out menacing walls such as Celesteela, Ferrothorn, and Toxapex one-on-one. It is also able to effectively stall out menacing attacks like Tapu Bulu's Horn Leech with Pressure. Due to its lack of reliable recovery, Suicune is extremely vulnerable to entry hazards, status, and other chip damage leaving it unable to reliably switch into attacks. In addition, having Scald as its only offensive move makes it vulnerable to Water-immune Pokemon such as Gastrodon and Mantine. Furthermore, Suicune's heavy reliance on Leftovers makes it extremely vulnerable to Knock Off.
Suicune.comments:
Other Options

Water

Rest and Sleep Talk can be used over Protect + Substitute in order to fully recover HP, but that leaves Suicune as setup bait and relies on RNG to select the ideal moves. This set also makes Suicune worse at PP stalling.

Checks and Counters

Water

Water-types: Specially defensive Water-type Pokemon easily wall Scald and force Suicune to switch. Toxapex is particularly a threat due to its access to Haze and reliable recovery.

Electric-types: Pokemon such as Regieleki and Alolan Raichu can spam Thunderbolt and Rising Voltage against Suicune, but it can threaten them from behind a Substitute, especially if it has used Calm Mind.

Chip Damage: Any chip damage, like from damaging entry hazards and status conditions, reduces Suicune's ability to wall its foes. Toxic Spikes deserves a special mention, as it automatically puts Suicune on a timer.

Grass-types: Grass-types resisting Scald makes them extremely hard to break past. Tapu Bulu deserves a special mention for its ability to set up a Substitute and proceed to use Suicune as setup fodder. Rillaboom's Grassy Glide will not only OHKO Suicune but decimate any Water team. However, both Rillaboom and Tapu Bulu fear Scald burns, making opponents reluctant to switch them in.

Haze Users and Phazing: Moves such as Haze and Whirlwind make it difficult for Suicune to set up for a late-game sweep.

Stallbreakers: Common Taunt users like Cobalion and Keldeo can lock Suicune into Scald, which is only threatening after it has used Calm Mind. Suicune is also vulnerable to Encore, which allows opposing physical attackers to come in and revenge kill it without the risk of being burned by Scald.

Water-immune Pokemon: Due to Scald being its only offensive move, Suicune is unable to damage Water-immune pokemon such as Cradily and Mantine. However, Suicune is able to annoy them through Pressure stalling.

Calm Mind + Substitute (Water).description:
Calm Mind allows Suicune to both sweep and take on special attackers like Tornadus-T while being able to fire back with Scald; Scald allows Suicune to spread burns, which threaten opposing physical attackers such as Dragonite and Scizor coming in. Protect adds passive recovery via Leftovers and works with Substitute and Pressure to PP stall foes; Protect also allows Suicune to scout Choice-locked Pokemon such as Rillaboom, Tapu Lele, and Latios. Substitute can also be used to block status conditions such as poison and burn that would nullify Suicune's passive recovery and therefore prevent it from effectively PP stalling. It can create a Substitute for free on Pokemon like defensive Celesteela. Suicune's HP investment allows it to form a Substitute with 101 HP, which doesn't break after one Night Shade or Seismic Toss from Galarian Corsola or Blissey.

Toxapex is able to provide Toxic Spikes support, which helps Suicune stall out its foes. In addition, it can stop setup sweepers like Bisharp with Haze. Swampert provides an Electric immunity to the team and phazes setup sweepers such as Dragonite and Dragapult with Roar. Furthermore, Swampert can set Stealth Rock, which helps Suicune wear down opposing teams. Urshifu-R is good to break past many potential checks to Suicune, such as Water-immune Pokemon such as Cradily, Seismitoad, and Mantine, with Close Combat and Thunder Punch. Tapu Fini provides a Dragon immunity while also setting up Misty Terrain, which prevents Suicune from becoming statused, and threatening Suicune's Dragon-type checks like Latios and Hydreigon. In turn, Suicune can assist Tapu Fini by spreading burns and PP stalling its checks such as Skuntank. Choice Scarf Tapu Fini also helps to weaken foes with Trick and Knock Off. Mantine not only removes hazards like Toxic Spikes, but also offers a Ground immunity. In addition, it provides a key neutrality to Grass. Mantine also has Haze to stifle setup Pokemon like Belly Drum Azumarill and Volcarona. Slowking assists Suicune and the team by filling the role of a specially defensive pivot, bringing in Suicune with ease and countering Pokemon it struggles against such as Toxapex and Toxicroak. Teammates with Heal Bell like Vaporeon help with Suicune's vulnerability to status chip damage.

Tyranitar.overview:
Dark

Tyranitar easily finds itself a spot on Dark teams thanks to its access to Stealth Rock. Setting sand enhances its natural bulk, allowing Tyranitar to act as a special sponge against threats such as Dragapult, Galarian Moltres, Zapdos, and Kyurem. It also comes with a variety of utility options; Thunder Wave is great against faster threats such as Dragapult and Weavile, while Toxic helps when facing common walls Tyranitar struggles against, such as Swampert. Its typing allows it to check Flying- and Fire-types, most notably Togekiss, Galarian Moltres, Zapdos, Heatran, Blacephalon, and Victini. However, despite being a solid special tank, Tyranitar's typing stacks up its team's Fighting weakness while also creating weaknesses to common types such as Water and Ground. Due to its mediocre Speed, Tyranitar is outsped by the vast majority of the metagame, giving foes a chance to do serious damage. Tyranitar also lacks any form of recovery and is weak to residual damage.
Tyranitar.comments:
Other Options

Dark

Tyranitar has no other options.

Rock

Tyranitar can viably run a set with Dragon Dance over Fire Punch, though Corviknight, Celesteela, and Skarmory can easily exploit this set. In addition, Tyranitar is a better wallbreaker than sweeper for Rock teams because it can pave the way for other sweepers like Barbaracle to sweep. It can also run a special set using Dark Pulse, Earth Power, Fire Blast, and Ice Beam to surprise foes such as Skarmory. However, this set isn't very good due to Tyranitar's mediocre Special Attack stat, as well as Nihilego taking care of Special special Tyranitar's targets, anyway.

Checks and Counters

Dark

Physical Walls: Physical walls such as Skarmory and Toxapex can comfortably take on Tyranitar and threaten it with moves like Body Press and Scald, respectively.

Revenge Killers: Due to its mediocre Speed, Tyranitar is easily revenge killed by many Pokemon such as Urshifu-R, Terrakion, Keldeo, Zeraora, Garchomp, and Tapu Bulu.

Status: Tyranitar doesn't appreciate status conditions like Toxic and burn, as they negate its Leftovers and limit its overall longevity in the field.

Specially Defensive (Dark).description:
Stealth Rock allows Tyranitar's offensive teammates such as Zarude, Weavile, and Hydreigon to break through teams more consistently. Rock Blast is its preferred STAB move, allowing Tyranitar to take on Substitute Kyurem and Galarian Moltres more reliably. Thunder Wave can be used to cripple faster threats such as Dragapult, while Toxic cripples Pokemon Tyranitar cannot beat reliably such as Swampert. Heavy Slam allows Tyranitar to take on Tapu Lele and the uncommon Hatterene. Sand Stream sets sand, which boosts Tyranitar's Special Defense, allowing it to tank hits from foes such as Zapdos and Kyurem better.

Zarude makes a phenomenal partner for Tyranitar, as it can cover two of Tyranitar's most crucial weaknesses: Ground- and Water-types such as Swampert, Hippowdon, and Toxapex. In return, Tyranitar can deal with Flying-types such as Galarian Moltres and Zapdos. Weavile enhances the matchup against Dragon-types such as Dragapult and Garchomp, while Tyranitar handles Kyurem for Weavile. Mandibuzz forms a solid defensive backbone with Tyranitar for Dark teams. As it takes neutral damage from Bug- and Fighting-type attacks, Mandibuzz can take on such attacks directed at Tyranitar, while Tyranitar can comfortably tank BoltBeam coverage with its excellent special bulk. Moreover, Mandibuzz provides Toxic and Defog; the former allows Tyranitar to run Thunder Wave freely and the latter prevents entry hazards from damaging Tyranitar. Hydreigon is a fantastic wallbreaker that can handle Steel-types such as Ferrothorn and Skarmory, as well as directly switching into Water- and Grass-type moves for Tyranitar. Mandibuzz and Hydreigon also provide Ground immunities for Tyranitar. Bisharp breaks past Fairy-types such as Clefable and Klefki and threatens Defog users such as Mantine and Zapdos due to Defiant, helping keep Stealth Rock up. Drapion aids Tyranitar with checking Fairy-types such as Tapu Lele and Hatterene. Drapion also has Toxic Spikes, which can be used to cripple types without proper hazard removal options such as Grass, Dragon, and Fairy.

Choice Band (Rock).description:
A fierce wallbreaker, Tyranitar plays an important role on Rock teams in beating defensive foes such as Corviknight, Slowbro, and Ferrothorn. Stone Edge is used for its high Base Power and effectiveness against Flying teams. It's also the safest move to use against Poison, Flying, and Electric teams, as their defensive cores cannot easily switch into it. Despite having less power, Crunch is more reliable than Stone Edge and can threaten many Ghost- and Psychic-type walls, such as Galarian Corsola and Slowbro, as well as Dragapult and Latios. Earthquake allows Tyranitar to hit Steel- and Electric-types such as Heatran and Tapu Koko, as well as Toxapex. In conjunction with Earthquake, Fire Punch pressures Steel-type teams and prevents Tapu Bulu, Zarude, and Ferrothorn from coming in on Tyranitar, gaining momentum with their setup or utility moves. The given EV spread allows Tyranitar to survive Choice Specs Tapu Lele's Moonblast while still outpacing Adamant Azumarill.

All of Tyranitar's teammates appreciate its ability to set sand. Shuckle can slow foes down with Sticky Web and chip them via Stealth Rock, both of which let Tyranitar break through teams more easily. Terrakion and Tyranitar form a deadly wallbreaking core together, with Terrakion dealing with foes such as Bisharp and Excadrill for Tyranitar, and Tyranitar handling Ghost-types and Psychic-types such as Galarian Corsola, Dragapult, and Slowbro. Nihilego is an excellent partner due to it taking on Corviknight and Urshifu-R, which beat Tyranitar. In return, Tyranitar is able to take care of Slowking and Galarian Slowking, as well as Steel-types such as Klefki and Aegislash, all of which wall Nihilego. Rhyperior can gang up on Steel- and Flying-types with Tyranitar and provide an Electric immunity. Barbaracle appreciates Tyranitar getting rid of foes such as Slowking, Slowbro, and Aegislash, which Barbaracle has trouble defeating. Coalossal is a decent partner for Tyranitar, as it can not only chip foes via Spikes, but also use Rapid Spin to clear entry hazards, which prevent Tyranitar from being as effective. Furthermore, it can burn foes like Scizor and Melmetal with Flame Body.

Nasty Plot (Grass).description:
Celebi is a great choice for Grass teams due to its bulk, access to Nasty Plot, and Psychic typing, allowing it to threaten Poison- and Fighting-types that give its teammates trouble like Toxapex and Cobalion. Nasty Plot turns Celebi into a dangerous sweeper, that can dismantle troubling matchups such as Poison and Steel. Giga Drain allows it to have passive recovery and mitigates Life Orb's recoil damage. Psychic helps greatly in the Poison- and the Fighting-type matchup, as Celebi can take care of Toxapex and Kommo-o with it. Earth Power is used to hit most Steel- and Poison-types such as Excadrill and Skuntank. Weather Ball can be used over Earth Power on sun teams to hit Corviknight and Ferrothorn when sun is active. Celebi should try to come in on passive attacks such as Toxapex's Scald, on a predicted switch, via U-turn, or after a teammate faints. Nasty Plot should be used on Pokemon it can threaten out such as Toxapex and Keldeo. Having 252 Special Attack EVs and Life Orb allows Celebi to be as powerful as possible, and 252 Speed EVs with a Timid nature allow it to outpace Lucario and Speed tie with Jirachi.

Celebi loves Stealth Rock support from Ferrothorn, as it makes it easier for Celebi to sweep mid- to late-game and can swap into faster Poison-type Pokemon like Gengar. Celebi also appreciates Ferrothorn's Steel typing to take physical attacks or Ice-type attacks from Pokemon like Mamoswine and Alolan Ninetales. Appletun is another key member that forms a defensive core with Ferrothorn and can come in on Fire-type attacks thanks to its Dragon typing and Thick Fat. Choice Scarf Virizion provides great speed control and can OHKO Alolan Ninetales with Smart Strike, use its Fighting-type STAB moves greatly in the Dark-type matchup to take care of Hydreigon and Bisharp, and handle Choice Scarf Charizard with Stone Edge. Virizion can also serve on sun teams as a secondary Sunny Day setter if Whimsicott is eliminated. Rotom-C is another good teammate to help take care of Flying-types such as Togekiss and can use Nasty Plot, Substitute, and Dark Pulse to greatly help out in the Ghost-type matchup. Whimsicott is another good member, especially if Celebi is running Weather Ball, thanks to its Prankster-boosted Sunny Day, allowing Celebi to sweep Steel teams with Weather Ball. Whimsicott is also able to switch into Dragon-type attacks for Celebi and hit back with Moonblast. Shiftry is good to pair with Celebi because it helps greatly with the Psychic- and Ghost-type matchup, using its STAB attacks to take care of troubling Pokemon like Indeedee and Chandelure. In return, Celebi takes care of threats to Shiftry such as Lucario and Toxapex. Venusaur is a nice partner because it can help greatly with Fairy-types such as Togekiss as well as threats to Celebi like Bisharp and Aegislash with Weather Ball when sun is active.

Swampert.overview:
Water

Providing a key immunity to Electric-type moves as well as walling Pokemon such as Regieleki, defensive Zapdos, and Zeraora, Swampert is a good addition to any Water team. In addition, Swampert has access to a wide variety of utility moves, including Stealth Rock and Roar. It is also able to take hits in order to reliably set Stealth Rock multiple times during a battle. Its Water / Ground typing may turn out to be its eventual downfall, as Swampert is 4x weak to Grass-type attacks from Rillaboom, Tapu Koko, and Thundurus-T. Swampert suffers from constantly tanking hits from foes due to having no reliable recovery and therefore has little longevity. This prevents it from switching in and out of battle constantly, making Defog users a nuisance. Swampert can generate momentum with Flip Turn, preventing it from becoming passive.
Swampert.comments:
Other Options

Water

A set with Rindo Berry and Mirror Coat is able to catch threats such as Alolan Raichu, Tapu Koko, and Thundurus-T off guard. However, it severely reduces Swampert's HP, making it harder to bring it onto the field. Furthermore, this set can be scouted for with any chip damage. Toxic can be run over Roar in order to put bulkier walls such as Mantine and Mandibuzz on a timer; however, this prevents Swampert from phazing setup sweepers such as Hydreigon.

Checks and Counters

Water

Bulky Water-types: Pokemon such as Mantine and Rotom-W are immune or resistant to both of Swampert's offensive moves, in addition to having the ability to get rid of Stealth Rock via Defog. Mantine is particularly dangerous, as Swampert is also unable to use Flip Turn against it due to its Water Absorb ability.

Physical Walls: Bulky foes such as Celesteela and Mandibuzz can Toxic stall Swampert while being immune to Earthquake.

Grass-types: Due to having a 4x weakness to the type, Grass-type coverage can easily break past Swampert.

Knock Off: Knock Off can be used on Swampert to remove Leftovers, meaning it has no way to reliably recover HP. This in turn diminishes Swampert's ability to act as wall somewhat effectively and prevents it from consistently being able to set up Stealth Rock multiple times during a battle.

Powerful Wallbreakers: Wallbreakers such as Choice Specs Zapdos, Choice Specs Keldeo, and Nidoking pose an immense threat to Swampert due to its lack of reliable recovery.

Status: Like most walls, status conditions such as burn and poison severely hinder Swampert's ability to wall its foes.

Specially Defensive.description:
Swampert is able to set Stealth Rock in order to reduce the longevity of Pokemon that do not run Heavy-Duty Boots such as Choice Specs Zapdos. Earthquake is used to prevent Swampert from being strictly passive, allowing it to hit Electric- and Poison-types like Tapu Koko, Zeraora, and Toxapex. Roar not only takes advantage of the aforementioned Stealth Rock, but it allows Swampert to phaze setup sweepers such as Dragon Dance Dragapult and Dragonite, preventing it from becoming setup fodder. Flip Turn takes advantage of Swampert's little Speed investment to allow the player to gain momentum by having switch advantage. Swampert's EVs allow it to survive a Grass Knot from Choice Specs Tapu Koko and KO it back with Earthquake after Stealth Rock damage.

Almost all Water-type Pokemon benefit from the presence of Swampert on the team, as it is able to shield the rest of the team from Electric-type moves such as Rising Voltage and Thunderbolt, as well as set Stealth Rock. Notable mentions of Pokemon that benefit from Swampert being on a team are Pelipper and Mantine, as they both have a 4x weakness to Electric-type moves. Pelipper and Mantine can also switch into Ground-type moves to prevent Swampert from taking unnecessary damage. Pelipper can set rain for Swift Swim teammates that Swampert can pivot in via Flip Turn, and Mantine can use Defog for its teammates. Due to the aforementioned immunity, Swampert and Toxapex form a defensive backbone together, with Toxapex being able to take on physical attackers for Swampert such as Dragon Dance Dragapult and Dragonite. Toxapex can also absorb Toxic Spikes and Toxic for Swampert. Swampert assists wallbreakers such as Choice Specs Keldeo and Barraskewda. These wallbreakers are able to take care of walls such as Blissey, Porygon2, and Skarmory, which Swampert struggles against due to its passive nature. Choice Specs Keldeo especially is an amazing teammate for Swampert, as Flip Turn can bring it in to obtain KOs on both physical and special walls such as Blissey, Ferrothorn, and Celesteela. Choice Scarf Urshifu-R heavily benefits from the presence of Swampert, as it not only provides an aforementioned immunity to Electric but a special wall to take the special hits that Urshifu-R cannot. In turn, Urshifu-R can handle Dark- and Steel-type Pokemon such as Hydreigon and Ferrothorn for Swampert, as well as being able to revenge kill threats such as Tapu Koko and Zeraora. Tapu Fini prevents Swampert from being statused and can help Swampert avoid entry hazard damage with Defog. Tapu Fini also deals with Dragon-types that can wall Swampert such as Hydreigon, Kyurem, and Latios. Slowking also appreciates the aforementioned immunity as well, and Swampert appreciates a switch-in for certain special attackers such as Tapu Lele. Suicune is an excellent partner for Swampert due to its ability to stall out many bulkier Pokemon that Swampert would otherwise be unable to hit such as Celesteela. Slowking can form a pivoting core with Swampert, bringing in teammates like Barraskewda safely and then having them wreak havoc.

Pelipper.comments:
Other Options

Water

A Choice Specs can be used for better wallbreaking, but it makes Pelipper easy to wear down with Stealth Rock.

Defensive (Water).description:
Pelipper is an essential Pokemon for rain Water teams thanks to its Drizzle ability, as well as the utility it provides through U-turn and Defog. Hurricane is Pelipper's STAB move of choice, hitting Grass-types such as Amoonguss and Zarude. Scald is another STAB option to hit other weather setters and Electric-types such as Hippowdon, Tyranitar, and Tapu Koko on the switch, as well as spreading burns. U-turn helps Pelipper safely bring in its teammates, while Roost keeps it healthy throughout a match. Heavy-Duty Boots prevents Stealth Rock from wearing Pelipper down, allowing it to set rain consistently.

Most Pokemon on Water teams appreciate Pelipper setting rain and checking Grass-types. Swift Swim users, including Barraskewda, Kingdra, and Seismitoad, can decimate offensive teams under rain with their high Speed and high-powered STAB moves. Seismitoad can also double as an Electric sponge and Stealth Rock setter, but these roles can also be covered by Swampert, which has Flip Turn to further preserve momentum and greater bulk to survive Grass Knot from the likes of Tapu Koko and Alolan Raichu. Urshifu-R appreciates rain making its Surging Strikes even harder to switch into, and it helps break past walls such as Ferrothorn. Crawdaunt is a wallbreaker that can help break through defensive cores in types like Psychic and Poison while also threatening frailer Pokemon with rain-boosted Aqua Jet. Slowking switches into Freeze-Dry users such as Kyurem and Alolan Ninetales for Pelipper. Toxapex alleviates pressure on Pelipper to check difficult Grass-types like Rillaboom, Zarude, and Tapu Bulu. Both Slowking and Toxapex can also provide momentum with Teleport and Eject Button, respectively, which is crucial to bring in rain sweepers, and this is also why other pivots like Swampert and Barraskewda are valued so highly.

Revenge Killer (Fairy).description:
Thanks to its ability Trace, Gardevoir is specifically used to revenge kill common threatening weather sweepers for Fairy-type teams. With coverage moves like Energy Ball and Focus Blast, Gardevoir is able to revenge kill threats like Seismitoad, Drednaw, Barraskewda, and Excadrill against Water- and Ground-type teams, respectively. Additionally, Gardevoir helps in beating Poison-type Pokemon such as Toxtricity and Gengar, which can be pain otherwise for Fairy-type teams. Gardevoir has low bulk, so it should be brought in via a free switch after a Pokemon has fainted to revenge kill the foe or through aggressive double switching to threaten opposing Pokemon. The Speed EVs along with a Choice Scarf and Trace make it possible to outspeed the aforementioned weather sweepers.

Slower Pokemon such as Nasty Plot Togekiss and Mimikyu benefit from Gardevoir's ability to revenge kill faster Pokemon like Salazzle and weather sweepers of Water- and Ground-type teams. Wallbreakers like Bulk Up Grimmsnarl appreciate Gardevoir as a cleaner. Due to its middling Speed stat, faster revenge killers can outspeed and threaten to beat it, hence Pokemon like Ribombee can provide Sticky Web support to allow Gardevoir to outspeed opposing Pokemon more readily.

Choice Scarf (Psychic).description:
Gardevoir is a fantastic Choice Scarf user for Psychic teams thanks to its Fairy typing and access to Moonblast, which allows it to revenge kill otherwise troublesome Dark-types. It is also a fantastic check to weather-focused types such as Water and Ground, as it can easily dispatch of their respective weather sweepers, such as Barraskewda and Excadrill, thanks to Trace and good coverage in Energy Ball and Focus Blast. Choice Scarf is a necessity to revenge kill these sweepers after their ability has been copied. Psychic is a great STAB option that prevents Gardevoir from being walled by Poison-types like Toxapex, while Healing Wish can be used late-game to allow a weakened teammate to clean up. Maximum Special Attack and Speed investment maximizes Gardevoir's offensive capabilities, as it does not need to invest in bulk.

Every Pokemon on Psychic appreciates Gardevoir's ability to manage Dark-types, as they are a large threat to the type. Furthermore, frailer offensive threats such as Indeedee and Gallade greatly value Gardevoir's ability to keep weather sweepers in check. Gardevoir is walled by bulky Steel-types such as Aegislash and Corviknight, making Pokemon that can wear them down, such as Hatterene, good partners. Furthermore, entry hazard support from the likes of Bronzong and Mew makes cleaning with Gardevoir late-game much easier, as Gardevoir often falls short of KOing opposing Pokemon without sufficient chip damage.

Stallbreaker (Dark).description:
Sableye acts as a stallbreaker for Dark teams with its combination of Prankster and Taunt, being able to shut down annoying threats like Bulk Up Corviknight, hazard setters like Ferrothorn, and defensive Pokemon like Toxapex, while also having reliable recovery in Recover. It can also act as a Fighting-type check with its good typing in Ghost / Dark, giving it a immunity to this type while also being immune to Rapid Spin. It can also cripple physical attackers that threaten Dark teams such as Mamoswine with Will-O-Wisp. Using Knock Off it can get rid of important items such as Black Sludge and Leftovers from certain Pokemon, helping it stallbreak more efficiently. Sableye runs a fully defensive spread to increase its overall defense, being able to take hits from Galarian Zapdos and Urshifu-R.

Sableye pairs well with Tyranitar and Mandibuzz, covering for Sableye's average defenses and taking care of powerful attackers such as Choice Specs Dragapult and Bisharp respectively, forming a good defensive core. Mandibuzz can Defog hazards away so Sableye can enter more comfortably onto the field. Also, a teammate such as Toxic Spikes Drapion helps it by spreading status, but note that Sableye would then not be able to burn Pokemon like Mamoswine when they are already poisoned. Wallbreakers such as Hydreigon, Bisharp, and Grimmsnarl are also good teammates for Sableye, being able to clean more easily with Sableye preventing hazards being set and wearing down the enemy team. Bisharp and Drapion also help in the Fairy matchup, which is a matchup problematic for Dark. Grimmsnarl also helps Sableye versus other Dark teams due to Dark-type's immunity to Prankster.

Stallbreaker (Ghost).description:
Sableye's main merit on Ghost teams comes from its access to Prankster, along with good utility moves like Taunt and Will-O-Wisp, making it an exceptional stallbreaker. This, along with reliable recovery in Recover, makes it hard to beat for many teams alike. Generally, Taunt should be used to block setup, recovery, entry hazards, and status, and should be used in conjunction with Will-O-Wisp and Knock Off to break down many different Pokemon like Ferrothorn, Toxapex, Corviknight, and more. Be aware that Prankster Will-O-Wisp is especially useful for crippling faster offensive threats that Ghost teams hate dealing with such as Excadrill, Barraskewda, and Dracozolt. Maximum HP and Special Defense investment ensures Sableye is as specially bulky as possible, and it can cripple physical attackers with Will-O-Wisp just fine.

The entire Ghost team appreciates Sableye's ability to block entry hazard setters from setting entry hazards using Taunt, seeing as Ghost teams typically do not carry entry hazard control. Galarian Corsola aids Sableye defensively, as it is also able to cripple Pokemon with Will-O-Wisp and take on more threatening wallbreakers like Mamoswine, Diggersby and Excadrill more comfortably with its sturdy bulk. Offensive Ghost-type Pokemon like Gengar, Polteageist, Mimikyu, Dragapult, and Aegislash appreciate Sableye's ability to stallbreak and soften up the opposition, making it easier for them to sweep.

Torkoal.comments:
Other Options

Fire

Rest is an option over Yawn on Torkoal to increase its longevity, but it makes Torkoal setup fodder for Pokemon like Substitute Dragapult. Will-O-Wisp is also an option over Yawn or Lava Plume, giving Torkoal a better chance to burn Pokemon like Dragonite than Lava Plume. Heavy-Duty Boots over Heat Rock makes Torkoal immune to Stealth Rock, but this cuts into sun's duration and thus isn't that good.

Sun Setter (Fire).description:
Torkoal is the premier sun setter on Fire teams; it pairs well with Pokemon like Cinderace, Blacephalon, and Victini. It provides immense utility due to it having both Stealth Rock and Rapid Spin, the latter of which especially benefits its Fire-type teammates. Yawn deters setup sweepers such as Dragonite while also forcing out Water-types like Urshifu-R, which can let Torkoal get off a crucial last-second Rapid Spin. Lava Plume can be used over Yawn to burn opposing physical attackers. Body Press takes advantage of Torkoal's high Defense stat and hits foes such as Tyranitar and Heatran super effectively.

All Fire-types appreciate Torkoal setting sun and removing entry hazards. For example, Cinderace's Pyro Ball OHKOes Nidoking under sun. Volcarona can take advantage of sun effectively while also aiding against Water and Psychic teams. It is especially effective against the former, notably beating Toxapex if it is carrying Psychic. Mixed-attacking Victini helps against Ground and Dragon teams, with Glaciate + Energy Ball making it very uncomfortable to switch into. Also, Choice Band Victini's V-create becomes a nuke under sun, 2HKOing Mantine. Choice Scarf Blacephalon provides a fast attacker that also takes advantage of sun. Volcanion provides a Water immunity and a temporary Ground immunity with Air Balloon, which is very useful against Water and Ground teams. Heatran is a great partner for Torkoal, as Heatran can fit Flash Cannon to threaten Fairy and Rock teams because Torkoal sets Stealth Rock instead. Furthermore, Toxapex becomes easier to trap, as it does less damage under sun. Moltres provides a more reliable Ground immunity than Air Balloon Volcanion while also providing Defog support and pivoting with U-turn. Incineroar switches into special attackers better under sun, which weakens Water-type attacks from threats such as Volcanion, Toxapex, and Rotom-W. It also helps the team deal with Ghost-types such as Dragapult and Spectrier.

Crawdaunt.comments:
Other Options

Water

A set with Swords Dance and Life Orb or Muscle Band can be used to snowball through slower teams such as Poison and Steel teams, as Crawdaunt's STAB moves KO walls such as Toxapex and Ferrothorn at +2 after minimal chip damage, while Aqua Jet takes on faster threats such as Nidoking and Excadrill.

Choice Band (Dark).description:
With a high base Attack stat in conjunction with a phenomenal ability in Adaptability, Choice Band Crawdaunt serves as a hard-hitting wallbreaker for Dark teams. Knock Off is Crawdaunt's most powerful and most spammable Dark-type STAB move, allowing it to remove items from targets. Crabhammer is the strongest Water-type STAB move backed by Adaptability, cleanly OHKOing the likes of physically defensive Hippowdon and 2HKOing physically defensive Mandibuzz and defensive Corviknight. Aqua Jet makes up for Crawdaunt's low Speed and additionally allows it to pick off weakened or frail Pokemon such as Alolan Raichu, Gardevoir, Galarian Darmanitan, and Zeraora. Close Combat serves as a stronger means of hitting Ferrothorn as well as threatens Normal teams, as no Normal-type can switch into it. Alternatively, Crunch allows Crawdaunt to maintain the 2HKO on an itemless Toxapex. Crawdaunt should be brought into the battle to wallbreak with pivoting moves such as U-turn or through double switches, as it cannot switch into attacks due to its lackluster bulk. Maximum Attack investment in conjunction with an Adamant nature while holding a Choice Band allows Crawdaunt to hit as hard as possible. Maximum Speed investment allows Crawdaunt to outspeed defensive Rotom-W and defensive Mandibuzz.

Tyranitar is able to provide Stealth Rock support, which wears the opposing team down and allows Crawdaunt to wallbreak more easily. Tyranitar can also cripple threats such as Mew, Gardevoir, and Indeedee-M with Thunder Wave, allowing Crawdaunt to outspeed them and making up for its lackluster Speed tier. Mandibuzz can switch into Pokemon such as Flygon, Virizion, and Excadrill that threaten Crawdaunt greatly, Defog away entry hazards such as Toxic Spikes and Sticky Web that hinder Crawdaunt, and allow Crawdaunt to safely get into the battle with U-turn. Weavile and Bisharp appreciate Crawdaunt's wallbreaking abilities, as they all share similar checks. Weavile is able to beat Dragon-types such as Kommo-o and Noivern, while Bisharp is able to defeat Fairy-types such as Galarian Weezing and Hatterene. Additionally, Crawdaunt is able to wallbreak and punch holes through teams early-game, allowing Bisharp to sweep late-game. Dual screens Grimmsnarl makes up for Crawdaunt's poor bulk, allowing it to take hits more easily, while Bulk Up Grimmsnarl appreciates Crawdaunt's wallbreaking capabilities weakening Pokemon like Toxapex and allowing it to sweep more easily. Drapion is able to threaten Fairy-types such as Primarina, Togekiss, and Whimsicott, which all threaten Crawdaunt, in addition to providing Toxic Spikes support for Crawdaunt to wallbreak more easily. Incineroar is able to switch into Grass- and Fairy-type attacks and can provide Crawdaunt with a slow U-turn to enter the battle safely.

Choice Band (Water).description:
Crawdaunt is an incredible wallbreaker that fits on both balance and rain teams and can break through teams of many types such as Poison, Water, and Psychic. Knock Off is its most spammable move and can 2HKO walls like Toxapex and Slowbro, which can annoy rain sweepers, as well as removing important items such as Heavy-Duty Boots from Dragonite. Crabhammer offers more power and threatens Dark-resistant walls like Galarian Weezing, Mandibuzz, and Clefable. Close Combat is a good coverage move for Steel-types such as Ferrothorn and Melmetal. Crunch can be used instead to guarantee high, reliable damage after Knock Off removes a foe's item. It's especially helpful against bulky archetypes such as Poison and Water stall teams, notably 2HKOing Toxapex and Amoonguss even after they lose their items. Aqua Jet helps Crawdaunt compensate for its low Speed, pick off weakened foes, and potentially OHKO Gengar, Nihilego, Thundurus-T, and Choice Specs Tapu Koko after Stealth Rock in rain. An Adamant nature with maximum Speed EVs is enough to outpace slower Pokemon like Clefable, Swampert, uninvested Rotom-W, and Mantine.

Pokemon such as Slowking, Slowbro, and Rotom-W that can pivot Crawdaunt into annoying walls are great teammates; Slowbro and Slowking can also provide Future Sight support, which helps Crawdaunt break through Poison teams, especially if it isn't running Crunch. Swampert provides an immunity to Electric, Stealth Rock support, and Flip Turn to pivot Crawdaunt in safely. Toxapex can check Grass-, Fairy- and Fighting-types, such as Tapu Bulu, Clefable, and Terrakion, and carry Eject Button on rain teams to pivot Crawdaunt in against slower threats. Pelipper is a reliable Defog user and activates rain, which can allow Crawdaunt to spam Aqua Jet and Crabhammer, 2HKOing Pokemon such as Amoonguss. Urshifu-R can overwhelm Steel-types if Crawdaunt is lacking Close Combat, threaten Ice-types such as Kyurem, and use U-turn to avoid losing momentum by bringing Crawdaunt into Psychic-types such as Slowbro. As Crawdaunt is slow, faster teammates such as Barraskewda and Choice Scarf Tapu Fini can clean up teams late-game.

Cradily.overview:
Grass

Cradily is a great support option for Grass teams because of its utility options in Stealth Rock and Toxic, part-Rock typing that provides neutrality to Flying- and Fire-type attacks, and ability in Storm Drain to absorb Water-type attacks. Its part-Rock typing in conjunction with its high Special Defense and reliable recovery betters its ability to take on special attackers like Volcarona, Zapdos, and Tornadus-T. It forms a great defensive core with Amoonguss and Ferrothorn, with all covering each others' weaknesses fairly well. However, Cradily's typing leaves it susceptible to threats like Fighting-, Steel-, and Ice-types like Terrakion, Scizor, Galarian Darmanitan, and Glastrier. Its poor offensive stats give setup sweepers like Excadrill, Rillaboom, and Dragapult opportunities to set up with ease.
Cradily.comments:
Other Options

Grass

Earthquake is an option over Toxic to hit Poison- and Steel-types like Dragalge, Nidoking, Heatran, and Magnezone, but be aware of Rillaboom's Grassy Terrain being active. Heavy-Duty Boots is another effective way to keep Cradily healthy, since Grass normally doesn't run entry hazard removal.

Checks and Counters

Grass

Poison-types: Poison-types like Galarian Weezing and Toxapex are immune to Toxic and aren't bothered by Cradily's Rock Blast. They can also hinder its recovery with Will-O-Wisp or Toxic.

Status: Cradily should be cautious of status, particularly Toxic and burns, because the former limits it as a reliable defensive switch-in and the latter halves the damage of Rock Blast.

Steel-types: Steel-types such as Celesteela, Excadrill, and Aegislash can easily take Rock Blast repeatedly, are immune to Toxic, and can KO Cradily with their Steel-type attacks. Setup sweepers like Bisharp and Scizor can additionally set up. However, Earthquake can deal with Pokemon like Heatran and Magnezone.

Wallbreakers: Physical wallbreakers like Choice Band Zeraora and Choice Band Rillaboom can OHKO Cradily with their STAB attacks or super effective coverage moves, while special wallbreakers like Choice Specs Hydreigon can heavily dent Cradily.

Specially Defensive (Grass).description:
Rock Blast hits Flying-, Ice-, Bug-, and Fire-types like Zapdos, Alolan Ninetales, Araquanid, and Volcarona and helps with Pokemon that commonly set up Substitute like Galarian Moltres, Hydreigon, and Kyurem. Kyurem, in particular, can stall out other Rock-type STAB moves due to Pressure. Toxic allows Cradily to cripple potential switch-ins, bulkier Pokemon like Hippowdon, Mandibuzz, and Porygon2 that can recover off damage from Rock Blast, and setup sweepers like Hydreigon that may try using it as setup bait. Cradily can reliably stall foes with Toxic thanks to Recover. Storm Drain allows Cradily to pivot into Water-type attacks and prevents Scald burns from Pokemon like Toxapex. Maximum Special Defense and HP investment along with a Careful nature gives Cradily the best matchup against special attackers like Volcarona and Kyurem.

All of Cradily's teammates appreciate its ability to set up Stealth Rock, which allows sweepers like Rillaboom and Zarude to secure KOs mid- or late-game and hampers threatening Fire- and Flying-types. Rillaboom and Zarude can take care of Steel-types like Heatran, Ferrothorn, and Bisharp with their Fighting-type attacks, while Cradily can get rid of threats like Volcarona and Togekiss with Rock Blast. Choice Band Rillaboom can break past defensive cores that threaten Cradily such as Toxapex + Pelipper and Galarian Slowking + Slowbro. Rillaboom also sets Grassy Terrain for Cradily, giving it passive recovery, and is able to get rid of Heavy-Duty Boots from Pokemon like Zapdos and Mantine with Knock Off, resulting in Stealth Rock wearing down teams more effectively. Bulk Up Zarude can pressure defensive Pokemon like Toxapex and Blissey, which easily wall Cradily or threaten it with Toxic, and KO Psychic- and Ghost-types like Victini and Dragapult. Ferrothorn forms a defensive core with Cradily, setting Spikes and dealing with Ice- and Fairy-types like Alolan Ninetales, Cloyster, and Tapu Lele with Gyro Ball. Its part-Steel typing gives a neutrality against Bug-type attacks and allows it to pivot into Toxic. Ferrothorn also deals with physical attackers like Excadrill for Cradily, while Cradily deals with special attackers like Nidoking in return. Amoonguss absorbs Toxic Spikes that could hinder Cradily's recovery, spreads status ailments with Spore, Stun Spore, and poison from Sludge Bomb, and switches into Fighting-type attacks from Terrakion and Keldeo that could OHKO Cradily. Celebi and Whimsicott can also deal with Fighting-types that threaten Cradily with Psychic and Moonblast, respectively. Whimsicott also helps in the Dark- and Dragon-type matchups, as it can KO Pokemon like Hydreigon, Kyurem, and Dragapult with Moonblast and provides an immunity to Dragon. Rotom-C can get rid of Flying-types like Skarmory, Celesteela, and Taunt Mandibuzz with Thunderbolt, which Cradily fails to do much against, and break through defensive cores that overpower Cradily with Nasty Plot. Choice Scarf Rotom-C can also revenge kill faster Pokemon like Garchomp and Alolan Ninetales and bring Cradily safely into the field with Volt Switch.

Latias.overview:
Dragon

Latias is an excellent revenge killer for Dragon teams thanks to its great Speed stat, good Special Attack, and Psychic typing allowing it to take care of Fighting- and Poison-types like Terrakion, Nihilego, and Galarian Weezing. Latias is a great Choice Scarf user that can revenge kill Pokemon like Dragonite after a Dragon Dance without Multiscale intact, 2HKO threats like Tapu Koko, and threaten fast Choice Scarf users like Terrakion, Nihilego, and Buzzwole. Latias also has utility options like Healing Wish and Defog, which let it fulfill a more supportive role. Levitate lets it serve as a Ground immunity and prevents it from being worn down by entry hazards. However, Latias faces competition with Latios as a revenge killer, as it has a better Special Attack and the ability to OHKO Choice Scarf Heracross and Terrakion without prior chip damage.
Latias.comments:
Other Options

Psychic

Mystical Fire can be used over Defog to help Latias defeat foes such as Ferrothorn, Tapu Bulu, and Scizor; however, its Defog support is more desirable. Trick can be used to hinder bulkier Pokemon that easily switch into Latias such as Celesteela and Slowking. A non-Choice Scarf set with Calm Mind and Stored Power can be used to help combat Electric-type teams more effectively.

Dragon

Trick over Psychic or Draco Meteor can be an option to hinder special walls such as Blissey, Mantine, and Celesteela; however, it is hard to justify using it over either of these options, as losing Psychic prevents Latias from taking care of Choice Scarf Buzzwole and Heracross, while dropping Draco Meteor makes Latias unable to revenge kill boosted Dragonite and Choice Scarf Hydreigon.

Checks and Counters

Dragon

Steel-types: Latias fails to do meaningful damage to Steel-types because they resist both of its attacks. Pokemon like Excadrill and Jirachi threaten Latias with their STAB moves, while Aegislash and Bisharp OHKO it. Bulky Steel-types like Celesteela, Skarmory, and Ferrothorn wall Latias and weaken it with Toxic or Leech Seed.

Fairy-types: Fairy-types like Tapu Koko, Tapu Lele, and Tapu Fini can tank Psychic and threaten Latias with their STAB attacks.

Super Effective Attacks: Mimikyu, Spectrier, Alolan Ninetales, and Weavile are all able to tank an attack from Latias and take care of it with their super effective attacks. Dragapult can also outpace and take care of Latias if it is running Choice Scarf or after a Dragon Dance. Mamoswine is also able to take care of a weakened Latias with Ice Shard.

Specially Defensive Walls: Walls like Blissey and Mantine are able to tank both of Latias's attacks and wear it down with attacks such as Seismic Toss, Scald, and Toxic.

Status: Paralysis makes Latias unable to outpace Dragapult and Weavile, while Toxic puts it on a timer.

Choice Scarf (Dragon).description:
Draco Meteor is Latias's strongest STAB attack and allows it to revenge kill opposing Dragon-types like Hydreigon, boosted Dragonite, and Kyurem while also heavily denting physically defensive walls like Hippowdon and Mandibuzz. Psychic is a more reliable STAB option that allows Latias to take care of troublesome Fighting- and Poison-types like Terrakion, Galarian Weezing, and Choice Specs Gengar. Healing Wish can be used to fully heal threatening setup sweepers like Dragon Dance Dragapult. Levitate lets Latias come in on Ground-type attacks from Pokemon like Hippowdon and makes it immune to Spikes and Toxic Spikes. 252 Speed EVs with a Timid nature allow Latias to outpace Choice Scarf users like Terrakion and Buzzwole, Speed tie with Choice Scarf Latios, and outpace naturally faster threats like Dragapult and Weavile.

All teammates appreciate Latias's Healing Wish and Defog support. Hydreigon greatly helps against troublesome Steel-types such as Aegislash, Excadrill, and Skarmory. Garchomp is useful for Stealth Rock support to secure the OHKO on Terrakion and Heracross. Garchomp can also take care of Steel-types such as Excadrill and Heatran, wall Regieleki, and take out Volcarona with Stone Edge or a boosted Scale Shot. Dragapult is very helpful in the Ghost and Psychic matchups, as it handles Gengar, Spectrier, and Tapu Lele. It can also sweep in the Dragon mirror matchup after one Dragon Dance. Kyurem is a notable partner, as it tears apart Water- and Ground-types that Latias has trouble beating, like Tapu Fini, Slowbro, Hippowdon, and Gastrodon. Dragonite is a fearsome setup sweeper that greatly helps with troublesome Fairy-, Flying-, Steel-, and Dark-types like Tapu Koko, Mantine, Heatran, and Drapion. In return, Dragonite loves Latias's ability to take care of Terrakion and Buzzwole. Dragalge is great in the Fairy and Water matchups, as it can come in on Fairy-type attacks from Tapu Fini and Tapu Koko and use Toxic Spikes to make the Fairy and Normal matchups much easier. Dracovish excels at forcing switches and tearing apart defensive cores that Latias fails to do much against, such as Blissey + Porygon2 and Celesteela + Mantine + Zapdos, with its powerful STAB attacks and coverage moves like Stone Edge. In return, Latias threatens Keldeo and Toxicroak, which give it problems. Duraludon is also an option to provide Stealth Rock and take care of troublesome Fairy-types such as Mimikyu and Clefable. Kommo-o is an excellent partner that can greatly help in the Dark and Steel matchups that Latias cannot do much in.

Choice Scarf (Psychic).description:
Latias cements itself on Psychic teams over Latios thanks to its Healing Wish support, which fits great into a Choice Scarf set, allowing it to also revenge kill foes such as Regieleki, Dragapult, and fast Choice Scarf users such as Buzzwole and Blacephalon. Draco Meteor is Latias's strongest attack, nailing foes such as Thundurus-T, non-Choice Scarf Dragapult, and Hydreigon. Psychic is Latias's second attack of choice, as it 2HKOes Tapu Koko and Toxapex. Psyshock can also be used over Psychic to pick off Volcarona after Quiver Dance and Nihilego. Defog removes entry hazards for its teammates such as Victini and Galarian Slowking, which eases pressure on them. Healing Wish in tandem with Choice Scarf allows Latias to fully heal a teammate such as Hatterene without fear of being outpaced.

Victini helps Latias by beating Steel-types that Latias can't beat, such as Ferrothorn, Excadrill, and Aegislash, and appreciates Latias's Healing Wish. Hatterene can help defeat Dark-type Pokemon such as Zarude and Galarian Moltres thanks to its Fairy typing, Calm Mind, and Trick Room, while Latias can use Healing Wish to let it set up again if need be. Choice Scarf Tapu Lele is also a Fairy-type, and it revenge kills Pokemon such as non-Choice Scarf Weavile and Zarude for Psychic teams, alongside setting Psychic Terrain to help defeat Bisharp. Choice Specs Tapu Lele can also work alongside Latias to help defeat Pokemon such as Slowking and Landorus-T. Slowbro switches into Excadrill and Cinderace, alongside taking on Dragapult or Weavile if it's holding Kasib Berry or Colbur Berry, respectively. Galarian Slowking helps by switching into special attackers that can threaten Latias, such as Kingdra and opposing Tapu Lele. Jirachi provides an entry hazard for Psychic in Stealth Rock, can help combat Ice-types that threaten Psychic teams such as SubRoost Kyurem, and can take Dragon-type attacks such as Kingdra's Draco Meteor. While not directly supporting Latias, Mew provides strong general utility for Psychic teams by debilitating foes with Knock Off and Will-O-Wisp, which helps its teammates break through teams more easily. Indeedee can also be a niche teammate to help switch into Ghost-type moves, notably from Spectrier and Blacephalon.

Latios.comments:
Other Options

Psychic

Thunderbolt + Ice Beam, can be used over Mystical Fire and Draco Meteor to help combat Flying- and Water-type Pokemon such as Galarian Moltres, Slowking, and Landorus-T, although this leaves Latios unable to do anything against Ferrothorn and Excadrill, which can be quite troublesome. Aura Sphere can also be used instead of Mystical Fire to hit foes that would normally force Latios out, such as Tyranitar and Heatran. Recover may also be considered over Mystical Fire for longevity. A niche option on Latios is Colbur Berry, which helps defeat Galarian Moltres and Choice Scarf Zarude after a Calm Mind boost.

Calm Mind (Psychic).description:
Thanks to its great Speed tier and ability to boost with Calm Mind, Latios proves to be a threatening sweeper on Psychic teams. Draco Meteor is its strongest move and OHKOes Pokemon such as Thundurus-T and Hydreigon while heavily damaging Slowbro and Zarude -- but be aware that Choice Scarf Zarude forces Latios out. Psyshock is used over Psychic to hit foes such as Swampert, Galarian Slowking, and Blissey harder than Psychic would. Mystical Fire is a great coverage option to dismantle Steel-types, notably OHKOing Ferrothorn and 2HKOing Celesteela after a Calm Mind boost. In tandem with Levitate, Mystical Fire also allows Latios to threaten non-Mold Breaker Excadrill. With Soul Dew, Latios gains the extra power it needs after a boost to 2HKO bulky Pokemon with Psyshock, such as Gastrodon.

Victini helps dismantle threats Latios can't handle, such as Aegislash and Galarian Moltres, while also being able to debilitate Heatran with Trick. It also pivots Latios in against bulky Pokemon such as Slowbro and Toxapex, which Latios breaks through easily. Galarian Slowking can take on Heatran by itself with Earthquake and switch into special attackers such as Choice Specs Kingdra and Tapu Koko. Slowbro can switch into physical attackers Latios is forced out by, such as Choice Scarf Urshifu-R, Barraskewda, and Mamoswine. Jirachi is useful for Psychic, as the chip damage it provides via Stealth Rock can help Latios break through bulky Pokemon more easily; it also switches into Fairy-types that force out Latios such as Tapu Lele and Clefable. If running Choice Scarf, Jirachi can also deal with Choice Scarf Galarian Darmanitan and provide Healing Wish utility. Hatterene helps combat Dark-types such as Rest Galarian Moltres, and it provides Trick Room to help defeat faster Dark-types such as Choice Scarf Zarude and Weavile. Hatterene deters entry hazards thanks to Magic Bounce. Choice Scarf Tapu Lele helps deal with threats like Bisharp, Weavile, and Dragapult, while Choice Specs Tapu Lele can help defeat Tyranitar, which Latios can't break through on its own. Mew can shut down bulkier Pokemon such as Porygon2 and Landorus-T with Will-O-Wisp in tandem with Taunt and Knock Off, which Latios heavily appreciates, while also setting Spikes or Stealth Rock. Indeedee is a niche teammate that provides a Ghost immunity, notably checking Spectrier, while providing Healing Wish utility; however, it is worth nothing that other Ghost-types have coverage for it.

Jirachi.overview:
Steel

Jirachi is the premier special attacker for Steel with its huge pool of coverage moves such as Psyshock, Moonblast, Thunderbolt, and Energy Ball, which allow it to improve the Poison, Dragon, Flying, Water, and Ground matchups. It also has a good Speed tier, which allows it to outspeed and OHKO threats such as Urshifu-R, Nidoking, and Hydreigon. Furthermore, its decent bulk and neutrality to Fighting allow it to take a hit in a pinch and be a good answer to Tapu Lele. However, its Special Attack is quite lackluster, as Jirachi fails to OHKO bulky Pokemon such as Kyurem, Hippowdon, and Toxapex even with Choice Specs. Because of this, Jirachi needs support from wallbreakers like Bisharp and Melmetal to remove specially defensive Pokemon, such as Galarian Slowking, and Pokemon that resist its attacks like Heatran.
Jirachi.comments:
Other Options

Psychic

Ice Punch or Fire Punch may be considered over Trick or Healing Wish with Choice Scarf to threaten Landorus-T and Garchomp or Ferrothorn. However, this comes at the cost of reduced utility.
