Secret Sword is a good alternative to Aura Sphere if the little extra power and the ability to hit the Defense stat as opposed to the Special Defense stat is preferred, which is key in dealing with Pokemon like Snorlax. Keldeo also uses Icy Wind to hit some would-be threats on the switch such as Noivern, Vileplume, and Dragapult, and Scald to have a more reliable Water-type STAB move when needed. In order for it to maximize its offensive presence, Keldeo runs full EV investment in both Special Attack and Speed with a Timid nature. This boost in Speed allows it to outspeed key Pokemon like Mimikyu, Modest Alolan Raichu, and non-Choice Scarf Jirachi naturally.

Keldeo's offensive presence and ability to break open holes in the opposing team make it great as a partner for setup sweepers like Gyarados and Cloyster. Keldeo also helps get rid of prominent Grass-types like Appletun and Vileplume with Icy Wind. Crawdaunt and Primarina are offensive partners that can help out Keldeo by getting rid of annoying Psychic- and Dragon-types, respectively, while switching into their respective types. Crawdaunt in particular, while able to greatly improve the Steel matchup alongside Keldeo, also helps check Jellicent which completely walls Keldeo. Rotom-W is also a very invaluable teammate for Keldeo, as it can take Flying-type attacks from the likes of Corviknight and Togekiss and threaten them out with its own Electric-type STAB move and pivot using Volt Switch. It can also use a Substitute + Nasty Plot set that can break Pokemon like Jellicent and Toxapex, as well as provide support through Defog, which prevents Keldeo from getting worn down from hazards. Seismitoad allows Keldeo to have Stealth Rock support as well as providing it a switch-in to Electric-type attacks. Toxapex also helps take Grass-type attacks for Keldeo as a defensive pivot while using Toxic or Toxic Spikes to help wear down the opposing team. Pelipper sets rain, which gives Keldeo ludicrous amounts of power with its Hydro Pump and allows partners like Dracovish to help clean teams that were weakened by Keldeo's wallbreaking power. Araquanid is also very helpful in assisting Keldeo with Sticky Web to slow down faster threats like Heliolisk and Choice Scarf Indeedee.

Choice Specs (Fighting).description:
Keldeo holds a niche over Urshifu-R on Fighting teams, as its much higher Speed lets it combat threats such as Choice Band Galarian Zapdos and Garchomp, and it also defeats physical walls like Skarmory and Galarian Weezing. Hydro Pump is Keldeo's strongest move, allowing it to easily break through bulky Pokemon such as Celesteela and Aegislash, which Fighting-type teams can often struggle against. Secret Sword defeats Pokemon that would otherwise switch into its Water-type attacks easily, such as Volcanion, Gastrodon, and Chansey. Scald is used alongside Hydro Pump to avoid risking a miss when Hydro Pump's power isn't needed, compensate for Hydro Pump's lacking PP, and burn foes that can switch into Keldeo such as Kommo-o and Dragonite. Flip Turn allows Keldeo to maintain momentum and take advantage of common switch-ins such as Toxapex, Slowking, and Galarian Slowking. Icy Wind can be used over Flip Turn to ease Keldeo's matchup against the aforementioned Dragon-types in Kommo-o and Dragonite, helping Fighting teams deal with them and shutting down their setup opportunities with Dragon Dance by reducing their Speed.

Cobalion provides a Fairy and Psychic neutrality and can deal with Pokemon such as Clefable and Hatterene, albeit in a limited fashion, as its bulk leaves much to be desired. It also provides utility with Stealth Rock and Thunder Wave. Toxicroak checks Water-types like Toxapex and Tapu Fini, and it can sweep Fairy-type teams, which Keldeo struggles against, with Swords Dance and Gunk Shot. Choice Band Galarian Zapdos is a threatening wallbreaker that muscles past Pokemon that Fighting struggles to combat, such as Slowbro, Celesteela, and Toxapex. Choice Scarf Terrakion provides a revenge killer, late-game cleaner, and way to defeat Flying-type Pokemon such as Thundurus-T and Zapdos. It also outspeeds and beats Electric-type Pokemon such as Tapu Koko. Choice Scarf Buzzwole provides a defensive backbone for Fighting teams, as it can switch into threatening Water- and Ground-type attacks from Pokemon such as Barraskewda, Excadrill, and Choice Scarf Landorus-T.

Wallbreaker (Normal).description:
Due to its ability in Huge Power, great offensive typing in Normal / Ground, and access to priority, Diggersby is Normal's premier physical wallbreaker. Body Slam and Earthquake are Diggersby's STAB moves and should be used most of the time, given most non-resistant or immune targets are outright OHKOed or severely hurt by them. Fire Punch covers Steel-types not weak to Earthquake, notably Corviknight and Ferrothorn, while Quick Attack is useful to revenge kill faster threats like Barraskewda if they're weakened. An Adamant nature is optimal to hit as hard as possible; however, Jolly can be ran alongside Mega Kick to outspeed Adamant Excadrill outside of Sand and retain the 2HKOs on Mandibuzz and Hippowdon.

Snorlax appreciates the wallbreaking potential of Diggersby to sweep opposing teams with its Curse set. Similarly, Braviary can clean late-game once Diggersby removes walls such as Toxapex and Aegislash. Choice Scarf Ditto deals with the offensive threats Diggersby struggles against, like Dragapult and Galarian Darmanitan, and it can also deter opponents from attempting a setup sweep. As Diggersby appreciates spamming its powerful STAB moves, Indeedee is a good partner to remove Pokemon immune to them, such as Corviknight and Sableye. Indeedee's Psychic Terrain support also prevents priority moves from revenge killing Diggersby. Finally, Heliolisk helps Diggersby a lot by checking Water-types and bringing Diggersby safely into the field, respectively.

Swords Dance (Ghost).description:
Sporting an excellent Steel / Ghost typing with multiple resistances and immunities with phenomenal base stats and an amazing ability, Aegislash is a dominant force on Ghost teams fulfilling its role as an excellent Swords Dance wallbreaker. Shadow Sneak should be spammed the most after setting up and can pick off weakened foes and clean late-game; it mainly assists versus Psychic teams and opposing Ghost teams. Close Combat is able to hit threats such as Ferrothorn, Steelix, and Avalugg hard. Iron Head is used to hit Fairy-types such as Grimmsnarl, which poses a huge threat to Ghost teams with priority Sucker Punch. Maximum Attack and HP investment allows Aegislash to hit as hard and be as bulky as possible to effectively activate Weakness Policy when in Shield forme, where it exhibits its sky-high defenses.

Entry hazard setters such as Froslass, Runerigus, and Galarian Corsola all serve as great teammates for Aegislash, in order to help it sweep. Dragapult can break down with Choice Band or Choice Specs for Aegislash to sweep, as can Polteageist mid-game. Gengar is also a fine partner, as it can benefit from Aegislash's wallbreaking capabilities and can clean late-game. Lastly, Mimikyu can take on faster Dark-types such as Hydreigon and serves as a secondary check to Grimmsnarl.

Choice Specs (Steel).description:
With its amazing Special Attack in Blade forme paired with Choice Specs, Aegislash becomes a very powerful wallbreaker. STAB Shadow Ball is great, since only two types resist or are immune to it, making it very difficult to switch into, and it's able to 2HKO bulky Pokemon such as Ferrothorn and Toxapex. Flash Cannon is Aegislash's secondary STAB attack and is primarily used against Pokemon weak to Steel or against Pokemon that resist or are immune to Shadow Ball such as Indeedee and Grimmsnarl. Steel Beam is Aegislash's most powerful attack at the cost of cutting half of its HP, which is why it should only be used when Aegislash needs to OHKO a threat such as omni-boosted Kommo-o or Mandibuzz. Aegislash has high Attack despite having a Modest nature, which allows it to effectively run Shadow Sneak so it can revenge kill weakened threats such as Keldeo, Chandelure, and Alolan Raichu. Stance Change is part of the reason why Aegislash is such a great wallbreaker, because it can take a hit before changing to Blade forme and use a powerful attack. Maximum investment in HP allows Aegislash to take attacks such as Choice Specs Shadow Ball from Dragapult in Shield forme due to its amazing bulk. Alternatively, maximum Speed can be used to outspeed Pokemon such as Adamant Crawdaunt and Corviknight. Aegislash should be used to wallbreak early- to mid-game and clear the way for its teammates to win.

Corviknight is a great partner, as it covers Aegislash's Ground weakness and makes a great pivot to attacks that threaten Aegislash such as Indeedee's Mystical Fire and Gengar's Shadow Ball. Ferrothorn gets up entry hazards to weaken the opposing team and put them in range of Aegislash's attacks. It also works well with Aegislash in dealing with Choice Specs Keldeo, as Ferrothorn resists Water-type attacks and can scout with Protect, while Aegislash is immune to Fighting-type attacks. Ferrothorn can also support Aegislash with its Leech Seed and let it recover back some HP. Melmetal forms a very powerful offensive core with Choice Specs Aegislash, being able to break through the majority of the metagame. Choice Scarf Excadrill is a good revenge killer capable of dealing with threats such as Chandelure and Rotom-H. Bisharp works well with Aegislash in overwhelming Psychic- and Ghost-type teams and is also valuable in other matchups thanks to its ability to revenge kill threats such as Alolan Raichu, Dragapult, Venusaur in sun, and Seismitoad in rain with Sucker Punch. Choice Scarf Duraludon can revenge kill Dragon-types that Aegislash has trouble with such as Hydreigon and Dragapult. Jirachi can check Keldeo with Psychic, provide Healing Wish support for Aegislash, and run Trick Room to allow Aegislash to take advantage of its mediocre Speed. Bronzong is another option for Trick Room-oriented teams.

SubToxic (Steel).description:
Thanks to its great defensive typing and amazing bulk in Shield forme combined with Toxic, Substitute, and its signature move King's Shield, Aegislash is able to annoy teams with Toxic stall while also applying offensive pressure with Shadow Ball due to its naturally high Special Attack. It can use Substitute on Pokemon that can't break through it, such as Jirachi and Celebi, and use Shadow Ball to deal damage or Toxic on a predicted switch. Toxic works well with King's Shield and Substitute to stall out the opposing Pokemon. King's Shield is also incredibly useful for scouting Choice item users such as Keldeo and Zeraora, switching to Shield forme so Aegislash can take attacks such as Shadow Ball from opposing Choice Specs Dragapult and Aegislash and OHKO them, as well as regain health with Leftovers and stall out weather. Shadow Ball threatens some common Toxic switch-ins such as Jirachi, Hatterene, and Celebi and does decent damage to Pokemon such as Ferrothorn and Toxapex. Full investment in HP and Special Defense is used to maximize Aegislash's special bulk and allow it to take attacks such as Choice Specs-boosted Hydro Pump from Pelipper and unboosted Weather Ball from Venusaur in sun.

Corviknight and Ferrothorn form a great defensive core with Aegislash, as they're able to cover a lot of each other's weaknesses. Aegislash can check Pokemon that threaten the other two, such as Dragapult and Choice Specs Aegislash, and provides a valuable Fighting immunity. Corviknight is able to switch in on Ground-type attacks that threaten Aegislash and check Fighting-types that annoy Ferrothorn with Brave Bird. Ferrothorn switches in on strong Water-type attacks that the other two can't take very well such as Choice Specs Keldeo's Hydro Pump, which Ferrothorn and Aegislash are able to beat thanks to their shared ability to scout its move with Protect or King's Shield. Ferrothorn also provides Leech Seed support for additional recovery and sets up entry hazards. Choice Scarf Duraludon is a good partner because it's able to revenge kill Hydreigon and is great against Dragon-type teams. Choice Scarf Excadrill is another great revenge killer and deals with threats such as Chandelure and Zeraora. Jirachi is capable of handling Keldeo thanks to its STAB Psychic, breaking Corviknight and Toxapex with the combination of Calm Mind, Psychic, and Thunderbolt, and supporting Aegislash with Healing Wish. Bisharp is a strong wallbreaker and is especially good against Psychic- and Ghost-type teams together with Aegislash.

Swords Dance (Steel).description:
Aegislash acts as a powerful Swords Dance wallbreaker with incredible base stats, a wonderful Ghost / Steel typing, and an amazing ability that allows it to survive powerful hits and hit back hard, making it a staple on Steel-type teams. Shadow Claw is Aegislash's main STAB move and serves to hit Ghost- and Psychic-types. Shadow Sneak serves as a STAB priority move that helps to cover its horrendous Speed stat and revenge kill weakened foes. Close Combat is used in order to hit Steel-, Rock-, and Normal-types such as Ferrothorn, Tyranitar, and Indeedee. Weakness Policy takes advantage of Aegislash's ability to take powerful hits and boost its Attack to help it sweep more easily. Aegislash can be used early-game to weaken the opposing team to give its teammates the capability to sweep late-game, or as a late-game sweeper with its priority move in Shadow Sneak being able to KO weakened threats.

Entry hazard setters like Spikes Ferrothorn or Stealth Rock Duraludon helps Aegislash to sweep more easily late-game. Bisharp is also a good teammate, because the combination of both is very difficult for Ghost and Psychic teams to handle, as they can wear them down with their priority moves. Other late-game sweepers such as Choice Scarf Excadrill are also good partners for Aegislash, being able to clean remaining Pokemon after an Aegislash sweep. Aegislash fails to defeat Dark-type Pokemon such as Mandibuzz, so having a teammate that can take advantage of them like Bulk Up Corviknight is nice, too.

Barbaracle.comments:
Other Options

Rock

Barbaracle may use Cross Chop to deal with Steel-types like Ferrothorn and Magnezone; however, keeping both STAB moves and Grass Knot is preferred, as they target Pokemon that are more threatening to Rock teams. X-Scissor is a notable option for Grass-types like Zarude and Celebi, although the latter isn't as prevalent as the Steel-types or Ground-types mentioned. Air Balloon allows Barbaracle to deal with Excadrill, though White Herb is still preferred.

Shell Smash (Rock).description:
Barbaracle is a potent Shell Smash sweeper with its deadly STAB combination and excellent coverage. Shell Smash is a very powerful setup move; with White Herb, Barbaracle can maintain its good defensive stats to sponge priority attacks from Scizor, Bisharp, and Urshifu-R. Liquidation dismantles threats such as Choice Scarf Terrakion, Nidoking, and Mamoswine. Due to Pokemon like Urshifu-R, Gastrodon, and Seismitoad tanking Barbaracle's STAB moves, Grass Knot is run to utilize the Special Attack boosts from Shell Smash to muscle past them. Stone Edge combats Pokemon like Mantine, Kyurem, and Volcanion, which are either immune or resistant to Liquidation and don't mind Grass Knot. The given EV spread maximizes Barbaracle's Speed, which allows it to outpace Choice Scarf users such as Urshifu-R, Landorus-T, and Galarian Zapdos after a Shell Smash. A Naive nature maximizes Speed without hindering Grass Knot's power.

Barbaracle can quickly sweep Ground teams due to Liquidation and Grass Knot. Shuckle can set up Stealth Rock to provide chip damage on foes and Sticky Web to slow down threats that would otherwise threaten Barbaracle, such as Excadrill in sand and Choice Scarf Weavile, letting it clean Ground and Ice teams. Tyranitar supports Barbaracle with sand to chip foes like Polteageist and Cloyster, rendering their Focus Sashes useless, and boost Barbaracle's Special Defense. Additionally, Tyranitar breaks past walls that annoy Barbaracle like Slowbro, Bronzong, and Galarian Corsola with a Choice Band set. Choice Scarf Terrakion deals with Choice Scarf Zarude, Ferrothorn, and Cinderace. Nihilego takes care of physically defensive walls that Barbaracle struggles against like Slowbro, Corviknight, and Skarmory. Furthermore, Nihilego checks Grass-types like Zarude and Tapu Bulu. Rhyperior blanket checks many physical attackers like Excadrill, Cinderace, and Weavile because of its ability Solid Rock and good bulk. Coalossal provides support with Rapid Spin and Spikes while potentially triggering Flame Body against Steel-type Pokemon such as Scizor and Melmetal.

Dragalge.comments:
Other Options

Dragon

Draco Meteor is an option over Protect, allowing Dragalge to catch Poison-resistant Pokemon such as Garchomp, Toxapex, and Dragapult switching in on Gunk Shot. However, the most common switch-ins to Dragalge are Steel-types such as Klefki and Ferrothorn and general walls such as Gastrodon, which do not mind Draco Meteor either. Because teams like Psychic and Ground teams have Poison-types that absorb Toxic Spikes, a set with Rest, Sleep Talk, Gunk Shot, and Flip Turn may be considered for more longevity. However, Toxic Spikes goes a long way against types such as Normal and Fairy, easing would-be difficult matchups for Dragon teams. Payapa Berry may be used to properly check Tapu Lele and Volcarona, which may otherwise remove Dragalge with their Psychic-type attacks, but the lack of Black Sludge recovery makes it easier to wear down.

Toxic Spikes (Dragon).description:
Toxic Spikes makes Dragalge an excellent pick for Dragon teams to further enhance their offensive presence, most notably against types such as Fairy, Ghost, and Normal. Its Poison typing also allows Dragalge to take Fairy-type attacks from foes like Tapu Fini and Choice Scarf Tapu Lele and remove opposing Toxic Spikes. With its typing and immense Special Defense, Dragalge can blanket check special attackers such as Tapu Koko, Nihilego, and Galarian Moltres, although Choice Specs Aegislash, for example, can 2HKO it. Adaptability-boosted Gunk Shot deals solid overall damage, nails the aforementioned Fairy-types, and threatens Calm Mind users such as Clefable and Hatterene because it's physical. Dragalge's low Speed lets it put Flip Turn to excellent use, bringing in teammates such as Kyurem and Hydreigon safely against Pokemon it underspeeds, such as Toxapex, that like to spread status. Protect scouts Choice-locked Pokemon, such as Tapu Lele, Jirachi, and Gengar, while providing an extra turn of Black Sludge recovery and Toxic Spikes damage. 24 Speed IVs along with a Sassy nature allow Dragalge to underspeed Toxapex, thus sponging its status-inflicting moves such as Scald and Toxic before pivoting with Flip Turn, while outspeeding Hatterene outside of Trick Room to 2HKO it.

Substitute users such as Kyurem and Hydreigon appreciate Toxic Spikes greatly, as it continually helps them break through types like Normal, Fairy, and Ground more consistently. Furthermore, Dragalge can act as a slow pivot for the two with Flip Turn. In return, Kyurem can crush Water-types that don't fear Dragalge such as Gastrodon and Toxapex with Freeze-Dry, while Hydreigon provides a Psychic immunity, and it takes advantage of Steel- and Poison-types such as Ferrothorn and Toxapex that switch into Dragalge. Choice Scarf Dragapult is an excellent revenge killer that threatens foes like Kingdra in rain, Choice Scarf Weavile, and Dragon Dance Dragapult with its almost unresisted STAB combination. Toxic Spikes from Dragalge enables Dragapult's Hex and puts defensive checks of Dragon Dance Dragapult, such as Kasib Berry Slowbro and Hippowdon, on a timer. Furthermore, its Ghost typing lets Dragapult spinblock against foes like Excadrill and Torkoal to keep Toxic Spikes up. Garchomp also benefits from Dragalge's slow pivoting abilities, taking advantage of Pokemon such as Toxapex and Klefki, which come in on Dragalge. Garchomp can also utilize a Choice Scarf set to threaten Choice Scarf Galarian Darmanitan, Cinderace, and Zeraora. Latias provides a Ground immunity and runs Healing Wish, which lets Dragalge have a second chance in checking Tapu Lele or Tapu Fini. Duraludon is another good partner for Dragalge, as the duo forms a good defensive backbone thanks to Duraludon's good physical bulk. Thanks to its Steel typing, Duraludon can switch into Choice Scarf Jirachi's Iron Head and threaten it with Thunder Wave, and it handles Physical Fairy- and Ice-types such as Azumarill, Mimikyu, Choice Scarf Cloyster, and Weavile. Dragonite provides a Ground immunity to check Mold Breaker Excadrill, and it can either take advantage of Toxic Spikes wearing down walls with a Dragon Dance set or provide Defog support with a defensive set.

All-out Attacker (Normal).description:
On Normal-type teams, Heliolisk can act as a fearsome special attacker. Its above average Speed lets it outspeed common Pokemon like Indeedee and pivot out on them with Volt Switch to a suitable teammate if it cannot deal with them, allowing it to maintain momentum for the team. Grass Knot lets it pressure Ground-type teams and in combination with its STAB Electric-type move, it becomes a headache for Water-type teams to deal with, making such matchups relatively easier for Normal-type teams to handle. Focus Blast lets it beat Pokemon such as Ferrothorn and Excadrill that normally can switch into Heliolisk. Its ability Dry Skin is quite handy too, as it lets it pivot on defensive Pokemon like Toxapex. Maximum Speed investment makes Heliolisk as fast as possible, and maximum Special Attack investment with a Choice Specs bolsters its damage output. Expert Belt can be used to bluff a Choice item and boost super effective damage, as it synergizes well with its coverage.

Snorlax and Braviary are good teammates for Heliolisk, as they both appreciate it dealing with troublesome Steel-type Pokemon such as Corviknight, Ferrothorn, and Excadrill. In return, Thick Fat Snorlax checks Fire-type Pokemon for Heliolisk, and Choice Scarf Braviary can beat Fighting-type Pokemon like Gallade for it. Choice Scarf Braviary and Heliolisk form a threatening VoltTurn core, too. Choice Band Diggersby appreciates Volt Switch support from Heliolisk, giving it more chances to wallbreak and deal with Pokemon like Ferrothorn with Fire Punch, relieving the pressure from Heliolisk. Indeedee can wallbreak for Heliolisk and provide it with Psychic Terrain, allowing Heliolisk to revenge kill Pokemon like Lucario for the team. Obstagoon as a teammate adds in additional wallbreaking potential, as it appreciates Volt Switch to find opportunities to come in and break teams down with STAB Knock Off for Heliolisk.

Substitute + Glare (Normal).description:
Heliolisk makes its mark on Normal teams thanks to its ability Dry Skin alongside its offensive stats and coverage, which allow it to put in tons of work against Water and Flying teams. Glare allows it to paralyze faster threats such as Kingdra under rain and Choice Scarf Cobalion when Heliolisk is behind a Substitute. Glare mainly allows it to spread status well due to only Electric-type Pokemon being immune to it. Thunderbolt permits it to threaten Water- and Flying-type Pokemon such as Toxapex, Mantine, and Corviknight. Grass Knot grants Heliolisk the ability to target Water- and Ground-type Pokemon such as Seismitoad, Gastrodon, Mamoswine, and Rhyperior. The combination of Thunderbolt and Grass Knot allows Heliolisk to threaten every Water-type Pokemon for super effective damage. Substitute allows Heliolisk to take advantage of passive Pokemon such as Mantine, Toxapex, and specially defensive Aegislash. Heavy-Duty Boots allows Heliolisk to ignore entry hazards that will hinder it such as Sticky Web and Toxic Spikes. However, Leftovers can be used to passively regain health, giving it more opportunities to set up a Substitute. Dry Skin grants Heliolisk an immunity to Water-type attacks, allowing it to switch into attacks such as Dracovish's Fishious Rend and Azumarill's Aqua Jet, which can otherwise devastate Normal teams. Maximum EVs in Special Attack and Speed ensure it is as powerful as possible and faster than Pokemon such as Keldeo. Heliolisk should try to set up a Substitute against Water teams, especially on passive Pokemon such as Toxapex and Mantine or Pokemon Choice-locked into a Water-type attack such as Choice Scarf Rotom-W's Hydro Pump. Substitute then allows it to severely threaten Water teams. Outside of the Water and Flying matchups, Heliolisk's main job is to be spreading paralysis with Glare, which can be done more easily if it's behind a Substitute.

Heliolisk supports its offensive teammates with Glare, allowing them to outspeed threats such as Hydreigon. Blissey is a fantastic partner, as it can switch into a plethora of attacks for it such as Rotom-H's Overheat and Indeedee's Expanding Force. In addition, Blissey can set Stealth Rock for Heliolisk, allowing it to break past Pokemon such as Keldeo and Togekiss more easily. Finally, it can also pivot with Teleport to bring in Heliolisk safely. Ditto is a great way to check faster Pokemon such as Dragon Dance Dragapult and Cinderace. Braviary is an important teammate when Heliolisk is not using Heavy-Duty Boots, as it can clear hazards off the field, which is crucial for Heliolisk due to its weakness to Toxic Spikes and Sticky Web. This is especially important against Water teams. Diggersby, Bewear, and Obstagoon can break through special walls for Heliolisk such as Chansey, Ferrothorn, Celebi, and Tyranitar. Diggersby can also take on Fire- and Poison-type Pokemon such as Torkoal, Incineroar, and Salazzle. Obstagoon can help Heliolisk in the Psychic- and Ghost-type matchups by taking on Pokemon such as Mew and Alolan Marowak. Bewear is the best check to threats such as Urshifu-S, as Fluffy alongside a Chople Berry can make that matchup manageable. In return, Heliolisk can slow down faster Pokemon such as Hydreigon with Glare for them.

Swords Dance (Fighting).description:
On Fighting teams, Hawlucha is a fantastic late-game setup sweeper that utilizes its Unburden ability to become one of the fastest threats in the metagame. This and Hawlucha's access to Swords Dance, make it very good at cleaning weakened teams, and it grants the team a good matchup against Grass- and Bug-type teams thanks to its Flying typing. With White Herb, it can set up Unburden in front of any Pokemon that isn't a Ghost-type with Close Combat, and use either Acrobatics or Brave Bird to hit most of the tier very hard. Brave Bird is especially useful in matchups like Ghost, where activating White Herb is impossible due to everything being immune to Close Combat. Swords Dance is used to further boost its power in front of walls such as Ferrothorn on Steel. Taunt facilitates this by preventing walls like Toxapex or Hippowdon from healing and using Haze or phazing moves, as well as preventing entry hazards and other status moves. One should also be wary of Pokemon that are faster than Hawlucha after Unburden, such as Barraskewda in rain. Maximum Attack and Speed investment with a Jolly nature allows Hawlucha to hit as hard as possible while outspeeding most key threats outside of Unburden such as Gengar and Keldeo.

Hawlucha can't outright sweep teams from the beginning of the match, which is why it needs teammates like Bewear and Lucario to break holes in the opposing team so it can find an opportunity to set up and clean. Bewear helps check walls like Galarian Corsola thanks to its Substitute + Bulk Up set, while Lucario can help bust through walls like Toxapex with its Nasty Plot set. These Pokemon in return appreciate Hawlucha's ability to prevent hazards from being on the field thanks to Taunt, as well as making it easier to switch into walls like Hippowdon or Ferrothorn. Choice Scarf Toxicroak is also a great teammate, as it can KO most Fairy-types that threaten Hawlucha like Gardevoir and Hatterene. Hawlucha also enjoys the support that Stealth Rock Kommo-o can provide, as it weakens opposing Pokemon and makes it easier for Hawlucha to sweep late-game by breaking.

Klefki.comments:
Other Options

Fairy Lock in conjunction with Eject Button may be used to trap threats such as Nidoking, Excadrill, and Celesteela for a teammate to eliminate. However, this sacrifices an extra three turns of screens time and is usually not recommended. Additionally, this set loses either Foul Play or Thunder Wave, both of which are useful to cripple dangerous attackers. Toxic can be used over Thunder Wave to cripple threats such as Cosmic Power Mew and put defensive Pokemon such as Landorus-T and Zapdos on a timer. However, using Toxic means that Klefki is unable to cripple threats such as Nihilego and Choice Scarf Gengar.

Utility (Fairy).description:
Klefki's ability to set up dual screens and Spikes enables sweepers such as Tapu Bulu, Azumarill, and Tapu Fini, and its Poison-type immunity lets it check Nihilego, making it an invaluable asset to Fairy-type teams. Foul Play prevents Klefki from being passive against setup sweepers such as Excadrill, Scizor, and Dragon Dance Kyurem. Thunder Wave hampers dangerous attackers, such as Choice Scarf Gengar, Galarian Darmanitan, and Nihilego. Maximum Defense and HP investment lets it take on Scizor better.

Almost any setup sweeper is a good teammate for Klefki; however, Swords Dance Tapu Bulu is a particularly good teammate, as it deals with Ground-, Water-, and Steel-types such as Excadrill, Heatran, and Urshifu-R. Tapu Bulu also provides Grassy Terrain, which weakens Earthquake and gives Klefki recovery. In return, Klefki can take on and cripple Ice- and Poison-types such as Cloyster and Nihilego, set dual screens to help it set up and wear down the opposing team with Spikes. Clefable can stack entry hazards alongside Klefki with Stealth Rock and can make their entry hazards more impactful with Knock Off. Clefable can also utilize a Calm Mind set to break through walls such as Celesteela, Toxapex, and Ferrothorn, which can all take advantage of Klefki. Calm Mind Tapu Fini and Belly Drum Azumarill are excellent teammates, as they eliminate Fire-types such as Volcarona and Blacephalon. Tapu Lele is appreciated, as it offensively checks Poison- and Dragon-types such as Nidoking and Kyurem. Tapu Koko's Choice Specs and Three Attacks + Roost sets appreciate Klefki's Spikes support, as it allows them to 2HKO Nihilego and OHKO Toxapex, respectively, while Calm Mind sets appreciate the extra bulk under screens. Hatterene also appreciates the dual screens support, which lets it either set Trick Room or setup more easily. Its Magic Bounce also punishes opposing hazard setters such as Ferrothorn and Landorus-T, which would be able to set hazards on Klefki. Additionally, it can use Mystical Fire to deal with Magnezone, which could otherwise trap and set up on Klefki.

Defensive Rapid Spin (Ice).description:
Thanks to its high Defense stat, Recover, and coveted move in Rapid Spin, Avalugg is not only able to check physical attackers like Bisharp and Excadrill but also able to effectively act as a reliable spinner for Ice teams. Iron Defense allows Avalugg to increase its Defense stat powering up Body Press allowing it to become a dangerous attacker. However, forgoing Avalanche means Ghost-type Pokemon like Dragapult completely wall Avalugg. Body Press allows Avalugg to deal good amount of damage to the aforementioned Steel-types, while Recover lets it perform its role without getting worn out throughout the battle. Maximum HP and Defense investment with Impish nature makes Avalugg as physically bulky as possible and makes Avalugg's Body Press more powerful. Heavy-Duty Boots makes Avalugg unaffected by Stealth Rock and Toxic Spikes, allowing it to clear hazards more effectively, and helps preserve Sturdy. Sturdy is the preferred ability as it ensures Avalugg can use Rapid Spin even against Pokemon that would otherwise OHKO it such as Hydreigon and Indeedee.

Pokemon like Galarian Darmanitan, Lapras and Choice Scarf Weavile benefit from the hazard control Avalugg provides, as it gives them more opportunities to enter the battle and wallbreak or revenge kill without getting worn out by Stealth Rock and Toxic Spikes. Choice Band Mamowsine can beat Steel-type Pokemon like Aegislash and Heatproof Bronzong. Eviolite Piloswine and Lapras can take care of Fire-type Pokemon and special attackers that threaten Avalugg like Charizard and Gengar. Additionally, Piloswine can also provide Stealth Rock support, while Lapras can beat Water-type Pokemon like Pelipper and Toxapex for the team.

Fast Support (Dragon).description:
Noivern assists Dragon teams by acting as its primary form of entry hazard control and a stallbreaker. Defog and Taunt are used in tandem to remove hazards on the field and prevent foes from setting them up. However, Taunt has additional merit in preventing foes such as Corviknight and Toxapex from setting up and recovering health. Roost is used to maintain Noivern's health and creates opportunities to disrupt the foe later in the match. Heavy-Duty Boots is used to prevent damage taken upon entry from Stealth Rock so that Noivern can remove it for the team. It's also incredibly fast and naturally outspeeds most of the metagame, so foes will rarely disrupt Noivern from performing its roles.

Dragon-types generally appreciate Noivern for its ability to remove entry hazards from the field, as doing so would permit them to stay as healthy as possible. Some Dragon-types such as Dragapult and Choice Scarf Dracovish rely on their Speed in order to break through foes and require Noivern's help more in preventing Sticky Web from affecting their wallbreaking abilities. Choice Scarf Duraludon helps Noivern by using its Speed and STAB Flash Cannon to check Fairy-types, especially those who are faster than Noivern, such as Choice Scarf Gardevoir and Ribombee. Other teammates such as Hydreigon and Kommo-o that rely on setup moves appreciate Noivern's ability to Taunt foes that can prevent them from wallbreaking or sweeping, such as Whirlwind Hippowdon and Haze Toxapex.

Choice Scarf (Flying).description:
Noivern's main role on Flying teams comes from its presence as a great revenge killer that is particularly good for outspeeding Dragon-type Pokemon such as Dracovish, Choice Specs Dragapult, and Duraludon and beating them with Draco Meteor. Alongside hitting Dragon-type Pokemon for super effective damage, Draco Meteor also hits neutral targets such as Pelipper, Charizard, Cloyster, and Gengar hard. Hurricane allows Noivern to revenge kill Keldeo as well as hit Fairy-type Pokemon such as Hatterene and Mimikyu that are immune to Draco Meteor. U-turn generates momentum against Pokemon that Noivern can't beat such as Steel-type Pokemon like Jirachi and bulky Pokemon such as Tyranitar and against forced switches. Switcheroo cripples defensive Pokemon such as Toxapex, Snorlax, Corviknight, Hippowdon, and SubToxic Aegislash by locking them into one attack. The HP investment allows Noivern to always avoid the OHKO from Adamant Cloyster's Ice Shard, as well as letting it switch into Choice Specs Dragapult's Thunderbolt more comfortably, while still having enough Speed to outspeed common Choice Scarf users like Gengar, Terrakion, and Charizard. Infiltrator is particularly good for ignoring Aurora Veil and screens from Pokemon such as Alolan Ninetales and Duraludon, as well as for hitting Pokemon such as Whimsicott, Hydreigon, and Salazzle behind a Substitute, improving Noivern's revenge killing capabilities.

Choice Specs Charizard is a great teammate for Noivern, as it can beat Steel-type Pokemon such as Aegislash, Ferrothorn, and Corviknight that Noivern struggles against, as well as break walls such as Toxapex and Tyranitar. In return, Noivern can outspeed and revenge kill Dragon-type Pokemon such as Choice Specs Dragapult and Choice Scarf Dracovish Charizard has trouble with. Corviknight can use Defog to remove Stealth Rock to keep Noivern healthy and bring it in safely in the Dragon matchup with U-turn, as well as being able to switch into Ice- and Fairy-type attacks such as Weavile's Icicle Crash and Gardevoir's Moonblast. Alternatively, its access to Taunt and Bulk Up allows it to beat defensive Pokemon such as Tyranitar, Snorlax, and Aegislash. Togekiss can switch into Choice Scarf Dragapult, which would otherwise outspeed Noivern and beat it with Draco Meteor, as well as break down bulky defensive walls like Toxapex, Galarian Corsola, and Ferrothorn with Nasty Plot. In return, Noivern can revenge kill faster Pokemon such as Choice Scarf Dracovish, Choice Specs Dragapult and Arcanine that give Corviknight and Togekiss trouble.

Zygarde-10%.overview:
Ground

Thanks to Thousand Arrows, Zygarde-10% is an extremely unique Pokemon that can break through typical checks to Ground-types such as Celesteela, Rotom-W, Skarmory, and Corviknight and remove their Ground immunity for the team. This allows it to completely excel against types such as Flying, Electric, and Fire and improve the matchup against Steel teams, as these types rely on Ground-immune Pokemon. Additionally, its good Speed tier allows it to outpace threats such as non-Choice Scarf Hydreigon, Urshifu-R, Keldeo, and Tapu Lele, and it has good offensive utility in Extreme Speed. Unfortunately, Zygarde-10% is very frail, limiting its ability to stay in on attacks like Celesteela's Heavy Slam, Skarmory's Body Press, and Rotom-W's Hydro Pump without taking heavy damage before KOing them with Thousand Arrows. While Zygarde-10%'s Dragon / Ground typing is menacing for an offensive Pokemon, it struggles to break through generally bulky Pokemon such as Ferrothorn, Amoonguss, and Slowbro due to its only average Attack stat.
Zygarde-10%.comments:
Other Options

Ground

Iron Tail is an option over Toxic to decimate Fairy-types such as Tapu Bulu and Clefable attempting to switch in. However, this makes it more difficult for Zygarde-10% to weaken bulky walls, and Iron Tail's low accuracy makes it inconsistent.

Checks and Counters

Ground

Physically Defensive Walls: Mandibuzz, Slowbro, and Amoonguss are all able to tank Zygarde-10%'s attacks with ease and punish it with Foul Play, potentially burning it with Scald, or putting it to sleep with Spore, respectively. Slowbro and Amoonguss are also especially hard to wear down due to Regenerator. However, walls don't like taking a Toxic from Zygarde-10% if they aren't immune, as they are then constantly worn down during the match.

Ice-types: Ice-types like Choice Scarf Galarian Darmanitan and Weavile can OHKO Zygarde-10% with their Ice-type STAB moves, while Avalugg can switch into it almost freely but risks taking a Toxic from it.

Grass-types: Zygarde-10% has trouble getting past bulky Grass-types such as Ferrothorn, Rillaboom, and Tapu Bulu, since they can take its STAB moves with ease and force it out with their own STAB moves. Tapu Bulu must be wary of Iron Tail, however.

Faster Powerful Attackers: Dragapult, Zeraora, and Choice Scarf attackers like Latias and Jirachi are all common revenge killers that can KO Zygarde-10%.

Priority Moves: While Extreme Speed is useful, it can only KO weakened threats. As such, Mamoswine's Ice Shard, Rillaboom's Grassy Glide, and Dragonite's Extreme Speed can all pressure Zygarde-10% into switching out or being KOed in order to switch to another teammate.

Choice Band (Ground).description:
Thousand Arrows removes Ground immunities from Pokemon like Celesteela, Rotom-W, Skarmory, and Mandibuzz, making them easier to deal with. Outrage dents Pokemon like Pelipper, Appletun, Araquanid, and Celebi that are neutral or resistant to Thousand Arrows while providing valuable STAB coverage and helping greatly in the Dragon matchup. However, being locked into Outrage makes Zygarde-10% even more vulnerable to powerful attackers like Dragapult and bulky walls like Amoonguss, since it becomes unable to switch out for a few turns. Extreme Speed allows Zygarde-10% to revenge kill faster weakened threats such as Alolan Raichu and Barraskewda. It can use Toxic to lure in and cripple bulky Pokemon such as Slowbro, Hippowdon, Mandibuzz, and Galarian Corsola attempting to wall it in the long run. Maximum Speed investment allows it to outspeed Hydreigon, Urshifu-R, Keldeo, and Choice Specs Latios, while Choice Band is recommended to maximize its damage output and power. Zygarde-10% should be brought in through predicted switches or once a teammate has fainted, since it will likely take a lot of damage from powerful attacks such as Tapu Lele's Psychic, Nidoking's Earth Power, and Keldeo's Scald.

Teammates such as Excadrill and Mamoswine appreciate Zygarde-10%'s ability to make their Ground-type moves more spammable by removing the Ground immunity from Flying-types such as Celesteela and Skarmory. In return, Excadrill can KO Fairy- and Ice-types such as Tapu Koko, Tapu Lele, Alolan Ninetales, and Galarian Darmanitan, especially under Hippowdon's sand. Excadrill can also remove entry hazards with Rapid Spin to increase Zygarde-10%'s longevity and use Sand Rush to handle faster threats Zygarde-10% cannot take care of. Mamoswine is also useful for defeating problematic foes such as Amoonguss and Tapu Bulu, outspeeding and picking off faster foes like Dragapult with Ice Shard and removing items like Heavy-Duty Boots and Eviolite from prominent Pokemon such as Blissey, Mandibuzz, Porygon2, and Galarian Corsola with Knock Off. Hippowdon can deal chip damage on foes by setting Stealth Rock and sand, and it can preserve Zygarde-10%'s poor bulk by switching into most powerful attackers such as Dragonite, Terrakion, and Bisharp. Gastrodon and Seismitoad both provide a valuable Water immunity against Urshifu-R and Barraskewda. Nidoking is good for absorbing Toxic Spikes, setting its own, and using Flamethrower to KO Grass-types such as Ferrothorn and Tapu Bulu. The pair takes on Steel teams well because Nidoking has excellent coverage in Earth Power and Flamethrower, while Zygarde-10% can force switches with Thousand Arrows.

Volcanion.comments:
Other Options

Fire

Air Balloon makes Volcanion a good switch-in to Ground-types such as Excadrill and Landorus-T, as it catches these threats off-guard. This allows Volcanion to freely utilize its STAB moves against Steel and Flying teams, alongside letting it Defog on entry hazard setters such as Landorus-T and Hippowdon. However, Heavy-Duty Boots is preferred on Volcanion because Stealth Rock quickly whittles it down, leaving it unable to deal with Steel-type teams. Solar Beam can also be a niche pick for Volcanion to help get rid of foes such as Swampert and Gastrodon in sun.

Water

Volcanion can use a simpler EV spread such as 252 HP / 252 SpA / 4 SpD or 252 SpA / 4 SpD / 252 Spe to be a bulkier or faster wallbreaker. With maximum Speed, Volcanion can outpace Adamant Mamoswine, Adamant Diggersby, and Modest Heatran. Earth Power is a viable option to hit Pokemon like Toxapex, Dragalge, and opposing Volcanion, but Sludge Bomb is usually more beneficial, as Tapu Fini and Mantine force it out otherwise. Toxic cripples common switch-ins such as Slowking, Gastrodon, and Mantine, although it's hard to fit. Dropping Defog forces a teammate like Tapu Fini, Mantine, or Rotom-W to use it instead.

Utility (Fire).description:
Volcanion's unique typing, ability in Water Absorb, and access to Defog make it a great asset for Fire teams. Steam Eruption breaks through opposing Ground- and Fire-type Pokemon such as Hippowdon and Heatran. Steam Eruption also threatens to burn foes as well, deterring physical attackers such as Dragonite and Urshifu-R from switching into it. Flamethrower alongside it leaves Volcanion difficult for most teams to switch into, allowing it to dismantle Steel, Fairy, and Flying teams by hitting Ferrothorn, Klefki, and Celesteela, respectively. Sludge Bomb lets Volcanion threaten Tapu Fini and revenge kill Azumarill after it has used Belly Drum. Earth Power deals with Fire- and Poison-types such as Heatran, Volcanion, and Toxapex, which Fire teams struggle against. 96 Speed EVs lets Volcanion outspeed Adamant Azumarill and revenge kill it with Sludge Bomb, while 168 EVs in HP allow Volcanion to survive an Earthquake from Choice Scarf Excadrill, as well as letting i to deal with threats such as Galarian Zapdos and specially defensive Landorus-T in a pinch.

Cinderace serves as a great teammate, as it helps get through bulkier Pokemon that Volcanion can't always take on itself such as Tyranitar, Hydreigon, and Tapu Fini. Heatran also assists Volcanion by providing substantial bulk, giving a way to trap Mantine and Toxapex, and setting Stealth Rock. Volcarona works well with Volcanion, as it can take on many Electric-type Pokemon once boosted with Quiver Dance such as Zeraora, and it shuts down Steel teams once Volcanion has removed Heatran. Victini helps by being an incredibly strong wallbreaker, helping Fire get past troublesome bulkier Pokemon, such as Landorus-T and Mantine, while also providing pivoting in U-turn. Alolan Marowak provides an Electric immunity with Lightning Rod, helping Volcanion by dealing with Tapu Koko. Finally, Moltres provides a Ground immunity, which lets it take Choice Scarf Excadrill's and Hippowdon's Earthquakes; Moltres also spreads Toxic to wear down bulky Water-types such as Mantine, Slowbro, and Slowking, and it provides pivoting in U-turn.

Defog (Water).description:
Volcanion is a blessing on rainless Water teams, as it is an offensive buffer against Grass-types and provides excellent role compression with Defog. Steam Eruption grants Volcanion a very powerful STAB move, can burn physical attackers such as Dragonite and Azumarill, and threatens residual burn damage on specially defensive walls like Aegislash and Galarian Slowking. Flamethrower has near-perfect coverage with Steam Eruption, checking threats such as Ferrothorn, Zarude, and Amoonguss. Sludge Bomb targets troublesome Fairy-types such as Azumarill, Tapu Fini, and Clefable, which either resist or have recovery to shrug off Steam Eruption and Flamethower. Defog lets Volcanion be an offensive entry hazard remover, forcing out hazard setters such as Ferrothorn and Heatran. 176 Speed EVs allow Volcanion to outpace Choice Specs Aegislash, while the HP EVs let it combat Tapu Bulu and Zarude better.

Volcanion provides excellent entry hazard removal for teammates that lack recovery or are prone to hazard-stacking teams, such as Urshifu-R, Toxapex, and Cloyster. Swampert is essential, as it switches into Electric-type attacks from Tapu Koko, Zeraora, and Zapdos, provides utility in Stealth Rock and Roar, and brings Volcanion into Grass-types such as Ferrothorn and Tapu Bulu with Flip Turn. Slowking is a specially defensive wall that can switch into attacks from Nidoking and support Volcanion's wallbreaking with Future Sight and Teleport. Toxapex checks Pokemon like Tapu Bulu and Dragapult with Poison Jab and Toxic, removes held items such as Eviolite from Porygon2 and Galarian Corsola with Knock Off to ease Volcanion's wallbreaking, and helps wear down Grass-types with the aforementioned Poison Jab and Toxic. Choice Scarf Urshifu-R breaks past threats such as Kyurem and is fast enough to eliminate threats that outpace Volcanion, such as Choice Scarf Krookodile and Terrakion. Rotom-W appreciates Volcanion's Defog freeing up a moveslot for Pain Split, and in return it can switch into troublesome Ground-type attacks from the likes of Sand Rush Excadrill, Mamoswine, and Landorus-T. Golisopod provides Spikes and removes threatening Grass-types like Zarude and Rillaboom with First Impression. Additionally, Golisopod supports Volcanion with its Ground resistance and deals with walls such as Slowbro and Galarian Slowking. Tapu Fini can make up for Volcanion's middling Speed with a Choice Scarf set, letting it remove threats like Hydreigon and Garchomp. Cloyster appreciates Volcanion's hazard removal preserving its Focus Sash, and in return it breaks past Dragon-types like Latias, Dragapult, and Kommo-o. Choice Scarf Cloyster outpaces and deals with threats like Zarude, Tapu Bulu, and Nidoking while also setting Spikes for Volcanion's wallbreaking.

Specially Defensive Pivot (Fire).description:
Incineroar acts as a defensive pivot for Fire teams thanks to its respectable natural bulk backed by a good defensive typing for Fire teams and a great ability in Intimidate that allows it to take on threats such as Choice Scarf Dragapult, Kyurem, Indeedee, and Gardevoir. Knock Off allows Incineroar to remove items from offensive and defensive Pokemon alike such as Galarian Corsola's Eviolite, Alolan Ninetales's Light Clay, and Black Sludge. Toxic allows Incineroar to cripple walls such as Hippowdon and Mandibuzz, allowing its teammates to quickly wear them down. Taunt prevents entry hazards from slower setters such as Stealth Rock from Ferrothorn and Toxic Spikes from Pincurchin and stops walls such as Toxapex from recovering off damage and spreading status. Parting Shot allows Incineroar to safely pivot in a wallbreaker such as Choice Band Arcanine or Choice Scarf Charizard for the team. Alternatively, U-turn still allows Incineroar to act as a slow pivot and cannot be blocked by Taunt. Heavy-Duty Boots allows Incineroar to pivot in even when hazards are up, allowing it to tank more attacks such as Dragapult's Draco Meteor. Intimidate further allows Incineroar to act as a pivot by enabling it to switch into physical attackers such as Tyranitar, Corviknight, and Mimikyu. The given EVs with a Careful nature allow it to tank a plethora of special attacks such as being able to dodge the 2HKO from Choice Specs Dragapult's Draco Meteor, Aegislash's Shadow Ball, and Alolan Raichu's Thunderbolt.

All Fire-type Pokemon appreciate Incineroar's ability to pivot into Ghost attacks such as Mimikyu's Shadow Claw and Dragapult's Shadow Ball and provide a Psychic immunity. Wallbreakers like Charizard, Arcanine, and Darmanitan appreciate Incineroar's ability to safely bring them in with Parting Shot and can just break through any Pokemon that troubles Incineroar such as Mandibuzz with their sheer power. Torkoal's sun can allow Incineroar to more readily switch into Water attacks such as Toxapex's Scald and Gyarados's Waterfall. Incineroar again can take on special attackers for Torkoal such as Choice Specs Aegislash, Indeedee, and Hatterene, which all threaten easily Torkoal due to its pitiful Special Defense. Charizard provides a Ground immunity for Incineroar, while Incineroar can proactively cripple walls with Toxic and Taunt, such as Toxapex and Galarian Corsola, which can otherwise wall Charizard. Incineroar can also switch into Choice Scarf Dragapult for Charizard, which is the only faster Pokemon than Charizard in the Dragon matchup. Cinderace and Rotom-H also form a pivoting core with Incineroar, as each of them can generate momentum with their pivoting moves. Additionally, Rotom-H can take on Water-type Pokemon such as Gyarados for Incineroar with Thunderbolt. Cinderace can also take on Dark-type Pokemon for Incineroar with High Jump Kick, such as Hydreigon and Tyranitar. Arcanine additionally can revenge kill Pokemon that get out of hand for Incineroar, such as Cloyster, thanks to Choice Band-boosted Extreme Speed.

Defensive Calm Mind (Water).description:
Primarina performs the role of a bulky sweeper with Calm Mind for Water-type teams. Its Fairy typing is fantastic defensively, as it allows it to take on Dark-, Dragon-, and Fighting-type Pokemon for the team. With Calm Mind increasing its Special Attack and Special Defense, Primarina can threaten and steamroll through opposing teams late-game while also improving the team's matchup against the aforementioned types. Calm Mind also lets it take hits from Pokemon like Choice Scarf Gardevoir, Duraludon, and Dragapult better. Rest is Primarina's main form of recovery and also cures it of any status condition like Toxic that may hamper its sweep. Sleep Talk is used to ensure that Primarina is not completely passive during Rest turns. Moonblast lets Primarina deal with Dragon-, Dark-, and Fighting-type Pokemon like Dragapult, Hydreigon, and Keldeo by hitting them for super effective damage and allows Primarina to perform well against matchups like Psychic-, and Ice-type teams. Primarina should prioritize attacking more to weaken the team early-game, as such types cannot take repeated Moonblast from Primarina very well. Against types like Normal and Ice, Primarina should set up against Pokemon like Bewear and Avalugg. Maximum HP and Defense investment along with a Bold nature makes Primarina as bulky as possible, allowing it to tank unboosted attacks from Pokemon like Bisharp and Grimmsnarl.

Water-types like Toxapex appreciate Primarina taking on troublesome Dragon-type Pokemon like Hydreigon and Dragapult for the team. In return, Toxapex provides Primarina with a defensive pivot against Grass-type Pokemon such as Ferrothorn and Virizion. Toxapex can not only spread Scald burns, which makes it easier for Primarina to set up on and beat Pokemon like Drapion and Kyurem-B, but also provide Toxic or Toxic Spikes support to wear down teams, which lets Primarina be a more effective wincon in general. Seismitoad provides an essential immunity against Electric-type attacks and provides Stealth Rock support for Primarina to score easier KOs after setting up. Gastrodon can also be used as a bulkier teammate and for an additional Electric-type immunity. Keldeo does a great job of handling Ice- and Steel-type teams, beating Pokemon such as Kyurem and Ferrothorn. Crawdaunt and Barraskewda can also wallbreak and beat Jirachi and Toxapex for Primarina. Pokemon like Cloyster and Pelipper can take care of the Grass-type matchup , with the former additionally aiding Primarina to pressure Dragon-type teams even more and the latter breaking Pokemon like Toxapex and Ferrothorn with Choice Specs-boosted Hurricane.

Sticky Web Lead (Fairy).description:
Due to Ribombee's great natural Speed, it can reliably set up Sticky Web for Fairy teams. STAB Moonblast and Bug Buzz allow Ribombee to avoid becoming passive. Stun Spore slows down foes further by halving their Speed, allowing teammates such as Togekiss to set up against faster threats such as Dragapult. Skill Swap allows Ribombee to set Sticky Webs against Magic Bounce users such as Hatterene, although this is fairly useless outside of matches with Magic Bounce users. Ribombee's EV spread alongside its Timid nature will enable it to hit as fast as possible. Its Focus Sash ensures it can always lead and set up Sticky Web.

All of Ribombee's teammates appreciate its ability to set Sticky Web. Choice Scarf Gardevoir especially appreciates this, as it becomes even harder to stop with foes slowed down. Togekiss becomes faster than all unboosted grounded Pokemon, which allows it to easily set up Nasty Plot. Togekiss can also break past Steel-type Pokemon such as Aegislash and Ferrothorn that wall Ribombee. Since Ribombee's main niche is setting Sticky Web and Mimikyu can block Rapid Spin, the two make good teammates. Mimikyu appreciates Sticky Web as well, as it becomes less reliant on Shadow Sneak to hit threats such as Durant and Dragapult. Grimmsnarl can also pick off weakened airborne threats such as Gyarados with Sucker Punch, which are immune to the effect of Sticky Web.

Toxapex.overview:
Poison

An amazing typing, above average defensive stats, Regenerator, and a plethora of utility moves such as Recover, Haze, and Toxic all make Toxapex one of the best defensive Pokemon Monotype has to offer and allow it to fit on almost every Poison team. Thanks to its part-Water typing, it is able to better deal with Fire-, Rock-, and Ground-types, while Haze allows it to deal with setup users like Dragapult. However, Toxapex's offensive stats are feeble and it's extremely susceptible to stallbreakers such as Mew and Zarude.
Toxapex.comments:
Other Options

Poison

Baneful Bunker can be used over Toxic to better deal with physical threats like Choice Band Rillaboom and Choice Band Victini. Knock Off can be opted for to cripple Heavy-Duty Boots users and other Pokemon that heavily rely on their items. However, the utility provided by Toxic is generally appreciated more. A specially defensive spread along with a Calm nature can be used to better deal with special attackers like Volcarona.

Water

Scald can be used on Toxapex to spread burns against Pokemon such as Ferrothorn and Celesteela, as well as setup sweepers like Bisharp and Dragonite. Toxic Spikes can be used for types such as Fairy and Ice, in particular, that do not have a good absorber. Toxic directly punishes offensive threats such as Thundurus-T and Garchomp, which would otherwise take advantage of Toxapex's passivity. However, all of these moves require Toxapex to give up a crucial moveslot, and the aforementioned Pokemon and types can be taken care of by other teammates. Wacan Berry and Payapa Berry are both decent options: Wacan Berry allows Toxapex to stay in on Choice Specs Tapu Koko to retaliate with Poison Jab, and Payapa Berry means Toxapex can stay in on Tapu Lele and do the same, which is especially useful if the team lacks Slowking. Rocky Helmet is good for punishing attacks from U-turn users such as Urshifu-R, as well as putting Tapu Bulu into Poison Jab range after one of its attacks. Eject Button can be used on rain teams in order to generate momentum. Heavy-Duty Boots can be used to ignore Spikes against Fairy, letting Toxapex switch into the likes of Tapu Bulu more easily. However, Black Sludge is preferred over all these items to help Toxapex stand up to Pokemon such as Dragapult, and another item can only really be considered on teams that are not weak to it. If Toxapex does run another item or replaces Knock Off, Tapu Fini is a decent partner to serve as a good Dragapult answer.

Defensive (Poison).description:
Scald gives Toxapex some sort of offensive presence, threatening to burn offensive Pokemon such as Tapu Bulu and Bisharp that might try to take advantage of its passivity. Toxic nails both offensive and defensive Pokemon, including Volcarona, specially ones that Scald fails to do much against, such as Hydreigon and Gastrodon. Haze helps against setup users such as Dragapult and Mimikyu. Recover in tandem with Regenerator allows Toxapex to be a solid defensive pivot throughout the game.

Heavy-Duty Boots Amoonguss forms a potent Regenerator defensive core with Toxapex and provides the only reliable switch-in to Mold Breaker Excadrill available on Poison teams. Amoonguss also provides a resistance to Electric-type attacks from the likes of Tapu Koko and Zeraora. Drapion provides a much needed Psychic immunity and helps against Ghost-types such as Spectrier that can overpower Toxapex. Drapion also provides Toxic Spikes support. Galarian Weezing provides Defog support and a beneficial Dragon immunity against Pokemon such as Dragonite, as well as dealing with Substitute + Nasty Plot Hydreigon, which may take advantage of Toxapex. Nidoking is a great special wallbreaker and helps greatly in matchups like Flying, Steel, and Water thanks to its wide range of coverage options in Ice Beam, Thunderbolt, and Flamethrower. Assault Vest Galarian Slowking provides a great specially defensive pivot against Pokemon such as Kyurem, Tapu Lele, and Choice Specs Zapdos, which otherwise threaten the entirety of Poison-type teams. Gengar aids greatly against Psychic-type Pokemon such as Victini and Slowbro, while Nihilego is great in matchups like Flying and Water, as it can deal with Pokemon such as Zapdos, Thundurus-T, and Swampert.

Physically Defensive (Water).description:
Thanks to its amazing defensive stats, good typing, and excellent ability in Regenerator, Toxapex is key to Water teams' success by serving as one of the type's best possible walls. With its Poison typing and bulk, Toxapex can wall threats to Water teams such as Aegislash, Tapu Bulu, and Dragapult, and it can use Regenerator to outlast teams by switching. Knock Off is Toxapex's main utility move, and it is crucial for removing many items such as Celesteela's Leftovers, Galarian Slowking's Assault Vest, Tornadus-T's Heavy-Duty Boots, and Dragapult's Dragon Fang. The combination of Knock Off + Black Sludge is crucial for taking down a huge threat in Dragon Dance Dragapult, with Knock Off letting Toxapex remove Dragapult's Dragon Fang before using Haze, and Black Sludge allowing Toxapex to outstall it. Poison Jab prevents Toxapex from being setup fodder against Tapu Bulu, Hatterene, and Tapu Fini and helps spread status against other Pokemon such as Tyranitar and Slowking. Haze is crucial to the set, as it prevents Toxapex from losing to the setup sweepers that it excels at checking, such as the aforementioned Dragapult as well as Zarude, Dragonite, and Volcarona. A physically defensive EV spread is used to allow Toxapex to wall the aforementioned physical attackers, which would otherwise be hard to switch into.

Toxapex pairs well with other defensive Pokemon to form defensive backbones for Water teams. Swampert and Gastrodon are two Pokemon that can switch into Electric-type attacks from Pokemon such as Tapu Koko, Zeraora, and Thundurus-T, while Toxapex can switch into Grass-type Pokemon such as Zarude and Tapu Bulu in return. Slowking is another great Pokemon that pairs well with Toxapex thanks to its resistance to Psychic and even better special bulk, which allow it to come in on attacks such as Tapu Lele's Psychic and Substitute Kyurem's Freeze-Dry. It also has Regenerator, just like Toxapex, allowing the Water user to outstall opposing defensive cores just by switching in and out between the two Pokemon. Volcanion is a good partner that beats Steel-types such as Celesteela, Melmetal, Klefki, and Ferrothorn for Toxapex, and it can Defog away the entry hazards Ferrothorn gets up for free against Toxapex. It also forms a good Fairy-breaking core with Toxapex by offensively threatening Pokemon such as Clefable with Sludge Bomb. Toxapex's defensive backbones pair will with many offensive Pokemon, but Urshifu-R in particular is a really good partner for Toxapex, as it can commonly take on Pokemon that punish Toxapex's passivity such as Ferrothorn, Arctozolt, Kyurem, Galarian Moltres, and Hydreigon.

Araquanid.comments:
Other Options

Bug

Scald may be used with a Modest nature, as it allows Araquanid to fish for burns. However, Liquidation lets it check Spectrier and Roost Volcarona well. A trapping set with Infestation, Soak, Toxic, and Rest, holding a Grip Claw, traps and removes bulky walls such as Celesteela and Toxapex that normally give Araquanid a difficult time; however, if such targets are not present on the opposing team, it turns Araquanid into a liability. Water Absorb may be considered to pivot into threats such as Barraskewda, but Water Bubble's resistance to Fire-type moves is Araquanid's main appeal. Wacan Berry may be used to lure in Tapu Koko and Choice Band Victini, but since Bug can choose to not run dedicated entry hazard removers, forgoing Heavy-Duty Boots may hurt Araquanid's ability to check threats such as Blacephalon and Spectrier in the long run.

Sticky Web (Bug).description:
Araquanid is the best defensive Sticky Web setter available for Bug teams, and it differentiates itself from Galvantula by taking on special attackers such as Blacephalon, Spectrier, and Nidoking. Thanks to Water Bubble, it checks threats such as Volcarona and Heatran, which greatly trouble Bug teams. Liquidation deals with Calm Mind and Quiver Dance users such as Spectrier and Volcarona, and it generally threatens Fire-types. Mirror Coat takes advantage of Araquanid's excellent Special Defense, allowing it to retaliate against threats that don't mind Liquidation such as Thundurus-T and Volcanion. Toxic debilitates switch-ins such as Slowbro, Mantine, and Gastrodon. Magic Coat can be used over Toxic, as it bounces back Taunt, Leech Seed, and Stealth Rock from Cobalion, Celesteela, and Garchomp, allowing Araquanid to set Sticky Web uncontested and maximize its longevity. 156 Speed EVs let Araquanid outspeed and beat non-Air Slash Celesteela one-on-one, while maximum HP EVs allow it to survive attacks such as Choice Specs Tapu Koko's Volt Switch, Hurricane from Tornadus-T, and non-Choice Band Victini's Bolt Strike.

Setup sweepers such as Scizor, Volcarona, and Heracross make great teammates for Araquanid, as these all benefit from Sticky Web and a Fire resistance. Swords Dance Scizor deals with Ice- and Rock-type threats such as Kyurem and Tyranitar, can clean types such as Dragon and Fairy, and uses Sticky Web to outspeed Heatran. Volcarona greatly appreciates Araquanid dealing with Heatran and Victini, as this allows it to sweep types such as Steel and Psychic late-game. Guts Heracross deals with walls such as Toxapex, Slowbro, and Galarian Corsola, and Sticky Web allows it to outspeed the entire unboosted metagame, removing threats such as Dragapult, Choice Band Victini, and Choice Scarf Heatran. Araquanid setting Sticky Web frees a moveslot for Galvantula, allowing it to run Agility. Thanks to Sticky Web, Galvantula even outspeeds Swift Swim Barraskewda at +2, making it a potent late-game wincon against Water and Flying teams. Galvantula also appreciates Araquanid's ability to heavily damage Thundurus-T and pressure Ground-types like Landorus-T. Choice Scarf Buzzwole deals with threats such as Cinderace and Excadrill, and Sticky Web lets it clean frailer types such as Electric, Dragon, Dark, and Fire, which have limited defensive counterplay against it.

Sticky Web (Water).description:
Araquanid takes on the role as a Sticky Web setter for Water-type teams. Thanks to Sticky Web, slow, hard-hitting Pokemon like Crawdaunt and Choice Specs Pelipper become more threatening, as they are able to outspeed opposing Pokemon more easily. Araquanid should be used as a lead most of the time to get up Sticky Web early. Its ability Water Bubble not only boosts its Water-type moves, making Liquidation hit much harder, but it also makes it immune to burns from Scald and Will-O-Wisp, making it harder for defensive Pokemon like Toxapex and Sableye to deal with it. With Liquidation, Araquanid is also able to deal with Magic Bounce users like Hatterene, which can block Sticky Web. Leech Life lets Araquanid threaten Dark- and Psychic-type Pokemon like Hydreigon and Indeedee while also healing itself. Magic Coat allows it to bounce back status moves like Taunt against common lead Pokemon such as Froslass and Kommo-o. It is also useful against Spikes and Toxic Spikes setters like Ferrothorn and Toxapex. Mirror Coat allows Araquanid to beat threats to Water-type teams, like Duraludon, Heliolisk, Noivern, Hatterene, and Choice Specs Dragapult. Maximum Attack investment optimizes its overall damage output. Maximum Speed investment with a Jolly nature makes it as fast as possible to outspeed Pokemon like Mandibuzz and Corviknight, and Focus Sash ensures that it can set up Sticky Web most of the time.

Potent wallbreakers and setup sweepers like Keldeo, Gyarados, Pelipper, Crawdaunt, and Cloyster appreciate Araquanid's Sticky Web support because they are able to threaten opposing teams more and become much harder to get revenge killed. Since Araquanid is weak to Electric- and Rock-type Pokemon such as Zeraora and Tyranitar, Seismitoad makes for a good partner, as it can cover for its weakness against them and set Stealth Rock while also benefiting from Araquanid's Sticky Web support.

SubToxic (Poison).description:
Salazzle benefits Poison teams greatly by spreading status, threatening a plethora of defensive Pokemon along with Steel-type Pokemon thanks to its ability Corrosion. Salazzle should try to inflict Toxic on the opposing Pokemon then use Substitute and Protect to build up damage. Flamethrower is effective against Steel-type Pokemon like Ferrothorn and Corviknight along with various Grass-, Ice-, and Bug-type Pokemon such as Roserade, Frosmoth, and Ribombee. Before sending in Salazzle, you should try to get rid of any hazards, as it gets chipped especially heavily by Stealth Rock. It's best to avoid strong attacks because Salazzle doesn't have amazing bulk, even with maximized HP. Maximum Speed along with a Timid nature allows Salazzle to outspeed Pokemon like Hydreigon, Galarian Mr. Mime, and Froslass in setting up Substitute and stalling Toxic.

Poison teams love spreading status with Pokemon like Toxapex, Drapion, and Galarian Weezing. Salazzle contributes to spreading Toxic to all types and dealing with Steel. In return, Poison's defensive Pokemon support Salazzle because it has poor bulk. Galarian Weezing provides Ground-type immunity thanks to its ability Levitate and can Defog away hazards like Stealth Rock and Spikes, allowing Salazzle to come in safely. Galarian Weezing also serves as a Dragon-type check, with it having access to Strange Stream as a STAB move. Drapion provides decisive immunity to Psychic-type moves. Choice Scarf Drapion uses Knock Off to get rid of opposing Choice items from Pokemon like Excadrill and helps inflict status with Toxic Spikes or Toxic. Toxapex resists Water-type moves and also is effective in inflicting status by having access to Baneful Bunker, Toxic Spikes, Toxic, and Scald. Toxapex is an amazing wall that is fit to survive an attack from and potentially status Pokemon such as Tyranitar and Dragapult. Vileplume resists Water-type moves and takes neutral damage from Ground-type moves, which allows it to take attacks from Pokemon like Excadrill and Dracovish. Vileplume is used to stall out damage with Strength Sap and Leech Seed from an ally's Toxic.

SubToxic (Fire).description:
Salazzle is a good option on Fire teams because of its ability in Corrosion along with its good Speed stat, allowing it to effectively spread status using Toxic. Corrosion is particularly useful for crippling Poison- and Steel-type Pokemon such as Toxapex, Skuntank, Jirachi, and Aegislash, which would otherwise switch into Toxic. Salazzle can also it to outspeed fast threats such as Keldeo and Hydreigon in order to beat them with Substitute + Protect after they have been badly poisoned by Toxic. Protect + Substitute enables Salazzle to wear down Pokemon once they have been crippled by Toxic. Protect is also used to scout against common Choice item users like Excadrill and Galarian Darmanitan, as well as to gain more passive recovery using Black Sludge. Sludge Wave lets Salazzle take on Fairy-types like Hatterene and Rest Grimmsnarl that do not mind Toxic. Salazzle should try to come in once entry hazards are gone to avoid getting worn down by Spikes and severely chipped by Stealth Rock. It should not try to switch into strong attacks because of its poor bulk and should instead be brought in through U-turn and Volt Switch. Salazzle should try to use Substitute on a predicted switch in order to get more opportunities to spread status. Having 252 HP EVs maximizes Salazzle's poor bulk in order to spread status comfortably, while having 252 Speed EVs with a Timid nature makes Salazzle able to outpace fast Pokemon such as Keldeo, Terrakion, Gengar, and Alolan Ninetales.

Salazzle appreciates Torkoal and Ninetales because of their ability to set sun with Drought and therefore weaken Water-type attacks like Toxapex's Scald for Salazzle. The former can use Yawn to make it easier for Salazzle to come in, Rapid Spin to get rid of hazards, and Stealth Rock to help damage foes to make it easier for Salazzle to stall them out, while the latter can use Hypnosis to help Salazzle come in and can use Solar Beam to take care of Ground- and Water-types such as Seismitoad and Mamoswine. Cinderace, Arcanine, and Darmanitan are all fast physical attackers that appreciate Salazzle badly poisoning walls such as Galarian Corsola, Toxapex, and Mandibuzz that give them trouble, and they can all beat Pokemon such as Tyranitar and Snorlax for Salazzle in return. Cinderace is able to use Sucker Punch to help wear down fast Pokemon like Dragapult, use U-turn to bring in Salazzle safely, and use Court Change to move hazards to the other side of the field for Salazzle. Choice Scarf Darmanitan can outspeed and beat faster Pokemon such as Choice Scarf Gardevoir, Zeraora, and Choice Scarf Excadrill, and it can also bring in Salazzle safely with its fast U-turn. Choice Scarf Charizard can be used to help in the Dragon-type matchup, as it can take care of most Dragon-types such as Dragapult and Dracovish once sun and Stealth Rock are up with Dragon Pulse. Choice Band Arcanine can be used, as it can use Extreme Speed to take care of weakened Pokemon such as Hydreigon, Keldeo, and Alolan Raichu for the team mid- to late-game. Rotom-H is a good partner, as it can pressure Water-types such as Pelipper and Primarina with Thunderbolt and come in on Ground-type attacks from Pokemon such as Mamoswine, Flygon, and Hippowdon.

Bewear.comments:
Other Options

Normal

Heavy-Duty Boots is another option on teams without Braviary to help Bewear switch in and take on physical attackers such as Terrakion, notably avoiding Spikes from Ferrothorn and Toxic Spikes from Dragalge.

Bulk Up (Normal).description:
Bewear is a fantastic asset for Normal teams due to its ability, Fluffy, letting it check physical attackers such as Choice Band Zeraora, Zarude, Barraskewda, and Weavile. Drain Punch deals with Steel-types, 2HKOing Ferrothorn and Melmetal and OHKOing Terrakion and Excadrill after a Bulk Up while providing recovery. Darkest Lariat hits Psychic- and Ghost-types that attempt to switch in on Drain Punch, such as Mew and Aegislash, while ignoring defensive stat boosts, meaning that Bewear can face off against non-Taunt Corviknight. Bulk Up lets Bewear greatly threaten Steel-types, while Substitute allows it to set up without fearing moves such as Toxic from Aegislash and Leech Seed from Ferrothorn. Toxic can be run over Darkest Lariat to pressure walls that don't mind Bewear's boosted attacks, such as Slowbro and Hippowdon, while Roar lets it force out these walls alongside Amoonguss and Celesteela, which are immune to Toxic. Pain Split is an option to provide Bewear more instant recovery. Leftovers is standard, but Rocky Helmet can be run to punish contact moves such as Weavile's Triple Axel or Melmetal's Double Iron Bash. 60 Speed EVs let Bewear outspeed Corviknight, while the rest of the EVs go into making it as bulky as possible. On a set with Pain Split, zero HP EVs and maximum Defense and Special Defense EVs can be run to maximize Pain Split's recovery.

Heliolisk is a great teammate, as it can break through Water- and Flying-types such as non-Choice Scarf Urshifu-R, Toxapex, and Celesteela, and uses Dry Skin to help Bewear deal with Pokémon such as Kingdra and Volcanion. In return, Bewear can break through Steel-types such as Ferrothorn and Assault Vest Melmetal, which shrug off Heliolisk's attacks. Chansey, Porygon2, and Braviary can all safely pivot Bewear into a foe it can set up against such as Ferrothorn. Chansey can soak up status that would limit Bewear, take on special attackers such as Tapu Lele, Choice Specs Jirachi, and Hydreigon, and set Stealth Rock. In return, Bewear can defeat Pokemon that Chansey draws in, such as Terrakion and Melmetal. Porygon2 can spread paralysis through Discharge, while checking Flying- and Dragon-types such as Landorus-T and Dragonite with Ice Beam. Braviary removes entry hazards, helping Bewear switch in repeatedly and have better longevity. Diggersby and Obstagoon are threats that help Bewear break through Steel teams while also dealing with physically defensive walls such as Toxapex and Slowbro. Snorlax is a good soft check to Fire- and Ice-types that give Bewear trouble such as Blacephalon, Victini, and Kyurem. It can also set up on Fairy-types that force Bewear out. In return, Bewear can pressure Steel-types that can stop Snorlax's sweep such as Ferrothorn. Finally, Ditto can copy and punish setup sweepers with Imposter, such as Bulk Up Zeraora, Galarian Moltres, and Swords Dance Garchomp.

Golisopod.comments:
Other Options

Water

Liquidation can be used over Leech Life to combat Steel-type Pokemon such as Heatran, but Leech Life is preferred, as it allows Golisopod to defeat Grass- and Psychic-type Pokemon like Rillaboom and Slowbro. Taunt is another optionto stop foes such as Ferrothorn and Klefki from freely setting Spikes, as well as stopping Calm Mind users such as Clefable.

Utility (Water).description:
Golisopod finds itself a niche on Water teams thanks to its Spikes and First Impression, which revenge kills threatening Pokemon that can sweep Water-type teams such as Rillaboom, Zarude, and Alolan Raichu. Knock Off helps make progress against bulkier Pokemon that utilize Leftovers such as Celesteela, Ferrothorn, and Tapu Fini, gets rid of Rocky Helmet from Pokemon such as Slowbro, and removes Heavy-Duty Boots from Pokemon such as Victini, making Spikes more potent. Leech Life makes up for Golisopod's lack of recovery and also helps defeat the aforementioned Grass-type sweepers, alongside Psychic-type Pokemon such as Slowbro and Celebi. 172 Speed EVs allow Golisopod to outspeed Celesteela, so it can remove its Leftovers with Knock Off before potentially being forced out by Emergency Exit.

Swampert is an excellent teammate on any Water team thanks to its ability to switch into Electric-type attacks from Zapdos and Regieleki. Its Stealth Rock also benefits Golisopod removing Heavy-Duty Boots from Pokemon such as Mantine and Leftovers from Celesteela with Knock Off, which helps make progress against Flying- and Steel-type teams. Urshifu-S is a great wallbreaker that defeats Steel-types that Golisopod cannot, such as Ferrothorn and Heatran, while also benefitting from the extra chip damage Golisopod provides with Spikes. Toxapex can switch into Grass-type moves such as Power Whip from Zarude reliably, stops setup sweepers such as Dragonite and Dragapult with Haze, and deals with Tapu Bulu and Tapu Fini with Poison Jab. Tapu Fini provides Misty Terrain for its teammates, which helps them deal with the aforementioned Dragon-type sweepers, and Calm Mind Tapu Fini can use chip damage from Golisopod's Spikes and Swampert's Stealth Rock to sweep easily. Volcanion can also be used to deal with Grass- and Steel-type Pokemon such as Ferrothorn and Aegislash, which are troublesome defensive Pokemon for Water teams to handle. Due to Golisopod's Spikes being rendered completely useless against Flying teams, Cloyster and Rotom-W make for excellent teammates, as they can easily dismantle Flying teams with Shell Smash and Nasty Plot, respectively. Slowking can switch into Psychic-type attacks from Tapu Lele, Ground-type Pokemon such as Landorus-T, Excadrill, and Garchomp, and also Kyurem's Freeze-Dry. Slowking can also pressure foes with Future Sight, especially Poison-type Pokemon such as Toxapex and Amoonguss, while easily pivoting wallbreakers such as Urshifu-S in with Teleport.

Mimikyu.overview:
Fairy

Mimikyu is a unique setup sweeper on Fairy because of its ability Disguise and access to Swords Dance and Shadow Sneak, which allow it to pose an offensive threat and pressure revenge killers such as Dragapult.
