However, the reduced Defense worsens Duraludon's matchup against Swords Dance Weavile and Dragapult, though Dragon Darts still won't 2HKO it. Iron Head may be considered with an Impish nature to deal more damage against Calm Mind sweepers such as Hatterene and Clefable; however, Flash Cannon lets Duraludon revenge kill Shell smash Cloyster. Thunderbolt may be considered to deny Celesteela and Skarmory the ability to come in freely against Duraludon; however, these are handled better by its teammates. Metal Burst is also a notable move, as Duraludon has enough bulk to survive at least one attack from threats such as Zarude, Tapu Lele, and Melmetal. However, this move is extremely prediction-reliant and makes Duraludon prone to being used as setup fodder or giving free switch ins.

Physically Defensive (Dragon).description:
Duraludon is a decent physically defensive Stealth Rock setter that gives Dragon teams a check to Dragapult and Weavile, which would otherwise be difficult to handle. However, it faces competition from Garchomp, which is not only able to set up entry hazards against threats such as Landorus-T, Heatran, and Nidoking, but also has enough Speed to be functional in matchups against types such as Electric, Steel, Poison, and Flying, where Duraludon could be a liability. Still, Duraludon's Steel-typing is complemented by Levitate users such as Hydreigon and Ghost-types such as Dragapult, which combine their pool of resistances and immunities to cover for Duraludon's weaknesses against threats like Excadrill, Scizor, and Mimikyu, making it easier for Duraludon to check them. Flash Cannon weakens Weavile and Dragapult, dissuades Hatterene from reflecting Stealth Rocks, and pressures Ice- and Fairy-types such as Cloyster, Clefable, and Mimikyu. Body Press weakens Steel-types such as Melmetal and Ferrothorn, while Foul Play allows Duraludon to punish setup sweepers such as Dragapult, Dragonite, and Scizor. Thunder Wave punishes switch-ins such as Celesteela and Dragalge, and it offers speed control versus threats like Tapu Lele, Kyurem, and Dragonite. 16 Speed EVs allows Duraludon to outspeed and threaten Crawdaunt with Body Press, while the remaining EVs are allocated to HP and Defense to better handle attacks such as Weavile's Triple Axel and Excadrill's Iron Head. Light Metal minimizes the damage dealt by Weavile's Low Kick.

Hydreigon pairs extremely well with Duraludon: it switches into Pokemon that Duraludon struggles against like Steel-types like Aegislash and Ferrothorn, pivots into Pokemon that Duraludon struggles with such as Toxapex and Celesteela, and provides an immunity to Ground-type attacks with Levitate. Hydreigon can also take advantage of Duraludon's ability to spread paralysis with Thunder Wave, letting Hydreigon paraflinch defensive walls such as Toxapex and Galarian Slowking with Dark Pulse. Choice Scarf Dragapult deals with Sand Rush Excadrill and Swift Swim Kingdra for Duraludon. Alternatively, Choice Specs Dragapult can wallbreak against paralyzed foes without fear of being revenge-killed. Choice Specs or SubRoost Kyurem KOes or severely weakens walls like Toxapex and Slowbro, and Ground- and Flying-types such as Landorus-T, Nidoking, and Mantine. Dragalge forms a hazard-stacking core with Duraludon and is a specially defensive wall that can take on threats that Duraludon isn't bulky enough to switch into, such as Tapu Koko, Tapu Fini, and Thundurus-T. As Duraludon sets Stealth Rock for the team, Garchomp is now free to use offensively oriented sets such as Choice Scarf and Swords Dance to deal with Steel- and Poison-types Duraludon struggles with, such as Heatran and Toxapex. Latias deals with Fighting-types such as Urshifu-R and Choice Band Galarian Zapdos, clears entry hazards, and provides Duraludon a second chance to deal with Weavile and Dragapult with Healing Wish. Calm Mind Latios is a niche wallbreaker that eases matchups like Poison and Flying, where Duraludon is of limited use, and is fast enough to compensate for Duraludon's poor Speed. Dragonite provides another immunity to Ground for threats like Mold Breaker Excadrill and can use a variety of sets to support Dragon teams, including Dragon Dance and Defensive.

Dragapult.comments:
Other Options

Dragon

Sucker Punch may be used over Substitute on Dragon Dance to check faster Pokemon such as opposing Choice Scarf Dragapult and Barraskewda. Dragapult boasts a wide special movepool, and a Choice Specs set with Draco Meteor, Shadow Ball, Fire Blast, and Thunderbolt or U-turn makes it a good revenge killer and late-game cleaner against types such as Flying and Psychic. However, this set's primary goal is special wallbreaking, and common teammates such as Nasty Plot Hydreigon and Kyurem outclass it there.

Dragon Dance (Dragon).description:
Dragon Dance Dragapult is a strong setup sweeper and wallbreaker for Dragon teams, as it outspeeds the entire metagame bar Swift Swim Barraskewda and Surge Surfer Alolan Raichu at +1, making it extremely hard to revenge kill. Dragon Darts is the main attacking move, allowing Dragapult to OHKO Dragonite and Swift Swim Kingdra at +1 and clean most types late-game, especially Dragon. Phantom Force can remove Ghost-, Psychic-, and Steel-types that resist Dragon Darts such as Aegislash, Tapu Lele, and Excadrill. Substitute allows Dragapult to set up on passive Pokemon such as Ferrothorn and Slowbro without fear of status and circumvents Sucker Punch. Leftovers restores health after Substitute and lets Dragapult attempt to sweep or wallbreak multiple times in a match. Infiltrator stops dual screens and Substitute from blocking its sweep. An Adamant nature gives Dragapult a high chance to OHKO Kyurem and Garchomp without a Dragon Dance boost, and it ensures KOs against threats like Excadrill and Tapu Koko at +1. A Jolly nature may be considered to Speed tie with opposing non-Choice Scarf Dragapult, outspeed Jolly Sand Rush Excadrill at +1, and threaten Spectrier without boosts.

Hydreigon is a fantastic teammate for Dragon Dance Dragapult, as it can overwhelm physical walls such as Slowbro, Amoonguss, and Celesteela with Nasty Plot. It also can help Dragapult overwhelm Ghost and Psychic teams while also covering for it's weakness to priority moves such as Shadow Sneak and Sucker Punch. Dragapult repays this by covering for Hydreigon's Bug and Fighting weaknesses. Dragalge provides Toxic Spikes and Flip Turn to wear down the opposing team and pivot Dragapult in safely, as well as checking Fairy-types such as Tapu Fini and Clefable that Dragapult struggles with. Kyurem can remove bulky Flying-, Ground-, and Water-types like Landorus-T, Hippowdon, and Tapu Fini with its Choice Specs or SubRoost sets. Garchomp sets Stealth Rock, provides an Electric immunity, and can directly wear down the opposing team for Dragapult. Choice Scarf Latias is a great revenge killer that aids in the Fighting and Poison matchups and can provide Healing Wish support to give Dragapult a second chance to sweep or wallbreak.

Physical Choice Scarf (Dragon).description:
Choice Scarf turns Dragapult into one of the fastest Pokemon in the metagame, allowing it to outspeed and remove threats such as Swift Swim Kingdra and Choice Scarf Latias. Dragon Darts is Dragapult's most reliable physical STAB move, picking off specially bulky setup sweepers such as Volcarona and Galarian Moltres. Shadow Ball allows Dragapult to pick off weakened threats such as Choice Scarf Tapu Lele and clean against types such as Psychic and Flying late-game. U-turn allows Dragapult's teammates to take advantage of the switches it forces, as well as dent Dark-types such as Tyranitar and Zarude that like to switch in on Dragapult. Thunder Wave cripples switch-ins like Celesteela, setup sweepers like Galarian Moltres, and Sucker Punch users such as Cinderace, giving Dragapult's teammates an easier time handling these threats. Infiltrator allows Dragapult to deal with common Substitute users such as Kyurem, Hydreigon, and opposing Dragapult. A Hasty nature with Choice Scarf allows Dragapult to outspeed threats such as Adamant Dragon Dance Dragapult, Zeraora, Choice Scarf Galarian Darmanitan, and Choice Scarf Weavile.

Choice Scarf Dragpult lacks the wallbreaking and sweeping prowess of Dragon Dance sets, so wallbreakers such as Kyurem and Hydreigon are greatly appreciated, as are physical setup sweepers like Dragonite, Kyurem, and Garchomp. Hydreigon covers for Dragapult's Ghost and Dark weaknesses and can break down Steel, Psychic, Ghost, and Poison teams by threatening walls such as Ferrothorn, Slowbro, Aegislash, and Toxapex, which Dragapult struggles with. Kyurem can remove bulky Flying-, Water-, and Ground-types such as Mantine, Gastrodon, and Tapu Fini with a Choice Specs or SubRoost set. Dragalge provides a special pivot that can sponge attacks from Clefable and Tapu Fini while adding utility with Toxic Spikes. Garchomp is a good wallbreaker and threatens Flying, Poison, and Dragon teams with a Swords Dance set, or it provides Stealth Rock and phazing to wear down the opposing team with a defensive set. Iron Defense Kommo-o deals with Steel-, Dark-, and Ice-types such as Melmetal, Tyranitar, and Weavile, which Dragapult struggles with.

Choice Specs (Dragon).description:
With its blistering speed, solid offensive stats, and vast arsenal of moves to choose from, Dragapult serves as a powerful revenge killer and wallbreaker on Dragon teams. Few foes can withstand its Choice Specs-boosted STAB moves in Draco Meteor and Shadow Ball, and those that do are likely to feel threatened by its coverage moves in Thunderbolt and Fire Blast. Thunderbolt can take on foes such as Corviknight and Toxapex, while Fire Blast is great for checking Steel-types like Ferrothorn. Dragapult can also opt to use U-turn over Fire Blast as a means to pivot out of unfavorable matchups, such as against Grimmsnarl and Tyranitar. Infiltrator is often Dragapult's ability of choice in order to bypass Substitute users, though Clear Body also has its merits in preventing Sticky Web from dropping its Speed.

Despite being a powerful pressure tool in the face of many Pokemon, Dragapult is rather frail and has a poor defensive typing. Against threatening attackers such as Grimmsnarl and Mimikyu, Duraludon partners well with Dragapult, as it threatens them with Flash Cannon. Conversely, teammates such as Hydreigon and Kommo-o can offensively threaten the various Dark-, Dragon-, Ghost-, and even some Ice-types that would otherwise take advantage of Dragapult's frail nature. Hydreigon especially has a unique dynamic with Dragapult, as the former resists priority that would normally threaten Dragapult such as Shadow Sneak from Aegislash and Sucker Punch from Bisharp, while the latter is immune to the priority that Hydreigon is threatened by, such as Extreme Speed or Vacuum Wave from Lucario. This synergy, when combined with their raw power can dominate Steel teams. Dracovish and Dracozolt use their insane physical prowess and incredible STAB moves to assist Dragapult in creating a terrifying wallbreaking core that is capable of 2HKOing the entire metagame. Noivern assists Dragapult through its ability to remove entry hazards.

Special Choice Scarf (Dragon).description:
Choice Scarf Dragapult is a powerful revenge killer that's able to outspeed much of the metagame, including Pokemon with boosted Speed such as Excadrill in sand, Choice Scarf Galarian Darmanitan, Venusaur under sun, and Shell Smash Cloyster. Draco Meteor is its most powerful STAB move and allows it to revenge kill threats such as Choice Scarf Duraludon and Choice Scarf Charizard. Shadow Ball allows Dragapult to revenge kill Psychic- and Ghost-type Pokemon such as Gardevoir and Gengar. Fire Blast lets it hit Steel- and Ice-type Pokemon such as Ferrothorn, Excadrill, Alolan Ninetales, and Galarian Darmanitan for super effective damage. U-turn allows Dragapult to pick up momentum when it forces a switch. Clear Body is the preferred ability, as it allows Dragapult to take on Sticky Web teams easier and lets it still revenge kill threats such as Zeraora and Choice Scarf Gardevoir. Alternatively, Infiltrator allows it to hit through Substitutes and screens, making matchups such as Ice easier. The 4 Defense EVs enable Dragapult to always take a +2 Ice Shard from Jolly Cloyster when at full HP.

All of Dragapult's teammates appreciate its ability to act as a revenge killer, especially in matchups where Dragon teams can struggle such as against Fairy and Electric teams. Hydreigon can take on Steel-type Pokemon with Fire Blast that Dragapult struggles to break, such as Bisharp and Corviknight, taking some pressure off Dragapult and forming an anti Psychic- and Ghost-type core that deals with Pokemon like Aegislash. Choice Scarf Duraludon forms a speed control core with Dragapult, can set up Stealth Rock, and take on Fairy-type Pokemon such as Grimmsnarl and Togekiss that Dragapult struggles to break. Kommo-o can also set up Stealth Rock and check Tyranitar and Snorlax, Pokemon that would otherwise wall Dragapult's attacks. Defog Noivern can clear hazards for Infiltrator Dragapult. Kommo-o and Noivern can also use Taunt to prevent foes from recovering HP or setting hazards, which is especially useful in matchups against Cloyster. Noivern also forms a U-turn core with Dragapult, being able to generate momentum for the team. Dracovish and Dracozolt are strong wallbreakers that can take advantage of slower Pokemon thanks to their signature moves, Fishous Rend and Bolt Beak, allowing them to take on Hippowdon and Toxapex, respectively.

Choice Specs (Ghost).description:
Dragapult excels at being a special wallbreaker because of its vast special movepool, good Special Attack, and amazing Speed stat that allows it to outspeed various threats in the metagame such as Choice Scarf Dracovish and Dracozolt, Hydreigon, and Gengar, which makes it a massive threat to many teams alike. Using coverage along with its STAB attacks, it's able to take advantage of various matchups like Steel, Water, Dragon, and Ground. Fire Blast, Flamethrower, and Thunderbolt hit Steel- and Water-type Pokemon such as Ferrothorn, Corviknight, Gyarados, and Toxapex for super effective damage. Fire Blast is preferred in order to deal greater damage against Corviknight, while Flamethrower can be used for the consistency. Infiltrator can be used for Substitute users such as Whimsicott and Hydreigon, while Clear Body is useful against teams that carry Sticky Web. Dragapult should generally try to find opportunities where it can wallbreak with little drawback, which is easy to do with its high Speed.

Dragapult pairs well with offensive Pokemon such as Polteageist, Gengar, Mimikyu, and Aegislash to break past shared checks and sweep teams. For example, Mimikyu can work together with Dragapult to beat Dragon, while Polteageist and Dragapult can both pose a huge threat to Water. Choice Scarf Gengar can outspeed other Choice Scarf users like Gardevoir and Excadrill that Dragapult dislikes dealing with, and Aegislash appreciates Dragapult's early- to mid-game wallbreaking so that it can try to sweep teams late-game and can cover some of Dragapult's weaknesses using its Steel typing. Dragapult also appreciates defensive Pokemon such as Runerigus, Galarian Corsola, and Sableye. The former two can lay down entry hazards for it to have an easier time wallbreaking and serve as good pivots for Dragapult, while Sableye itself can use Knock Off, Taunt, and Will-O-Wisp to soften up opposing teams. Froslass is a useful partner for Dragapult because of its ability to set Spikes, allowing it to wallbreak more efficiently, and its ability to deny opposing hazards with Taunt.

Choice Scarf (Ghost).description:
Using its already high Speed stat coupled with Choice Scarf, Dragapult is an incredible revenge killer on Ghost teams that can reliably outspeed and check a variety of fast threats such as Choice Scarf Gengar, Excadrill under sand, and Choice Scarf Charizard. Draco Meteor is Dragapult's strongest attack that hits a variety of neutral targets hard while also being particularly useful for beating Dragon-type Pokemon such as Kyurem-B, Duraludon, and Hydreigon. Shadow Ball hits Ghost- and Psychic-type Pokemon such as Gengar, Mimikyu, Gardevoir, and Hatterene for super effective damage, making Dragapult great in the Ghost mirror matchup in particular. Fire Blast allows Dragapult to revenge kill Steel-, Ice-, and Grass-type Pokemon such as Excadrill, Weavile, and Venusaur with more ease. U-turn is amazing for grabbing momentum against forced switches or against bulky Pokemon such as Corviknight, Snorlax, Tyranitar, and Toxapex that give Dragapult trouble. Infiltrator is the preferred ability, as it allows Dragapult to revenge kill Substitute users such as Kyurem-B and Hydreigon effectively as well as ignoring Aurora Veil and dual screens from Pokemon such as Alolan Ninetales and Grimmsnarl, allowing Dragapult to revenge kill Pokemon with more ease on their respective types. 4 EVs in Defense ensure that it never gets OHKOed by Jolly Cloyster's +2 Ice Shard.

Galarian Corsola is an excellent teammate because of its ability to set Stealth Rock as well as serve as a defensive pivot for Dragapult. Stealth Rock is particularly good for putting Pokemon such as Weavile, Choice Scarf Charizard, Alolan Ninetales, and Chandelure in range of Dragapult's attacks as well as breaking Focus Sash against Pokemon such as Cloyster and Dugtrio. Chandelure is a good partner for Dragapult because of its ability to break down bulkier Steel-type Pokemon such as Aegislash and Corviknight with its strong Fire STAB attacks as well as use Substitute to take on Sucker Punch users such as Bisharp and Shiftry. Choice Specs Gengar and Aegislash are both wallbreakers that can beat bulky Pokemon such as Tyranitar and Toxapex as well as take on Fairy-types like Togekiss and Clefable for Dragapult. Swords Dance Aegislash can also beat Pokemon like Tyranitar and Snorlax for Dragapult. Mimikyu and Dragapult work together to take on Dragon teams effectively with their super effective coverage while Mimikyu can also beat Dark-type Pokemon such as Tyranitar and Mandibuzz for it. Froslass is a decent teammate on hyper offensive teams because of its ability to use Taunt on Sticky Web setters such as Galvantula and Araquanid that hinder Dragapult's revenge killing capabilities as well as use Spikes to continuously wear down teams in conjunction with Dragapult's ability to force switches and grab momentum with U-turn.

Dragon Dance (Ghost).description:
Dragon Dance Dragapult is a fantastic setup sweeper that takes advantage of its high natural Speed, outspeeding all of the unboosted metagame after a single turn, which makes it not only tricky to wall but also much harder to effectively revenge kill. Dragon Dance allows Dragapult to OHKO threats such as Diggersby and Zeraora and 2HKO Toxapex with Dragon Darts after a single boost as well as outspeed Adamant Excadrill in sand and Kingdra in the rain, and after using Dragon Dance twice, it can outspeed Hawlucha after Unburden. Dragon Darts is its main STAB attack and can severely dent any Pokemon that does not resist it. Phantom Force hits Pokemon that resist Dragon Darts such as Excadrill and Hatterene. Substitute allows Dragapult to avoid status moves from Pokemon such as Toxapex and grants it more opportunities to set up Dragon Dance. Sucker Punch can be used to gain an advantage over opposing Dragon Dance Dragapult and attack before Cinderace's Sucker Punch, Mimikyu's Shadow Sneak, and Rillaboom's Grassy Slide. Dragon Fang notably allows Dragon Darts to OHKO offensive Volcarona, but Leftovers is an option that gives Dragapult more opportunities to set up Substitute. Maximum Attack and Speed EVs alongside an Adamant nature allow Dragapult to move as fast and strike hard. 4 Defense EVs allow it to always survive +2 Jolly Cloyster's Ice Shard.

Galarian Corsola is the best partner Dragon Dance Dragapult can ask for many reasons; the first is its ability to set Stealth Rock up, allowing Dragapult to serve as a setup sweeper more effectively. It can also cripple physical attackers such as Tapu Bulu with Will-O-Wisp alongside Strength Sap, potentially provide Dragapult free turns to set up Dragon Dance through Cursed Body, and serve as a general physical pivot into Pokemon such as Cinderace for Dragapult. Mimikyu forms a physical setup core with Dragapult, as it can take on Dark- and Fighting-type Pokemon such as Tyranitar, Bisharp, Urshifu-R, and Terrakion for Dragapult with its STAB and coverage moves in Play Rough and Drain Punch as well as revenge kill Pokemon such as Hatterene under Trick Room thanks to its ability Disguise. Aegislash provides a specially defensive wall that can pivot into Dragon-, Fairy-, and Ice-type attacks such as Duraludon's Draco Meteor, Primarina's Moonblast, and Avalugg's Avalanche thanks to its Steel typing. It can also act as a Choice Specs wallbreaker or physical setup sweeper, allowing it to take on Pokemon like Corviknight and Chansey for Dragapult. Dragapult appreciates Choice Specs Gengar's ability to punch holes in walls such as Mandibuzz, Galarian Weezing, Skarmory, and Tyranitar with its coverage moves. Choice Scarf Gengar, on the other hand, can act as a revenge killer against Pokemon such as Zeraora for unboosted Dragapult. Jellicent can, like Galarian Corsola, cripple physical walls with Strength Sap and Will-O-Wisp while also preventing slower Pokemon such as Ferrothorn and Toxapex from setting entry hazards with Taunt. Alolan Marowak and Chandelure most simply can break through Steel-type Pokemon for Dragapult. Substitute Chandelure, in particular, can take on Pokemon, such as Bisharp, while Alolan Marowak is a strong Swords Dance attacker able to soften physically defensive Pokemon such as Toxapex and Braviary for Dragapult to sweep more easily.

Urshifu-Rapid-Strike.overview:
Water

Urshifu-R is a great wallbreaker for Water teams thanks to its excellent Attack as well as Surging Strikes and Close Combat. Surging Strikes in particular allows Urshifu-R to hit through Defense boosts from Magnezone and Mimikyu's Disguise. Unseen Fist allows Urshifu-R to prevent opposing Pokemon from scouting what move it will use. This allows it to break through types like Steel, where Aegislash and Ferrothorn cannot use Protect and see whether Urshifu-R will use Close Combat or Surging Strikes. It also has moves like U-turn to pivot and Thunder Punch to hit Pokemon that resist both of its STAB moves, like Mantine and Pelipper. However, Urshifu-R has an average Speed tier and is unable to outspeed threats like Zapdos and Zarude. This means Urshifu-R sees competition from Keldeo, which is able to outspeed and dent these Pokemon. Its mediocre Speed doesn't hinder its wallbreaking power, though. Pokemon like Rocky Helmet Skarmory and Iron Barbs Ferrothorn can also punish Urshifu-R for using Surging Strikes.
Urshifu-Rapid-Strike.comments:
Other Options

Water

Choice Scarf can be used over Choice Band, allowing Urshifu-R to be a solid revenge killer and outspeed Pokemon like Tapu Koko and Zarude, but it takes away Urshifu-R's damage output. Urshifu-R can also run coverage moves like Ice Punch, which hits Dragon-types like Dragonite and Dragalge, and Poison Jab, which hits Fairy-types such as Tapu Bulu. However, this usually comes at the cost of Urshifu-R dropping a more important move like U-turn or Aqua Jet. Bulk Up can be used to prevent Urshifu-R from being Choice-locked, but it forces Urshifu-R to use up a turn and drop Aqua Jet or Thunder Punch.

Checks and Counters

Water

Status: Burn reduces Urshifu-R's power, paralysis lowers its speed and lets more threats outspeed and KO it, and Toxic decreases Urshifu-R's wallbreaking turns.

Physically Defensive Walls: Pokemon like Slowbro, Galarian Corsola, Amoonguss, and Toxapex take very little from Urshifu-R's STAB moves and can punish it in return with status.

Revenge Killers: Faster Pokemon like Choice Scarf Tapu Lele, Tapu Koko, and Thundurus-T outspeed and OHKO Urshifu-R with a super effective move.

Contact Damage: Pokemon that punish contact moves like Skarmory and Ferrothorn are annoying for Urshifu-R to deal with, as Surging Strikes forces it to take a lot of chip damage when hitting these targets.

Choice Band (Water).description:
Close Combat allows Urshifu-R to fend off Pokemon like Kyurem, Ferrothorn, Galarian Moltres, and Rotom-W. Surging Strikes hits Pokemon Close Combat can't dent, like Landorus-T, Aegislash, and Galarian Slowking. It also allows Urshifu-R to break Pokemon that can boost their Defense, like Iron Defense Corviknight, and break Shuckle's Sturdy, which lets Urshifu-R KO it before it sets any entry hazards. Aqua Jet allows Urshifu-R to pick off weakened foes or revenge kill faster Pokemon like Volcarona and Alolan Raichu. U-turn is nice for keeping momentum against foes like Celebi and Slowbro, which tank Urshifu-R's other moves. Thunder Punch hits Mantine, Pelipper, and other Water-types. Maximum Speed investment with a Jolly nature allows Urshifu-R to outspeed Pokemon like Mimikyu, Tapu Lele, and Kyurem.

Urshifu-R greatly appreciates defensive pivots to absorb hits for it and bring it in safely. Slowking in particular is a great pivot, with Teleport and Future Sight to assist Urshifu-R. Teleport allows Slowking to bring Urshifu-R in safely, and Future Sight allows Urshifu-R to force progress in the Poison and Water matchups. Urshifu-R helps Slowking by checking threats like Kyurem and Weavile. Pelipper sets rain for Urshifu-R, allowing Surging Strikes to OHKO Pokemon like Aegislash and Clefable. Pelipper can also provide Defog and clear entry hazards like Spikes and Sticky Web, which limit Urshifu-R's chances to come in. Swampert and Gastrodon provide switch-ins to attacks from foes like Tapu Koko and Alolan Raichu with their Electric immunities; Swampert also sets Stealth Rock. Tapu Fini sets Misty Terrain for Urshifu-R, preventing it from getting statused, and also revenge kills Pokemon like Hydreigon and Garchomp with Choice Scarf. Rotom-W deserves a special mention as a Choice Scarf user, being able to check threats like Thundurus-T and Zapdos. Wallbreakers like Crawdaunt pressure checks to Urshifu-R like Slowbro and Toxapex. Crawdaunt especially can help in the Psychic matchup with its Psychic immunity. Other Knock Off users like Toxapex are incredibly helpful to remove opposing Leftovers and Rocky Helmet. On a weatherless team, it is a good idea to use another wallbreaker like Volcanion that can beat Steel-types, since Urshifu-R has a lot more trouble OHKOing Pokemon like Aegislash without rain.

Zarude.overview:
Dark

Zarude's Grass typing, good natural bulk, and favorable Speed tier make it a great check to Water- and Ground-types that would otherwise give Dark teams trouble such as Urshifu-R, Tapu Fini, and Nidoking. Thanks to this, it can be useful in matchups such as Water, Ground, and Rock. Jungle Healing and Taunt make Zarude a formidable stallbreaker as well, allowing it to use foes that rely on status ailments to wear it down such as Toxapex, Slowking, Slowbro, and Gastrodon as setup fodder while preventing them from using status moves like Recover and Haze. However, Zarude's Grass typing brings it many weaknesses, leaving it particularly weak to Pokemon like Blacephalon, Victini, and Choice Scarf Galarian Darmanitan. It also heavily struggles in matchups like Steel and Fire, as it mainly relies on Power Whip to deal damage. Its Speed tier is good, but not fast enough to outspeed many prominent fast attackers such as Tapu Koko, Dragapult, Weavile, and Cinderace, making it vulnerable to being revenge killed by them.
Zarude.comments:
Other Options

Dark

(Bulk Up) Choice Band significantly increases Zarude's damage output, giving it the means of 2HKOing Toxapex with Power Whip and specially defensive Celesteela with Darkest Lariat. However, Zarude then misses out on the ability to remove status conditions like burn and Toxic poison using Jungle Healing, which leaves it more easily crippled.

(Choice Scarf) Rock Slide may be considered, as it allows Zarude to revenge kill +1 Volcarona and pick off Fire- and Flying-types such as Cinderace and Dragonite, but Darkest Lariat gives better damage and coverage overall. A Choice Band set may also be considered, as it allows Zarude to terrorize slower teams such as rainless Water, Fairy, and sandless Ground teams, with the boost from Choice Band letting it threaten Toxapex, Tapu Bulu, and Landorus-T.

Grass

Rock Slide may be used over Power Whip in Choice Scarf sets to revenge kill Volcarona after a Quiver Dance boost, as well as dealing more damage to Flying-types like Dragonite, Zapdos, and Galarian Moltres, but Power Whip allows Zarude to pick off weakened threats like Clefable and OHKO Tapu Lele after Stealth Rock damage. Roseli Berry or Chople Berry can be considered in Bulk Up sets to survive a Fairy- or Fighting-type lure move and remove threats such as Choice Scarf Tapu Lele, Zeraora, and opposing Zarude, but the lack of Leftovers hurts Zarude's ability to set up consistently. Substitute may also be used over Jungle Healing, as it also allows Zarude to avoid status, but it reduces Zarude's longevity and ability to set up multiple times in a match.

Checks and Counters

Physically Defensive Walls: Zarude struggles to deal great damage to physically defensive walls such as Skarmory, Galarian Weezing, and Porygon2. In return, Skarmory is able to heal off its attacks with Roost and phaze it with Whirlwind, Galarian Weezing can weaken it with Strange Stream, and Porygon2 can weaken it with Ice Beam and use Teleport to bring in another teammate if Zarude switches out.

Grass-resistant Pokemon: Pokemon that resist Zarude's Power Whip such as Victini, Torkoal, and Buzzwole all threaten Zarude with their STAB moves while it struggles to deal massive damage to them. However, some foes that resist Power Whip such as Bisharp, Kyurem, and Hydreigon can all be hit super effectively by Drain Punch.

Physically Defensive Walls: Physically defensive Pokemon such as Celesteela and Mandibuzz take minimal damage from Zarude's attacks and threaten to chip it down.

Revenge Killers: Faster Pokemon such as Choice Scarf Blacephalon, Choice Scarf Weavile, and Choice Scarf Galarian Zapdos outspeed Zarude and OHKO it with a super effective move. Priority moves like First Impression from Golisopod will OHKO Zarude, while Ice Shard from Choice Band Weavile and Mamoswine can pick off Zarude if it is weakened.

Bulk Up (Dark).description:
Zarude can use Bulk Up on Water-types like Toxapex, Gastrodon, Slowking, and Slowbro, becoming a decent setup sweeper while increasing its already impressive physical bulk. Power Whip deals immediate damage to Water-types such as Urshifu-R, Slowbro, Tapu Fini, and Swampert. Taunt shuts down passive foes such as Galarian Corsola and Toxapex by preventing them from using status moves like Strength Sap and Haze. Drain Punch is an alternative over Taunt, hitting Steel- and Dragon-types like Bisharp, Kyurem, and Hydreigon super effectively. Jungle Healing gets rid of status ailments such as burn and Toxic poison while providing Zarude with useful longevity. Chople Berry enables Zarude to survive Fighting-type attacks from many threats such as Choice Scarf Terrakion, Keldeo, and Barraskewda and KO them back with Power Whip. Leftovers is another option over Chople Berry to provide passive recovery, letting Zarude heal off much more damage in conjunction with Jungle Healing. Maximum Speed investment with a Jolly nature allows Zarude to outspeed foes like Mimikyu, Garchomp, and Tapu Lele.

Mandibuzz handles threats such as Scizor and Dragonite for Zarude due to its good bulk and typing allowing it to take multiple Fighting- and Bug-type attacks. It can also get rid of entry hazards for Zarude with Defog and pivot out with U-turn, giving it opportunities to use Bulk Up. Tyranitar's amazing special bulk coupled with Sand Stream allows it to take on threatening special attackers such as Choice Specs Dragapult, Blacephalon, and Alolan Ninetales. Its Sand Stream and Toxic support can also wear down foes quickly, which Zarude appreciates. Hydreigon is a mandatory wallbreaker for Zarude, as it's able to pressure many physically defensive walls such as Skarmory, Avalugg, and Bewear that give Zarude and the rest of Dark teams trouble. It can also pressure Dragon- and Fire-types such as Dragalge, Kyurem, and Torkoal for Zarude. Drapion can deal with Fairy-types such as Tapu Bulu, Clefable, and Alolan Ninetales, which Zarude finds difficult to beat, and provide Toxic Spikes support. Weavile is also a neat revenge killer for Zarude thanks to its Ice typing, taking out Dragon-types such as Dragapult, Dragonite, and Latias while picking off weakened foes like Tapu Koko with Ice Shard. It also covers Flying-types like Zapdos, Tornadus-T, and Dragonite.

Choice Scarf (Dark).description:
Due to its above average Speed tier and excellent coverage, Zarude performs as a great Choice Scarf user for Dark teams, outspeeding and removing threats such as Choice Scarf Galarian Darmanitan, Urshifu-R, and Choice Scarf Tapu Lele. Power Whip nails Water- and Ground-types such as Urshifu-R, Tapu Fini, and Mamoswine, as well as OHKOing Choice Scarf Tapu Lele after Stealth Rock and picking off threats such as Tapu Koko and Zeraora. Close Combat deals with Ice- and Steel-types such as Slush Rush Arctozolt and Choice Scarf Excadrill. U-turn lets Zarude preserve momentum, pivoting out of switch-ins such as Amoonguss, Toxapex, and Corviknight.

Zarude is walled by Flying-types such as Zapdos and Dragonite, so Weavile makes for an excellent teammate, as it deals with these threats with a Choice Band or Swords Dance set. Zarude can lure in and pivot out of bulky walls like Toxapex, Skarmory, Celesteela, Mantine, and Amoonguss, turning them into setup fodder for Pokemon such as Galarian Moltres and Hydreigon. Specially defensive Tyranitar checks special attackers like Blacephalon, Volcarona, and Hatterene and sets Stealth Rock to wear down the opposing team. Zarude can pivot Dragon Dance Tyranitar into bulkier Pokemon such as Mandibuzz, Zapdos, and Kyurem to facilitate its sweep. Mandibuzz checks physical attackers such as Dragonite, Tapu Bulu, and Buzzwole, utilizes Defog to improve Zarude's longevity, and pivots it in safely with U-turn. Drapion deals with Fairy-types such as Clefable and Hatterene, sets Toxic Spikes to wear down types such as Electric and Ice, and absorbs Toxic Spikes for it.

Grass

Zarude is the premier revenge killer and setup sweeper for Grass-type teams. Thanks to its Speed and bulk, it greatly improves the Steel-, Psychic-, and Ghost-type matchups. Its also an excellent late-game cleaner with a Choice Scarf set due to its wide movepool and Speed, only being outsped by a few revenge killers like Choice Scarf Weavile and Blacephalon. However, Choice Scarf Zarude has trouble breaking past physically defensive Pokemon like Porygon2 and Ferrothorn, while Bulk Up Zarude struggles with common revenge killers like Choice Scarf Tapu Lele and Dragapult. Zarude's coverage also makes it hard to break through some physical walls such as Skarmory and setup sweepers such as Hatterene and Corviknight, which can be threatening for Grass teams.

Choice Scarf (Grass).description:
Darkest Lariat removes Ghost- and Psychic-type threats such as Spectrier and Victini. Close Combat deals with Steel-, Ice-, and Dark-types such as Heatran, Galarian Darmanitan, and Hydreigon. U-turn allows Zarude to gain momentum, pivoting out of potential switch-ins such as Galarian Weezing, Celesteela, and Kommo-o. Choice Scarf allows Zarude to outspeed threats such as Dragapult, Choice Scarf Tapu Lele, and Choice Scarf Galarian Darmanitan.

Ferrothorn is a good teammate, as it covers for Zarude's weakness to Ice and Fairy by taking on threats such as Kyurem and Hatterene, and it sets Spikes to wear down the opposing team further alongside U-turn. Rillaboom is an excellent wallbreaker that can deal with slower but bulkier walls such as Toxapex and Clefable, and it can pick off weakened threats such as Choice Scarf Blacephalon with Grassy Glide. Amoonguss covers for Zarude's Fighting weakness against Pokemon such as Tapu Bulu and Zeraora. Cradily is a great special wall that can take on threats such as Choice Specs Zapdos, Galarian Moltres, and Blacephalon, and it also sets Stealth Rock. Swords Dance Tapu Bulu can deal with walls such as Galarian Weezing, Celesteela, and Ferrothorn, improving the Poison, Flying, and Steel matchups, respectively.

Bulk Up (Grass).description:
Bulk Up Zarude can become an excellent late-game wincon against bulkier types such as Steel and Normal. Drain Punch gives Zarude longevity while threatening Steel- and Dark-types such as Ferrothorn, Heatran, and Hydreigon. Alternatively, Taunt stops phazers and hazers like Skarmory, Toxapex, and Mantine, which is useful in the Steel, Poison, and Flying matchups. Furthermore, Taunt also stops setup sweepers like Corviknight from boosting alongside it. Jungle Healing allows Zarude to shrug off status and provides recovery. Leftovers improves Zarude's longevity, allowing it to set up and wallbreak multiple times in a match.

Ferrothorn covers for Zarude's weaknesses to Ice and Fairy by checking threats like Weavile and Choice Scarf Tapu Lele and sets Spikes to let Zarude break down defensive cores of Steel and Ghost teams more quickly. Rillaboom provides Grassy Terrain for additional recovery, which helps Zarude set up, and checks threats like Choice Scarf Tapu Lele and Clefable. Additionally, it can work together with Zarude to pressure defensive cores of Steel and Poison teams with a Choice Band set. Both Rillaboom and Ferrothorn can also utilize Knock Off to remove Leftovers from Zarude's checks in Celesteela and Heatran, allowing Zarude to overwhelm them more easily. Amoonguss can create setup opportunities for Zarude with Spore, and it can cover for Zarude's Fighting weakness against foes such as Gengar and Buzzwole. Cradily is a great special wall that can take on SubRoost Kyurem, Galarian Moltres, and Blacephalon, and provides Stealth Rock. Whimsicott provides a fast teammate, cripples passive Pokemon such as Toxapex and Celesteela with Switcheroo, provides a Dragon immunity and Fighting resistance, and threatens Kyurem behind a Substitute with Infiltrator.

Regieleki.overview:
Electric

With the highest base Speed stat in the game at 200, Regieleki can even outspeed boosted Pokemon such as +1 Quiver Dance Volcarona, Choice Scarf Gengar, and Choice Scarf Latios. Its ability Transistor combined with its gargantuan Speed stat, decent Special Attack, high-power Rising Voltage, and Choice Specs makes Regieleki a formidable wallbreaker that can shred apart teams with no Electric-type immunity; even bulky resistant Pokemon and dedicated special walls like Kyurem and Blissey swiftly get 2HKOed. It does well against types like Fighting, Dark, Psychic, and Ghost that have trouble taking on Electric-type attacks. However, Regieleki suffers from having a very sparse movepool that does not include proper coverage moves to hit Ground-types for decent damage and, as a result, is left walled by Ground-type Pokemon. This forces the Regieleki user to think twice before attacking, since a Ground-type Pokemon could switch into it for free. It also has a horrendous bulk, which makes it prone to being KOed by any decent offensive Pokemon, especially priority users such as Bisharp, Dragonite, Rillaboom, and Crawdaunt. Regieleki faces a ton of overlap for improving matchups, as Electric teams are naturally good against types without immunities. It's a niche choice at best due to this.
Regieleki.comments:
Other Options

Electric

A suicide lead set with dual screens, Explosion, and Light Clay as an item is an option for more offensive Electric teams.

Checks and Counters

Electric

Electric-immune Pokemon: Ground-type Pokemon have an easier time beating Regieleki; since it has a poor movepool, it cannot deal good damage to them reliably and is therefore hard-walled. Other Electric-immune Pokemon like Zeraora and Alolan Marowak with Lightning Rod can also beat Regieleki, though the latter has to careful of switching in on Ancient Power.

Strong Priority Users: Owing to its horrible bulk, powerful priority users like Bisharp, Azumarill, Urshifu-R, and Dragonite can all deal with Regieleki easily once it is chipped.

Grass-types: Tapu Bulu can reliably check Regieleki, since it overrides Electric Terrain, removing the boost to Regieleki's STAB moves. Grassy Glide Rillaboom is another check to Regieleki.

Wallbreaker.description:
The boosts from its ability, its held item, and Electric Terrain allow Regieleki to hit like a truck with Rising Voltage, OHKOing neutral targets and 2HKOing bulky Electric-resistant Pokemon like Kyurem and Ferrothorn. Thunderbolt is a safe move to use outside of Electric Terrain and also hits non-grounded Pokemon like Latias for good damage. Volt Switch lets it keep up momentum for the team and bring in a teammate against Pokemon like Ferrothorn and Cradily when Electric Terrain is not active. Ancient Power lets Regieleki hit certain Pokemon like Lightning Rod Alolan Marowak for a 2HKO, letting Regieleki beat it on the switch. It is also Regieleki's best attack to hit Landorus-T. Rapid Spin can be used over Ancient Power to compress roles on offensive Electric-type teams. Maximum Speed investment with a Timid Nature makes it as fast as possible, letting it outspeed fast Pokemon like Choice Scarf Latios. Choice Specs boosts Regieleki's decent Special Attack to greater heights, making its attacks harder to tank.

Tapu Koko is a crucial teammate, as it provides Regieleki with Electric Terrain, which further boosts the power of its moves—especially Rising Voltage. Tapu Koko can also deal with Dragon- and Dark-type Pokemon for Regieleki such as Garchomp and Hydreigon as well as Ground-type Pokemon such as Hippowdon and Gastrodon with Grass Knot. Teammates like Zeraora and Alolan Raichu greatly benefit from Regieleki's wallbreaking capabilities, as it's able to blow past Pokemon that check those two such as defensive Zapdos, Amoonguss, Ferrothorn, Blissey, and specially defensive Drapion. In return, Zeraora provides Knock Off support and can use its Choice Band set to form a wallbreaking core with Regieleki. Alolan Raichu, on the other hand, can capitalize on Regieleki's wallbreaking ability to clean teams late-game and take care of Ground-type Pokemon like Gastrodon, Swampert, and Hippowdon with Grass Knot, which Regieleki dislikes facing. Rotom-W and Zapdos provide a good defensive backbone and pair of Ground immunities for Regieleki to rely on while also providing Defog support to keep it healthy and not slowed down by Sticky Web. Defensive Zapdos with Static also checks problematic Pokemon like Grassy Glide Rillaboom and Tapu Bulu for Regieleki and takes care of them with Heat Wave. Air Balloon Magnezone can trap and beat certain checks to Regieleki such as Ferrothorn and Choice item Excadrill.

Glastrier.comments:
Other Options

Ice

A more offensive set with maximum Attack and Speed EVs alongside an Adamant nature can wallbreak more efficiently and outpace Aegislash and Clefable, although it is generally inferior to the bulky set since it can no longer use Swords Dance against opponents like Celesteela and Corviknight harboring super effective coverage.

Swords Dance.description:
Glastrier is a niche wallbreaker on Ice teams thanks to its natural bulk, good matchup against Poison-types and threats like Celesteela, and monstrous Attack. However, it faces serious competition from Arctozolt and Galarian Darmanitan due to its abysmal Speed and inability to wallbreak efficiently without setup. Substitute eases predictions for Glastrier, makes it immune to status from slower Pokemon like Toxapex, Amoonguss, and Ferrothorn, and lets it use passive Pokemon like Pelipper and Celesteela as setup fodder. Icicle Crash and High Horsepower have great coverage against most defensive cores, with the latter providing crucial coverage against opposing Steel- and Fire-types like Klefki and Torkoal. The given EV spread outpaces Celesteela while retaining as much bulk as possible.

Teammates like Kyurem appreciate Glastrier dealing with or weakening walls such as Galarian Slowking, Celesteela, and Tyranitar. In return, Kyurem breaks past physically defensive walls such as Slowbro and Rotom-W. Alolan Ninetales is an excellent teammate that provides extra setup opportunities with Aurora Veil and deals with Fighting-types like Urshifu-R and Kommo-o. With Bolt Beak and Freeze-Dry, Arctozolt pressures common Glastrier checks like Slowbro, Tapu Fini, and Quagsire. Cloyster is an essential teammate for removing entry hazards with Rapid Spin; primarily Stealth Rock; and setting up Spikes. Fast teammates like Choice Scarf Galarian Darmanitan and Weavile can check foes like Zeraora, Victini, and Blacephalon for Glastrier. Additionally, Weavile can clean up types such as Flying late-game once Celesteela has been worn down or eliminated. Mamoswine threatens Steel- and Fire-types like Heatran, Volcanion, and Aegislash and can revenge kill Pokemon like Galarian Zapdos and Dragapult with Ice Shard. Piloswine provides Stealth Rock support and puts Rotom-W on a timer with Toxic while dealing with the likes of Tapu Koko, Regieleki, and Alolan Raichu.

Spectrier.overview:
Ghost

Spectrier is a dangerous special attacker that can quickly snowball teams thanks to its higher Speed than Pokemon like Garchomp and Keldeo, its access to Calm Mind to set up on and become resilient to the likes of Tapu Fini and Zapdos, a great ability in Grim Neigh, and its Ghost-type attacks hitting most Pokemon for neutral or super effective damage. Spectrier can also take advantage of Water and Ground teams, which lack good switch-ins to Will-O-Wisp + Hex. It can use passive Pokemon like Toxapex, Slowking, and Slowbro to set up with Substitute + Calm Mind, and it has good utility in Will-O-Wisp, which can force out physical attackers such as Garchomp and walls like Celesteela. However, Spectrier has very limited coverage, which makes it unable to take on Dark- and Normal-types such as Tyranitar and Porygon2. It also can get revenge killed by Choice Scarf users such as Landorus-T and Excadrill along with fast Pokemon such as Regieleki and Dragapult.
Spectrier.comments:
Other Options

Ghost

Choice Specs can be used to make Spectrier a fearsome special attacker to anything that does not resist its moves, but it cannot utilize Substitute or Calm Mind to take advantage of passive Pokemon like Toxapex. Nasty Plot with Metronome can turn Spectrier into a fearsome sweeper much faster, which helps it beat walls like Mantine, Zapdos, and Toxapex, but it cannot set up on special attackers like Tapu Fini more consistently without Calm Mind.

Checks and Counters

Ghost

Normal-types: Spectrier cannot do much against Normal-types such as Blissey, Porygon2, and Obstagoon.

Dark-types: Dark-types such as Hydreigon, Zarude, and Mandibuzz easily take Spectrier's Hex. However, Mandibuzz can be somewhat hindered by Will-O-Wisp weakening Foul Play or Knock Off.

Revenge Killers: Naturally faster Pokemon like Tapu Koko, Regieleki, and Dragapult as well as Choice Scarf users such as Excadrill and Landorus-T can OHKO or 2HKO unboosted Spectrier with their STAB attacks.

Entry Hazards: Stealth Rock, Spikes, and Toxic Spikes quickly wear Spectrier down. They are especially problematic due to Ghost not having reliable entry hazard control.

Status: Toxic and Will-O-Wisp easily wear Spectrier down, while Thunder Wave makes it unable to outpace Pokemon like Jirachi and Gengar.

Substitute + Calm Mind.description:
Spectrier can set up forced switches from slower Pokemon such as Urshifu-R and Garchomp and on walls like Celesteela and Ferrothorn with ease due to Substitute and Will-O-Wisp. Substitute blocks status from Pokemon like Zapdos, Rotom-W, and Heatran as well as Leech Seed from Celesteela and Ferrothorn, and is very good to use on predicted switches against Pokemon that fear Will-O-Wisp like Garchomp and Dragonite. Will-O-Wisp is primarily used on physical attackers such as Mamoswine, Dragonite, Garchomp, and Tapu Bulu, but it can be useful together with Hex to 2HKO walls such as Celesteela, Rotom-W, Toxapex, and Swampert. It also allows Spectrier to set up Substitute against defensive Tornadus-T's Knock Off and Mandibuzz's Foul Play. Hex goes well with Will-O-Wisp, as the combination allows Spectrier to beat bulky Pokemon like Celesteela and fast physical attackers such as Terrakion, Urshifu-R, and Garchomp. 52 HP EVs and 200 Defense EVs allow Spectrier to keep its Substitute up against burned Celesteela and Ferrothorn.

Galarian Corsola can switch into strong physical attacks from Pokemon like Barraskewda, Choice Scarf Terrakion, and Choice Scarf Excadrill. It can also provide Spectrier with Stealth Rock, Will-O-Wisp, and Cursed Body support, making it easier to sweep. Dragon Dance Dragapult is a great setup sweeper against Dragon and Electric type teams. Dragapult also helps with Pokemon that Spectrier has trouble against like Hydreigon and Zeraora, while Spectrier can take down troublesome walls for Dragapult like Toxapex, Avalugg, and Celesteela. Mimikyu is essential for using its Disguise to beat Dark- and Ghost-types such as Hydreigon, Tyranitar, Zarude, and opposing Dragapult. Mimikyu's Drain Punch can also help take care of Dark- and Normal-types like Bisharp, Obstagoon, and Diggersby. Choice Scarf Blacephalon checks Pokemon like Excadrill, Zarude, and Choice Band Weavile. Gengar is very useful in threatening troublesome Dark-types like Tyranitar and Hydreigon with Focus Blast, Mandibuzz with Thunderbolt, and Grimmsnarl with Sludge Wave. It can also remove Toxic Spikes thanks to its part-Poison typing. Aegislash can use Swords Dance to beat the defensive backbone of Blissey and Porygon2 on Normal teams. SubToxic Aegislash can hinder walls such as Mantine and Zapdos, and Hex Spectrier greatly benefits from Aegislash using Toxic to inflict status onto opposing Pokemon. Its part-Steel typing is also useful against Alolan Ninetales, Rillaboom, and Tapu Lele. Albeit uncommon, Jellicent is a great answer to Kingdra's attacks that Spectrier has trouble taking on.
